Venusaur.overview: Venusaur is a phenomenal sun sweeper in the current UU tier. Venusaur's defensive typing lets it set up on many common Pokemon like Tangrowth, Swampert, Tapu Bulu, and Rotom-W, allowing it to clean teams with its Growth boots. With moves like Giga Drain for reliable recovery, a powerful 100-Base Power and sun-boosted Weather Ball, and Sludge Bomb or Earth Power, Venusaur is able to punch holes in many teams, as with a boost it 2HKOes nearly every Pokemon in the tier barring Chansey. With a Modest nature, it outspeeds every relevant Pokemon in the tier under sun except +2 Galarian Moltres. However, Venusaur is severely limited if sun is no longer active, being outsped and KOed by plenty of Pokemon like Salamence and Azelf or used as setup bait for Pokemon like Galarian Moltres and Thundurus-T. Without a boost, Venusaur can sometimes be too weak to sweep, as common Pokemon like Rotom-H and Moltres are able to survive an unboosted hit and OHKO it back. Lastly, priority users such as Lycanroc-D and Mamoswine can pick off a weakened Venusaur.
Venusaur.comments:
Other Options

Knock Off can be used to remove Chansey's Eviolite while also nailing Nihilego and Chandelure, but generally Venusaur benefits much more from its other moves; it can OHKO Nihilego and Chandelure with Earth Power, and after enough boosts from Growth it can damage Chansey with Giga Drain and outheal the damage done by Seismic Toss.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: If Venusaur chooses to not run Earth Power, Chandelure can stomach any of Venusaur's hits at +2 and take it out with a Fire-type attack. Rotom-H and Moltres are other Pokemon that can take an unboosted Sludge Bomb from Venusaur and KO it back with their Fire-type attacks.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Special walls such as Chansey and Umbreon can take any of Venusaur's hits and stall out sun turns, with the former using Soft-Boiled and wearing it down with Seismic Toss and the latter being able to keep itself healthy with Wish + Protect and hit Venusaur hard with Foul Play due to Growth's attack boosts. Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro and RestTalk Galarian Moltres can take a +2 hit and KO it back.

Priority Users: Zygarde-10%, Lycanroc-D, and Mamoswine can revenge kill Venusaur using their priority moves if Venusaur is worn down, which can happen due to Venusaur sometimes having to take a hit to set up Growth while also dealing with Life Orb recoil.

sets.name: Chlorophyll Sweeper
sets.description:
Growth is a powerful setup move under sun, boosting Venusaur's Special Attack by 2 stages and allowing it to 2HKO nearly all the Pokemon in the tier. It can set up on popular Pokemon such as Tangrowth, Swampert, and Tapu Bulu due to its typing, and then sweep through opposing teams. Giga Drain hits Water-, Ground-, and Rock-types like Primarina, Krookodile, and Rhyperior super effectively. Weather Ball is Venusaur's main attacking move under sun, as its Base Power becomes 100 and is boosted by the sun, KOing Steel-types that resist Giga Drain like Celesteela, Aegislash, and Jirachi. Sludge Bomb hits Pokemon that resist Giga Drain and Weather Ball like Salamence, Hydreigon, and Rotom-H while also hitting Fairy-types like Hatterene super effectively, though it will need a boost to OHKO the former two. Earth Power is an alternative option to hit Tentacruel, Chandelure, and Nihilego harder, but this leaves Venusaur susceptible to Salamence, as Giga Drain and Weather Ball are mandatory moves. Maximum investment in Special Attack and Speed ensures Venusaur is as strong and fast as possible. A Modest nature is typically used to maximize damage output while still nearly outspeeding everything under the sun, but a Timid nature can be used to outspeed +2 Galarian Moltres if needed. Life Orb is used to boost Venusaur's damage output, letting it OHKO Pokemon such as Rotom-H, Salamence, and Moltres after a boost, while a boost to Giga Drain gives Venusaur insane damage output and reliable recovery, making it an unstoppable force.

Venusaur only fits on sun teams, so Torkoal is a mandatory partner, as it is the most reliable sun setter in the tier. It provides the team with entry hazard support and entry hazard control with Stealth Rock and Rapid Spin, respectively. Other Pokemon that take advantage of sun like Chandelure, Darmanitan, and Charizard break holes in enemy teams thanks to their powerful wallbreaking capabilities amplified by sun, allowing Venusaur to sweep much more easily. Venusaur also appreciates momentum such as Teleport from Chansey to help it get in safely as well as give it more opportunities to set up; for example Chansey can bring Venusaur in on physical attackers like Krookodile and Azumarill, which are forced out by it under sun. Hatterene can be run as a Hydreigon check and discourages entry hazards from being set so Torkoal can come in more, allowing Venusaur to sweep more easily.

Nidoqueen.overview: Nidoqueen is an exceptional wallbreaker and capable entry hazard setter because Life Orb and Sheer Force let it 2HKO the entire UU metagame bar Chansey and bulky Galarian Moltres. Its solid defensive typing also lets it check Pokemon such as Nihilego and discourage common Electric-types such as Rotom-H from using Volt Switch. However, Nidoqueen can struggle to pivot into Electric-types like Raikou and Thundurus-T that commonly carry super-effective coverage to break through it. Unfortunately, Nidoqueen's overreliance on its Life Orb leaves it susceptible to Knock Off from Pokemon it would pivot into like Nihilego. A low Speed stat gives Nidoqueen an undesirable matchup versus faster-paced teams, and although Nidoqueen sports a quality defensive typing, it is still weak to common Pokemon in the tier such as Mamoswine and Keldeo. These struggles sting a bit more because Nidoqueen has no form of reliable recovery, meaning it is worn down pretty quickly throughout a match. Lastly, Nidoqueen faces severe competition from its counterpart Nidoking, who sports better offenses and a higher speed tier, making it preferred on most teams. Still, Nidoqueen's better bulk and role compression as an entry hazard setter gives it a role on certain teams.
Nidoqueen.comments:
Other Options

Nidoqueen can run a bulkier set holding Black Sludge, as it can somewhat take advantage of its bulk and defensive typing to better check Lycanroc-D lacking Psychic Fangs and Mienshao and do a better job setting up entry hazards, but this set struggles because it is somewhat weak. Taunt does a decent job of giving utility Pokemon like Chansey a hard time. Substitute can be a viable option to ease prediction on a forced switch. Protect also helps prediction by letting Nidoqueen scout Choice-locked Pokemon it is weak to such as Krookodile and Jirachi.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey is the single best answer to Nidoqueen, as it can consistently switch into its attacks without worry, recover any damage away, and chip Nidoqueen with Seismic Toss.

Psychic-types: Psychic-types such as Azelf, Necrozma, and Starmie all can outspeed and KO Nidoqueen, with Necrozma being able to live a hit and use it as set up fodder thanks to its high natural bulk. Assault Vest Reuniclus counters Nidoqueen and can force it out with ease.

Water-types: The majority of Water-types in UU can outspeed and OHKO Nidoqueen with ease. Keldeo can outspeed Nidoqueen and OHKO it with Hydro Pump, while Choice Band Crawdaunt OHKOes it with Aqua Jet. Milotic and Gastrodon can take hits and deal heavy damage back thanks to their high natural bulk. Tentacruel and Rotom-W can also force out Nidoqueen if Nidoqueen is worn down enough.

Faster Revenge Killers: Faster Pokemon such as Lycanroc-D, Chandelure, Mamoswine, and Krookodile can outspeed and OHKO Nidoqueen.

sets.name: Offensive Entry Hazard Setter
sets.description:
Nidoqueen is a reliable setter of entry hazards because of its above average bulk, ability to force switches, and good matchup versus hazard removers such as Salamence and Rotom-H. Stealth Rock is the better hazard choice for this set, as it provides excellent utility to just about any team, although Toxic Spikes is an option if the team has another Stealth Rock user. Earth Power and Sludge Wave are mandatory, powerful STAB moves that OHKO bulkier Pokemon such as Aegislash, Hatterene, and Tangrowth. Fire Blast is an excellent coverage move and the best pick for the last slot, as it almost OHKOes Amoonguss and cleanly 2HKOes Celesteela. Modest is the preferred nature because it grants Nidoqueen exceptional power and still lets it outspeed most of its primary targets, although a Timid nature can be used to outspeed Buzzwole, Timid Volcanion, and Timid Toxtricity. However, a Timid nature will make Nidoqueen noticeably weaker, missing out on benchmarks such as the guaranteed 2HKO on defensive Kommo-o.

Tapu Bulu pairs very well with Nidoqueen, as it appreciates Nidoqueen taking care of Amoonguss and Tangrowth and in return can check Water-types like Azumarill, Starmie, and Keldeo. Its Grassy Terrain also provides a bit of recovery to Nidoqueen. Wallbreakers such as Azumarill and Lycanroc-D make good teammates because they also appreciate Nidoqueen's good matchup versus Amoonguss and Tangrowth. In return, they can remove specially defensive walls like Chansey and Galarian Moltres. Starmie is a decent teammate for Nidoqueen because it checks many Pokemon that threaten Nidoqueen, such as Keldeo. Rotom-H and Rotom-W are both Volt Switch users that can bring Nidoqueen in safely and also check Mamoswine, and the latter has the added benefit of checking Krookodile. Nidoqueen pairs well with almost any Kommo-o set, as Nidoqueen can break through Primarina and Hatterene to help it succeed. Kommo-o sets using Stealth Rock also can let Nidoqueen run Toxic Spikes.

Nidoking.overview: Thanks to its excellent offensive typing, ability in Sheer Force, powerful STAB moves like Sludge Wave and Earth Power, and excellent coverage moves like Ice Beam and Thunderbolt, Nidoking is a very powerful wallbreaker. It can hit a large portion of the tier for super effective damage, checking plenty of Pokemon like Skarmory, Primarina, Aegislash, and Tapu Bulu. Even though Nidoking is one of the most dangerous threats in the tier, its mediocre Speed tier and bulk mean it can't find many opportunities to wallbreak, mandating pivot support to get it onto the field safely. Nidoking also relies on its Life Orb to do massive damage, so it despises Knock Off from the likes of Nihilego and Mienshao. Its typing also doesn't benefit it much defensively, leaving it weak to common attacking types like Ground, Water, and Psychic from Pokemon like Excadrill, Azumarill, and Azelf. Furthermore, despite being a Ground-type, Nidoking doesn't provide a functional Electric immunity for its team, being outsped by Rotom-W, Rotom-H, and Thundurus-T and getting hit hard by their other moves. This lack of defensive utility makes it hard to justify over other Pokemon that share its Ground or Poison typing like Krookodile, Excadrill, and Nihilego.
Nidoking.comments:
Other Options

Fire Blast is also a solid option, giving Nidoking the ability to 2HKO Celesteela and OHKO Amoonguss after Stealth Rock, but its BoltBeam coverage already deals with both either way. Superpower can be used to hit Chansey for solid damage on the switch, but it doesn't hit anything else, and doing enough damage requires either a nature change or heavy investment, which normally isn't worth it. While Nidoking's higher Attack might make a physical set worthwhile, it lacks the proper movepool, and most of its Sheer Force-boosted moves are special. Sucker Punch is an option to pick off the likes of Jirachi and Azelf as well as other revenge killers like Lycanroc-D, but forgoing coverage or added utility isn't great for Nidoking. Protect can used over Substitute to scout moves from Choice-locked foes and checks like Hydreigon and Keldeo. While you forgo the additional power from Life Orb, a Choice Scarf set is a solid revenge killer while still being an effective wallbreaker.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Thanks to Chansey's tremendously high special bulk, it is able to switch into any of Nidoking's attacks and can proceed to whittle it down with Seismic Toss, set up Stealth Rock, or recover its HP with Soft-Boiled.

Water-types: Keldeo and Rotom-W outspeed and threaten Nidoking. Crawdaunt and Azumarill can both effectively revenge kill Nidoking thanks to Aqua Jet. Slowking can tank a Thunderbolt and deal heavy damage with Scald or pivot out into a revenge killer.

Ground-types: Pokemon like Krookodile, Excadrill, and Zygarde-10% can comfortably revenge kill Nidoking. Swampert can switch into most attacks, but must be wary of switching into Earth Power as it can 2HKO. Gastrodon can switch in relatively easily and threaten it.

Psychic-types: Psychic-types such as Reuniclus, Azelf, and Starmie can hit Nidoking super effectively with their STAB moves. Reuniclus is particularly threatening, as its Assault Vest lets it pivot into Nidoking and force it out.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Sludge Wave is Nidoking's strongest STAB move, hitting Pokemon like Hatterene, Tangrowth, and Primarina super effectively, as well as discouraging Rotom-W and Rotom-H from switching in freely. Earth Power slams Steel- and Poison-types such as Jirachi, Aegislash, and Nihilego. Thunderbolt allows Nidoking to nail Water- and Flying-types like Slowking, Skarmory, Celesteela, and Gyarados. Ice Beam can be used to OHKO opposing Ground-types like Krookodile, as well as OHKOing Salamence and Noivern, while Substitute makes Nidoking much less prediction reliant, giving it free turns against foes that it forces out like Nihilego, Tangrowth, and Aegislash. Stealth Rock can be run for role compression thanks to Nidoking preventing common entry hazard removers like Excadrill and Tentacruel from switching into it. A Modest nature should be run to increase Nidoking's damage output against threats like Slowking and Mandibuzz, since it doesn't miss out on any notable Speed benchmarks. Life Orb and Sheer Force pair together to negate the health loss of Life Orb while giving an effective 70% power boost, which is a big factor behind Nidoking's power.

Nidoking fits best on offensive teams that are able to bring it in many times to wallbreak and tear through defensive Pokemon like Amoonguss and Aegislash. As a result, pivots such as Rotom-W, Zarude, and Mienshao make for good partners. Mienshao comfortably beats Chansey, Zarude forces out Swampert, and Rotom-W lures in Tangrowth for Nidoking and OHKOes Krookodile. Chansey is also a great partner for Nidoking, providing pivot support while beating its common checks like Rotom-W and Hydreigon. Switch-ins to Psychic-, Ground-, and Water-type attacks like Jirachi, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss can be paired with Nidoking on bulkier teams. Jirachi also provides entry hazard support, allowing Nidoking to reliably KO Celesteela, and Healing Wish support to let it wallbreak even more. Tangrowth and Amoonguss are also able to handle Electric-types in the tier much better than Nidoking and can pivot into the likes of Lycanroc-D and Keldeo excellently. Late-game cleaners like the aforementioned Mienshao and Lycanroc-D are great to break through Chansey, which Nidoking struggles against. Sticky Web support from Ribombee offsets Nidoking's average Speed tier, allowing it to outspeed and OHKO threats like Tentacruel, Excadrill, and Lycanroc-D.

Tentacruel.overview: With incredible Special Defense, an excellent defensive typing that allows it to deal with threats like Primarina, Keldeo, and Celesteela, and the distinction of being one of the only viable Rapid Spin users in the tier, Tentacruel is a solid option for many balance and bulky offense teams. Its base 100 Speed and wide utility movepool that includes options like Knock Off and Haze allow it to outspeed threats like Nidoking and Chandelure and trade with top threats like Keldeo. While its Special Defense is excellent, its Defense and HP are fairly poor, making it difficult for Tentacruel to switch into strong physical attackers like Lycanroc-D and Buzzwole. This is further worsened by Tentacruel's mediocre attacking stats making it difficult to acquire KOs and leaving it overly reliant on status, which worsen its matchup against foes like Buzzwole and setup sweepers like Galarian Moltres and Azelf. These weaknesses also put Tentacruel at a disadvantage against entry hazard setters like Krookodile, Nidoqueen, and Seismitoad, which can handle Scald, and make it difficult to remove entry hazards.
Tentacruel.comments:
Other Options

Toxic Spikes can be used to give Tentacruel its own method of setting up entry hazards, but it is unreliable due to the prevalence of Heavy-Duty Boots and Amoonguss. Toxic lets Tentacruel cripple switch-ins such as Seismitoad and Salamence but is hard to fit. Clear Body can be used to better counter Sticky Web teams, but is not very useful otherwise.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric types such as Thundurus-T, Raikou, and Rotom-W severely dent Tentacruel with their STAB attacks. The latter two can also easily use Volt Switch on Tentacruel to generate free momentum.

Ground-types: Krookodile easily OHKOes Tentacruel with Earthquake, although it doesn't like having to take a Scald in the process. Seismitoad and Gastrodon are immune to Scald and resistant to Sludge Bomb, which means Tentacruel can only force progress by fishing for poison against them. Gastrodon also has reliable recovery, which makes fishing for poison even more ineffective.

Dragon-types: Kommo-o can easily switch into Tentacruel and force it out. Salamence and Noivern can also switch into it easily, although Tentacruel does have enough special bulk to stay in against them and remove their Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off.

Psychic-types: Hatterene, Reuniclus, and Necrozma easily OHKO Tentacruel with Psyshock or Photon Geyser, although Hatterene doesn't like taking a Sludge Bomb, and both Reuniclus and Necrozma don't like taking a Knock Off. Galarian Slowbro is especially troublesome for Tentacruel, as it cannot be poisoned and can easily set up on Tentacruel with Calm Mind.

Physical Attackers: Conkeldurr, Lycanroc-D, and Gyarados can muscle through Tentacruel due to its poor Defense. The former is especially dangerous, as unlike the latter two, it doesn't have to fear getting burned by Scald.

sets.name: Defensive Spinner
sets.description:
Sludge Bomb prevents Tentacruel from being too passive and hits foes such as Tangrowth, Tapu Bulu, and Azumarill. It also has a chance to poison, which is useful for crippling threats like Salamence and Suicune. Rapid Spin can provide a boost to Tentacruel's Speed, letting it outspeed common Pokemon like Lycanroc-D, Noivern, and Azelf. Knock Off cripples checks like Seismitoad and Gastrodon. Haze allows Tentacruel to shut down setup sweepers like Clangorous Soul Kommo-o, Calm Mind Primarina, and Belly Drum Azumarill, which can take advantage of its passivity. Black Sludge gives Tentacruel a form of recovery, which it completely lacks otherwise. Liquid Ooze punishes draining moves such as Leech Seed, allowing it to deal passive damage to foes that rely on these moves for recovery, like Celesteela and Amoonguss. A Timid nature and 144 Speed EVs allow Tentacruel to outspeed Mamoswine, Chandelure, and maximum Speed Rotom-W. The rest of the EVs are put into Defense to more easily deal with Lycanroc-D and Azumarill.

Tentacruel is best used on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its ability to remove entry hazards. Entry hazard setters like Jirachi, Rhyperior, and Krookodile benefit greatly from Tentacruel removing Heavy-Duty Boots with Knock Off and clearing entry hazards solely from its side of the field, which let them fully capitalize on their entry hazards. Krookodile also sports crucial immunities to Electric and Psychic, which allow it to check foes like Thundurus-T and Galarian Slowbro for Tentacruel. Grass-types like Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu provide switch-ins to some of Tentacruel's biggest checks such as Thundurus-T, Raikou, and Krookodile. The latter can also set up Grassy Terrain, which provides Tentacruel with another source of recovery and weakens Earthquake. Sylveon provides Wish support for Tentacruel, another form of recovery, and acts as a secondary check to Buzzwole and Keldeo. Pokemon like Salamence, Moltres, and Rotom-H appreciate Tentacruel's Rapid Spin allowing them to forego Defog. Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi are greatly valued as partners for Tentacruel, as they can check Psychic- and Dragon-types like Reuniclus and Kommo-o, which Tentacruel struggles with.

Slowbro-Galar.overview: Thanks to its amazing ability and typing, Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro can act as a great late-game cleaner. Its resistances let it stomach hits from the likes of Nihilego and Amoonguss, and its Poison STAB allows it to threaten Pokemon such as Primarina and Tangrowth. Galarian Slowbro's decent bulk and Regenerator let it come in multiple times to spam Sludge Bomb or Scald, wearing checks like Jirachi and Gastrodon down through potential poison and burns. It can similarly cripple offensive checks like Krookodile, Zarude, and Keldeo, which it can take a hit from and then switch out. Regenerator lets Galarian Slowbro easily set up even if it's been weakened or forced out early-game, and it's very difficult to take out once it gets going with Calm Mind. Its immunity to Toxic also contributes to its longevity. Being capable of using Colbur or Shuca Berry forces Pokemon like Zarude and Mamoswine to scout for its specific Berry. However, its very low Speed for a sweeper lets Pokemon like Krookodile, Diggersby, and Azumarill revenge kill it. Its special bulk is not good before setting up, leaving it weak to special attackers such as Primarina and Galarian Moltres. Galarian Slowbro can easily become setup fodder for Pokemon like Calm Mind Reuniclus and Suicune. Furthermore, it faces competition with Reuniclus as a Calm Mind sweeper because of its Magic Guard and ability to beat Pokemon like Celesteela more easily. Reuniclus is also not weak to Ground, easing matchups against Pokemon like Gastrodon and Nidoqueen.
Slowbro-Galar.comments:
Other Options

Heavy-Duty Boots preventing entry hazard damage can create more setup opportunities.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Choice Band Krookodile, Crawdaunt, and Galarian Moltres scare Galarian Slowbro with their Dark-type attacks. The former two do huge amounts of damage to Shuca Berry Galarian Slowbro, and even after consuming its Colbur Berry, Knock Off still does a good chunk. Galarian Moltres takes advantage of Galarian Slowbro's bad Special Defense before it sets up. It also doesn't fear status thanks to Rest.

Ground-types: Quagsire doesn't care about Galarian Slowbro's boosts thanks to Unaware. Rhyperior, Mamoswine, Diggersby, and Krookodile can remove Galarian Slowbro with their powerful Earthquakes, but they have to be wary of Scald and potential burns. Furthermore, they should only be brought in to revenge kill Galarian Slowbro and while knowing its item, as Shuca Berry can negate its Ground weakness.

Ghost-types: Both Aegislash and Chandelure can exploit the low Special Defense of Galarian Slowbro before setting up. They also can heavily damage Assault Vest variants, though they dislike taking a super effective hit in return if they fail to KO it.

Knock Off and Trick: All of Galarian Slowbro's sets hate Knock Off, Trick, or both even. Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro can lose its Assault Vest against Pokemon it normally checks like Nihilego, making it a weaker pivot into threats like Thundurus-T. Both Assault Vest and Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro get crippled by Trick from threats like Jirachi and Rotom-W.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
Future Sight lets Galarian Slowbro assist teammates like Zarude by preventing checks such as Buzzwole from freely switching in. Ice Beam can be used in its place to hit Salamence and Kommo-o a bit harder, especially on teams that don't benefit from the Future Sight support as much. Psyshock lets Galarian Slowbro immediately threaten Pokemon like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Amoonguss without having to rely on Future Sight. Shell Side Arm is mostly used to pressure Calm Mind Primarina. Sludge Bomb is an alternative to fish for poison more reliably on foes like Salamence when not running Ice Beam, but it's not as reliable overall due to being worse against Calm Mind users. Flamethrower targets Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi. It also hits Buzzwole harder than Psyshock without depending on Future Sight. Eathquake is an option to hit Nihilego, Tentacruel, and Aegislash on teams that struggle to fit Psyshock and Flamethrower. Scald is another option that nails Krookodile on the switch as well as Rhyperior. Assault Vest lets Galarian Slowbro face special attackers like Keldeo, Primarina, and Salamence with ease. A Quiet nature is used to secure an OHKO with Ice Beam on Salamence and to not lower Galarian Slowbro's damage output when using physical Shell Side Arm while still boosting its Special Attack. 16 Special Attack EVs make Galarian Slowbro less passive overall.

Mienshao, Buzzwole, and Lycanroc-D love Galarian Slowbro's Future Sight support letting them break through checks like Buzzwole and Amoonguss a lot more easily. They also appreciate Galarian Slowbro's ability to pressure checks like Salamence and Tapu Bulu with its coverage. In return, they threaten Dark-types like Zarude and Krookodile with their Fighting-type attacks. Amoonguss, Buzzwole, and Tapu Bulu make for great partners, as they take on physical attackers like Lycanroc-D and Crawdaunt, act as Knock Off absorbers, and check Dark- and Ground-types like Zarude and Rhyperior. Amoonguss notably forms a Regenerator core with Galarian Slowbro and acts as a great secondary check to Keldeo and Primarina. Secondary checks to special attackers such as Nidoking, Aegislash, and Nihilego are needed, as Galarian Slowbro is 2HKOed by STAB moves from the former two and hates losing its Assault Vest to the latter's Knock Off. Rotom-W, Zarude, and Cobalion are Pokemon that can pivot into their STAB attacks and keep offensive presence. Entry hazard removal from partners like Salamence and Starmie is appreciated to facilitate Galarian Slowbro's ability to check special attackers like Salamence.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Calm Mind allows Galarian Slowbro to muscle through checks like Jirachi and Gastrodon. Psyshock has great synergy with Flamethrower, the former hitting Nihilego and Chansey while the latter targets Steel-types like Aegislash. Sludge Bomb is an option to cripple Pokemon like Galarian Moltres and Crawdaunt, while also doing more damage to Primarina and Hatterene. Scald is aimed at Ground-types such as Rhyperior and Krookodile, and it can burn physically offensive threats like Kommo-o. However, it will have a harder time dealing with Aegislash. Slack Off helps Galarian Slowbro pose a constant threat and set up on Pokemon like Celesteela. Shuca Berry does the same against Ground-types like Nidoking and Mamoswine. Kasib Berry lets you take a Shadow Ball from Aegislash and retaliate back with a boosted Flamethrower. Colbur Berry lets it take an attack like Zarude's Darkest Lariat and KO back. Safety Goggles is an option that lets Galarian Slowbro beat Amoonguss and stay in against Spore. A Bold nature and the given EV spread help against physical attackers such as Azumarill. An EV spread of 252 HP / 152 Def / 104 SpD with a Bold nature avoids the 2HKO from Choice Specs Primarina's Moonblast, lets +1 Galarian Slowbro always take Choice Specs Chandelure's Shadow Ball, and improves its odds at beating Aegislash.

Tapu Bulu is an exceptional teammate for its Grassy Terrain, which allows Galarian Slowbro to face Ground-types like Mamoswine and Rhyperior more easily. Tapu Bulu also takes on dangerous threats like Crawdaunt, while Galarian Slowbro removes Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth can remove Krookodile and Rhyperior, some the largest Ground-type threats to Galarian Slowbro. Due to Galarian Slowbro's low Speed, pivots that can get it in safely against setup fodder are ideal teammates. Jirachi and Zarude can use U-turn in front of Pokemon like Celesteela and Buzzwole. Raikou and Rotom-W can use Volt Switch on Grass-types and offensively check Chandelure. Galarian Slowbro appreciates Mienshao and Buzzwole checking Dark-types such as Krookodile and Crawdaunt. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Salamence and Rotom-W is needed. Strong wallbreakers like Choice Band Krookodile and Buzzwole can remove Calm Mind sweepers that beat Galarian Slowbro one-on-one like Suicune.

sets.name: QCQD
sets.description:
Galarian Slowbro is able to maximize its power with Nasty Plot and destroy would-be checks like Kommo-o and Aegislash. The chance to activate either Quick Draw or Quick Claw is 44%, which makes a fortunate Galarian Slowbro difficult to check. Galarian Slowbro can be tailored to what it needs to break. Psyshock is useful for dealing with Keldeo and Chansey. Fire Blast is essential for hitting Steel-types like Celesteela and Aegislash. Ice Beam hits common Pokemon such as Salamence, Krookodile, and Thundurus-T, but Grass Knot is an alternative to have a better matchup against bulkier teams, as it can OHKO Quagsire and Rhyperior. Other combinations of these moves like Sludge Wave / Psyshock / Fire Blast or Weather Ball with rain support are also acceptable, depending on the rest of the team.

Quick Claw Quick Draw Galarian Slowbro is best on hyper offense structures, especially with team support from Pokemon such as Alolan Ninetales, which helps it set up much easier. Galarian Slowbro is also useful on Sticky Web teams, where it can be slightly less reliant on Quick Claw + Quick Draw to outspeed Amoonguss and Aegislash and provide some defensive utility with its resistances and ability to absorb Toxic Spikes. Entry hazard support from Pokemon such as Krookodile can facilitate an easier sweep. Galarian Slowbro is vulnerable to Pokemon like Krookodile and Kommo-o, so other setup sweepers such as Galarian Moltres and Salamence are good partners. Rotom-W and Zarude can draw in passive Pokemon such as Chansey and Tangrowth for Galarian Slowbro. In return, Galarian Slowbro can lure Kommo-o and Tangrowth.

Chansey.overview: Chansey's sky-high, Eviolite-boosted special bulk allows it to wall nearly every special attacker in UU, including fearsome threats such as Nidoking and Primarina. In addition, Chansey can withstand certain physical attacks from setup sweepers like Gyarados and Salamence before they are sufficiently boosted and cripple them with Toxic. Chansey is also hard to wear down, since it has Soft-Boiled for HP recovery and Natural Cure to remove status ailments. It also has many utility moves such as Teleport and Stealth Rock to support its team. However, Chansey is rather passive, as it relies on Seismic Toss and Toxic to deal damage. As a result, many Pokemon such as Aegislash, Galarian Slowbro, and Reuniclus, easily take advantage of Chansey. Without Teleport, Chansey is a huge momentum drain for non-stall teams. Chansey's typing provides few useful resistances, and Chansey by itself must rely on its bulk to keep threats in check. Chansey is vulnerable to every entry hazard, meaning it gets overwhelmed by them quickly. Chansey is also susceptible to Knock Off and Trick, as without Eviolite, it is harder for Chansey to keep threats in check.
Chansey.comments:
Other Options

Chansey can run Counter to surprise physical attackers. However, it's hard to fit over another move, works only once as a lure, and depends on prediction. Wish is helpful to heal teammates, especially those without a reliable recovery move. However, Chansey prefers the one-turn recovery in Soft-Boiled to be a reliable wall. Additionally, many Pokemon on stall teams have reliable recovery and prefer the Stealth Rock or Heal Bell support.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types and Fighting-type Coverage: Fighting-types such as Mienshao, Conkeldurr, and Keldeo can easily break through Chansey with their powerful STAB moves. Strong physical attackers with Fighting-type coverage such as Aegislash, Lycanroc-D, and Tapu Bulu are also able to break through Chansey easily. However, all but Conkeldurr dislike being crippled by Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Strong Physical Attackers: Strong physical attackers such as Diggersby, Mamoswine, and Azumarill can break through Chansey despite its Defense investment with their powerful moves or weaken it by removing its Eviolite with Knock Off. However, most fear Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Bulky setup sweepers such as Swords Dance Aegislash and Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro are immune to Toxic and take advantage of Chansey's passive nature.

Knock Off and Trick: Every Knock Off user, including Krookodile, Nihilego, and Tangrowth is a huge threat to Chansey, as once it loses its Eviolite, it is harder for it to switch into attacks. Trick users like Jirachi and Chandelure limit Chansey's effectiveness by crippling it with a Choice item.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Seismic Toss makes Chansey less passive, since it deals reliable damage to all but Ghost-types. Toxic helps Chansey wear down opposing Pokemon, especially bulky foes like Salamence, Tangrowth, and Moltres. Teleport is a great support move to bring other teammates safely onto the battlefield and to keep up momentum. Since Chansey has little to fear from many special attackers, it can force switches and get many opportunities to set up Stealth Rock. Chansey can use Heal Bell to support its teammates; however, this is usually only considered on balance and stall teams. Thunder Wave can be used instead of Toxic to support slow teammates, but it makes Chansey weaker against bulky Pokemon and has less use overall. Maximum investment in Defense and HP alongside a Bold nature allows Chansey to check Starmie and Hatterene as well as weaker physical attackers such Rhyperior more effectively.

Chansey can fit on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams as a sturdy wall for special attackers. Sturdy physical walls such as Tangrowth and Skarmory can check threatening wallbreakers such as Lycanroc-D and Diggersby for Chansey. In return, Chansey checks strong special attackers such as Nidoking, Moltres, and Primarina. Wallbreakers such as mixed Aegislash, Lycanroc-D, and Crawdaunt appreciate Teleport Chansey's ability to bring them safely onto the battlefield. Since entry hazards limit Chansey's ability to switch into attacks and force it to recover more, entry hazard control from Salamence, Hatterene, and Excadrill is crucial. Quagsire and Haze Tentacruel can check threatening setup sweepers like Aegislash and Galarian Slowbro. Ditto is also an option to keep offensive setup sweepers like Azumarill and Gyarados in check. A good Knock Off absorber such as Tangrowth, Amoonguss, or Cobalion is helpful, as Chansey needs Eviolite to better switch into attacks. Amoonguss is also able to check Keldeo and Azumarill.

Starmie.overview: With a variety of coverage moves like Ice Beam and Psyshock alongside a great Speed tier to outrun top UU Pokemon like Keldeo, Nihilego, and Salamence, Starmie is a solid offensive threat in the UU metagame, being able to threaten nearly the entire tier for super effective damage and 2HKO most of it. Starmie's wide coverage allows it to force many switches, and its ability Analytic severely punishes nearly all of them. Starmie also has great utility options: access to reliable recovery in Recover allows it to check Pokemon like Celesteela and Keldeo more reliably, while Rapid Spin lets it clear entry hazards thanks to its solid matchup against common setters like Rhyperior and Nihilego. However, while Starmie's attacks can hit exceptionally hard, specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Tangrowth are able to take non-Analytic-boosted attacks and take advantage of it. Other Pokemon like Aegislash and Rotom-W have enough bulk to take a hit from Starmie and threaten it in return. Furthermore, Starmie is prone to being worn down by entry hazards and Life Orb recoil, forcing it to use Recover more than it would like and limiting its effectiveness as a wallbreaker. Lastly, Starmie's vulnerable typing and frailty causes it to be easily revenge killed by common Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Zarude.
Starmie.comments:
Other Options

On the offensive set Thunderbolt can be used over Psyshock or Recover to break through Mantine, Celesteela, Pelipper, and Primarina more easily; however, with the exception of Mantine, the rest can easily be worn down by its other coverage options. Scald can be run to cripple physical attackers with a burn, but the power drop is noticeable.

Checks and Counters

Faster Threats and Priority: Choice Scarf users like Krookodile, Mienshao, and Zarude outspeed Starmie and KO it due to its frailty, and Noivern naturally outspeeds Starmie and heavily damages it with its Draco Meteor. Additionally, Starmie must watch out for Aegislash, which can severely dent it with Shadow Sneak. Other priority move users like Zygarde-10% and Lycanroc-D can also pick off a weakened Starmie.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Common specially defensive Pokemon like Chansey, Gastrodon, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can all take Starmie's attacks and limit it in their own ways. The former two can status it, hampering Starmie's longevity, while the latter can deal solid damage to Starmie with Giga Drain.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Hydro Pump deals devastating damage to common Pokemon like Jirachi, Rotom-H, and Nidoking. Alternatively, Surf can be used for increased accuracy but slightly less power. Ice Beam threatens Grass-types like Tangrowth and Zarude as well as Dragon-types like Salamence. Psyshock hits Pokemon like Chansey, Amoonguss, Keldeo, and Rotom-W harder. Recover is used to alleviate the Life Orb and heal off entry hazard damage, improving Starmie's longevity against foes like Keldeo. It can often use the move against common Pokemon it forces out such as Nidoking and Nihilego. Rapid Spin is an option to let Starmie clear entry hazards, but dropping Recover for Rapid Spin significantly diminishes Starmie's defensive capabilities as it struggles with longevity issues due to the lack of recovery. Life Orb combined with Analytic gives Starmie an incredible damage output, letting it 2HKO nearly the entire tier.

Starmie best fits on offensive teams due to its great Speed tier and solid wallbreaking power. Due to Starmie's frailty, it appreciates pivot support from Pokemon like Rotom-H and Mienshao to get in safely against Pokemon like Rhyperior and Salamence. Rotom-H in particular likes Starmie's ability to deal with Ground-types like Rhyperior so it can freely use Volt Switch, and it also helps threaten Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Defoggers like the previously mentioned Rotom-H as well as Salamence help Starmie from getting worn down by clearing entry hazards, and both appreciate Starmie's ability to dispatch threats to them like Nihilego and Lycanroc-D. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Krookodile and Roserade allows Starmie to break through opposing teams more easily, as it wears down Pokemon like Rotom-W and Chansey for it. Tangrowth and Amoonguss are notable partners for Starmie, as they are able to deal with faster threats like Choice Scarf Krookodile and Choice Scarf Zarude for it. Both appreciate Starmie pressuring troublesome Pokemon like Moltres and Salamence for them in return. Pokemon like Rhyperior and Nihilego can be paired with Starmie to help it answer threats like Salamence, as Starmie can get overwhelmed due to its proneness to being worn down and its lack of bulk.

sets.name: Bulky Spinner
sets.description:
Scald nails threats like Lycanroc-D, Rhyperior, and Nidoking super effectively. It also allows Starmie to threaten a burn on Aegislash, which would otherwise attempt to block Rapid Spin. Psyshock lets Starmie immediately threaten Pokemon like Keldeo, Roserade, and Nihilego while not being completely passive against Water-types like Primarina. Flip Turn can be run over Psyshock to make Starmie less passive while also letting it pivot, but this requires secondary answers for Keldeo, as it is let in freely without Psyshock, and makes Psyshock the preferred option. Recover allows Starmie to reliably switch into and check Celesteela and Keldeo throughout the game. Rapid Spin lets Starmie support its team by removing entry hazards thanks to its amazing matchup against common entry hazard setters like Rhyperior and Nihilego. 216 Speed EVs let Starmie outspeed Lycanroc-D, while the rest are put into HP and Defense to check threats like Keldeo and Zygarde-10% better.

Starmie best fits on bulky offense, balance, and semi-stall teams that appreciate its ability to absorb status with Natural Cure, support its team with Rapid Spin, and check Keldeo and Lycanroc-D. Fire-types like Moltres and Entei remove Pokemon like Tangrowth, Zarude, and Aegislash for Starmie, with the former also being able to lure in Stealth Rock setters like Rhyperior and Nihilego for it as well. Zarude can take out bulky Water-types like Rotom-W and Primarina for Starmie. Nihilego appreciates Starmie removing entry hazards for it and can threaten Pokemon that take advantage of Starmie's passivity like Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Galarian Moltres. It can also remove Aegislash's Leftovers with Knock Off, allowing Starmie to wear it down easier as it attempts to spinblock. Walls like Umbreon and Tangrowth handle setup sweepers like Necrozma and Gyarados, which force out Starmie. Physically defensive Tangrowth forms a great defensive core with Starmie, as Starmie checks Keldeo for it and lets it focus more on checking common threats on rain like Crawdaunt and Azumarill.

Gyarados.overview: Gyarados is one of the most dangerous setup sweepers in UU due to its fantastic coverage and combination of Dragon Dance and Moxie, which allow it to muscle through almost everything in the tier. Great coverage moves like Ice Fang help it break through bulky foes like Amoonguss and Salamence, and Power Whip allows it to hit Rotom-W, Swampert, and beat standard Unaware walls like Quagsire, unlike many other physical sweepers like Azumarill. It has good HP and respectable bulk, allowing it to withstand attacks from threats like Keldeo and certain Excadrill sets while setting up. Unfortunately, its only Flying-type STAB move is Bounce, which has low accuracy and is exploitable because it requires two turns to use without Power Herb. Meanwhile, Ice Fang's power can be underwhelming at times when facing bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Unboosted Gyarados is outsped by many common threats such as Thundurus-T and Nihilego. Even at +1 Speed, it will still get outsped by common Choice Scarf users like Zarude, Jirachi, and Mienshao. Gyarados struggles against defensive Pokemon like Umbreon, Mandibuzz, Skarmory, and Tangrowth due to their immense bulk and ability to hinder Gyarados from gaining too many boosts.
Gyarados.comments:
Other Options

Intimidate can be used on a more balance-oriented team to set up more freely against physical foes, but it notably lessens Gyarados's sweeping potential. A Substitute set with Waterfall, Bounce, and Leftovers as an item can help Gyarados break through defensive teams, as Substitute blocks status and Gyarados can easily boost multiple times against foes like Celesteela. However, the lack of coverage causes it to struggle with foes like Rotom-W and Quagsire.

Checks and Counters

Electric-types: Electric-types like Thundurus-T and Rotom-W reliably outspeed and KO Gyarados. While they can also withstand an unboosted hit, Rotom-W loses to boosted Power Whip and Thundurus-T can get KOed by Ice Fang.

Physical Walls: Many physical walls can be challenging for Gyarados, as it requires multiple boosts to KO them. Mandibuzz and Umbreon can take multiple boosted hits from Gyarados and OHKO it with Foul Play. Skarmory can simiarly take several hits and chip it down with Rocky Helmet while forcing it out with Whirlwind, but Life Orb Gyarados can break through Skarmory with a flinch. Rocky Helmet Tangrowth can give Gyarados problems if it does not have Bounce, as +1 Ice Fang does not 2HKO. Both Aegislash and Chansey can also withstand several boosted hits and cripple Gyarados with Toxic, with the former being able to lower Gyarados's attack with King's Shield.

Revenge Killers: Gyarados is slow, and many Choice Scarf users like Hydreigon, Mienshao, and Zarude will outspeed it at +1 and deal heavy damage with STAB or coverage moves, so Gyarados needs to boost to +2 Speed to overcome these threats. Lycanroc-D can revenge kill Gyarados with Accelrock, though Gyarados must be slightly chipped to guarantee the KO.

sets.name: Dragon Dance Sweeper
sets.description:
Ice Fang hits many threats like Salamence, Hydreigon, Mandibuzz, and Tapu Bulu. However, Gyarados requires multiple boosts to reliably KO bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss with it. Bounce can be used over Ice Fang, as it can more reliably KO a chipped Amoonguss with just one boost. However, Bounce requires a Power Herb as the item to limit its exploitability from Protect, Substitute, or switching. Even so, once the Power Herb is consumed Gyarados will still fall victim to these issues. Power Whip offers essential coverage against bulky Water-types like Quagsire, Slowking, and Rotom-W. Moxie is the preferred ability, as it enables Gyarados to snowball through a team after one or two boosts. Lum Berry allows Gyarados to freely setup twice against foes like Chansey and Toxic Excadril. Life Orb is an alternative option to let Gyarados break through Skarmory, Celesteela, and Mandibuzz much easier with Waterfall, though this lets Gyarados get worn down quickly. On more bulky offense teams, Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to prevent Stealth Rock damage, allowing Gyarados to switch in more frequently. An Adamant nature is preffered for extra wallbreaking power, as Gyarados doesn't outspeed anything notable with a Jolly nature and it guarantees an OHKO on Azumarill with unboosted Power Whip as well as Thundurus-T with +1 Ice Fang.

Gyarados is best used on hyper offense and bulky offense teams due to the offensive pressure it offers. Gyarados is primarily used as a late-game cleaner, but it struggles against defensive Pokemon like Chansey and Amoonguss. A teammate that offers entry hazard support like Krookodile and Excadrill helps wear these foes down enough for Gyarados to break through them. Both of these Pokemon can absorb Electric-type attacks and keep Stealth Rock off with Taunt or Rapid Spin, allowing Gyarados to use Lum Berry or Life Orb. Roserade can provide Spikes support to help wear down foes like Aegislash and Amoonguss. Early game wallbreakers like Aegislash, Diggersby, and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T can break through walls like Mandibuzz, Chansey, and Celesteela, allowing Gyarados to clean these typically bulky threats up more easily. Sticky Web setters like Ribombee can make up for Gyarados's mediocre Speed tier and prevent Choice Scarf users like Mienshao revenge killing it.

Ditto.overview: The combination of Imposter and Choice Scarf allows Ditto to outspeed the foe, making it a strong setup deterrent and one of the best revenge killers to sweepers like Thundurus-T, Salamence, and Kommo-o. Ditto also has utility against stall teams, as it cannot be easily PP stalled, especially if it is able to switch into Knock Off from defensive Tangrowth, and can take advantage of transforming into opposing clerics like Umbreon and Chansey. However, Ditto can be awkward to fit onto teams, as it often cannot switch into anything safely or provide any defensive utility outside of Regenerator. Imposter also fails against Substitute, which can be problematic against sweepers like Keldeo and Primarina. Ditto is also unable to effectively stop bulkier setup sweepers with recovery such as Galarian Slowbro due to being Choice-locked.
Ditto.comments:
Other Options

Ditto's value is rooted in its revenge killing capabilities, so it should never run anything besides Choice Scarf.

Checks and Counters

Substitute Users: Substitute users like Keldeo and Primarina can prevent Ditto from revenge killing them and proceed to wreak havoc.

Choice Scarf Users: Opposing Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Krookodile will always Speed tie with Ditto and cannot be reliably revenge killed.

Knock Off: Ditto relies on Choice Scarf to outspeed and properly check threats, so it should avoid taking a Knock Off except when it is copying Regenerator or facing a stall team.

sets.name: Imposter
sets.description:
Transform is the only move Ditto learns. The provided EVs allow Ditto to do more damage with Future Sight after transforming into a Pokemon like Reuniclus.

Ditto is able to function as a revenge killer on any archetype but is most often found on bulky balance or stall teams that are too passive to efficiently prevent Pokemon from setting up. Chansey is an excellent partner that can get Ditto in safely with Teleport to immediately pressure strong wallbreakers like Salamence and Lycanroc-D. Since Ditto is grounded before transforming, it is vulnerable to all entry hazards besides Sticky Web; entry hazard removal from Salamence and Rotom-H is valuable to keep Ditto healthy. Klefki and Roserade are able to provide Spikes to wear down the opposing team to better facilitate a countersweep from Ditto. Bulky pivots such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss appreciate Ditto's ability to countersweep, since Pokemon like Salamence often use them as setup fodder. In return, Tangrowth and Amoonguss can switch into opposing Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Zarude, which Speed tie with Ditto, and sponge Knock Off. Regenerator users such as the aforementioned Reuniclus, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth work well with Ditto, as they can PP stall defensive walls like Chansey together. On stall teams, Pokemon like Haze Quagsire and Spite Pyukumuku can beat Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro, which Ditto is unable to revenge kill.

Moltres.overview: Moltres's Fire typing threatens major defensive staples like Amoonguss and Aegislash, and its Flying typing lets it hit common Fire-type answers, such as Keldeo and Kommo-o, super effectively. Defensively, it's a reliable switch-in to Fighting- and Steel-types like Buzzwole and Aegislash, and its immunity to Ground lets it pivot into foes like Mamoswine. It can also punish physical attackers like Krookodile and U-turn users like Jirachi and Zarude due to Flame Body. Its option to run a more defensive Substitute + Toxic set gives it certain versatility too, dealing with conventional checks like Rhyperior, Rotom-W, and Rotom-H way better due to Toxic and PP stalling. However, Moltres's weakness to common offensive typings like Water and Electric hinders it defensively. Its crippling 4x weakness to Rock also leaves it extremely vulnerable to tier staples like Nihilego and Rhyperior, and foes like Krookodile and Zarude can circumvent their vulnerability to Moltres with Rock-type coverage. It also overly relies on its Heavy-Duty Boots and entry hazard removal to not be extremely crippled by Stealth Rock and Knock Off from foes like Mienshao and Krookodile, and its Speed tier, while good, falls short of others like Krookodile and Thundurus-T.
Moltres.comments:
Other Options

An Agility set with Flamethrower, Hurricane, and Roost can act as a late-game cleaner, but finding opportunities to set up Agility can be hard, and Moltres still can't touch Rock-types like Nihilego. Scorching Sands over U-turn or Defog lets offensive Moltres lure in Nihilego and 2HKO it as well as punish switch-ins like Rhyperior with a burn, but it is very niche compared to its alternatives.

Checks and Counters

Knock Off and Stealth Rock: Moltres's 4x weakness to Stealth Rock severely hampers its defensive utility, and losing its Heavy-Duty Boots compromises it for the rest of the game if its teammates can't keep Stealth Rock off of the field.

Rock-types: Nihilego and Rhyperior wall Moltres extremely well, threaten it back with their Rock-type STAB moves, and can punish Defog attempts by putting Stealth Rock back on the field. Nihilego also has the added benefit of walling the Substitute + Toxic set. Lycanroc-D destroys Moltres with its Rock-type STAB attacks but has to be wary of Flame Body if using Accelerock.

Water-types: Primarina and Keldeo can switch into Moltres's Fire-type attacks and threaten it with their Water-type moves, but Keldeo has to be wary of Hurricane, and both hate taking Toxic. RestTalk Primarina, however, has a better matchup against it. Rotom-W doesn't care about any of Moltres's moves other than Toxic and threatens it with Volt Switch and Hydro Pump. It needs to be careful with Hydro Pump's PP if facing the Pressure set, though. Other Water-types like Barraskewda and Starmie are faster than Moltres and can threaten it out of the field, while Milotic and Gastrodon can easily take hits from it, though the former can't switch into Hurricane and the latter two dislike Toxic.

Electric-types: Rotom-H and Rotom-W check the offensive set well, but they can't keep the defensive set at bay for very long, as they are forced to take a Toxic to break the Substitute with Volt Switch. Thundurus-T can KO Moltres with Thunderbolt.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Flamethrower targets Grass- and Steel-types like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, Aegislash, and Celesteela. Fire Blast can be used to hit neutral targets like Hatterene, as well as the aforementioned Grass-types, just as hard as Hurricane but with better accuracy. Hurricane hits Pokemon that resist Fire like Keldeo, Kommo-o, Salamence, and Primarina either super effectively or quite hard neutrally. U-turn lets Moltres keep momentum on Pokemon like Rotom-W and Rhyperior. Defog can be used if Moltres's team can't afford other forms of entry hazard removal. Roost gives Moltres longevity to keep threats like Jirachi and Zarude in check throughout the game, and it keeps Moltres healthy if its Heavy-Duty Boots is removed and Stealth Rock is up. Flame Body is chosen to scare away Pokemon such as Buzzwole, Jirachi, and Mienshao from using contact moves due to a potential burn. 88 HP EVs let Moltres avoid the 2HKO from Zarude's Darkest Lariat.

Bulky offense and balance teams appreciate Moltres pressuring Pokemon like Amoonguss, Kommo-o, and Buzzwole. Knock Off absorbers like Buzzwole and Amoonguss make excellent teammates. They're also secondary checks to Mienshao and Zarude so Moltres isn't overwhelmed by them and doesn't have to constantly risk taking the former's Knock Off. Moltres can remove Steel-types such as Aegislash and Cobalion for them in return. Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth check Electric- and Water-types like Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Primarina for Moltres. Jungle Healing Zarude also checks Raikou and Rotom-W, and Choice Scarf variants can revenge kill them and others like Keldeo. Water-types like Keldeo appreciate Moltres dealing with Grass-types like Amoonguss for them, and in return they can pressure Rock-types like Rhyperior for it. Pokemon such as Jirachi and Zarude can form a pivoting core with U-turn Moltres, bringing Moltres in against foes like Tangrowth. If Moltres foregoes Defog, entry hazard removers like Rotom-W and Starmie can help it by keeping Stealth Rock off of the field, and they like Moltres threatening Tangrowth for them. Frail wallbreakers such as Choice Specs Primarina and Thundurus-T like Moltres's U-turn bringing them in safely against foes like Rhyperior and Salamence.

sets.name: SubToxic
sets.description:
Mystical Fire hits Toxic-immune foes like Amoonguss and Steel-types like Jirachi and Aegislash, and it weakens special attacks from switch-ins such as Primarina and Nihilego, letting teammates like Tangrowth and Aegislash come into the field more safely. For example, after Stealth Rock, Assault Vest Tangrowth is no longer 2HKOed by Choice Specs Primarina's Moonblast at -1. Toxic is Moltres's main way of harming foes like Rotom-W, Salamence, and Kommo-o. Substitute gives Moltres a decoy against moves like Rotom-W's Hydro Pump and Rhyperior's Stone Edge and lets it PP stall them. It also eases prediction when foes switch out and blocks status from Pokemon like Amoonguss and Aegislash. Pressure lets Moltres stall moves with low PP like Primarina's Hydro Pump and Buzzwole's Stone Edge. The given EV spread minimizes the chance of the Rotom formes breaking Moltres's Substitute with Volt Switch after using Roost while still avoiding the 2HKO from Zarude's Darkest Lariat. 224 Speed EVs let Moltres outspeed the Rotom formes and Buzzwole.

This set fits on balance and stall teams, where Moltres can slowly wear down checks like Rotom-H and Rhyperior with Toxic and PP stall others like Rotom-W and Buzzwole. Zarude and Amoonguss can pressure RestTalk Primarina, which limits Moltres from making progress throughout the game. Moltres in return deals with Grass-types that bother Zarude, like Amoonguss. Jirachi, Aegislash, and Choice Scarf Krookodile check Nihilego, a major roadblock to this set, and deal with Lycanroc-D. The former can also bring Moltres safely against Steel-types like Aegislash. Entry hazard removers like Salamence and Starmie make for great partners. The former likes Moltres crippling Primarina and Rhyperior, while the latter appreciates Moltres threatening Tangrowth and crippling Milotic and Quagsire. Chansey takes care of the special attackers Moltres can't handle, like Nihilego and Thundurus-T. On stall teams, Umbreon provides cleric support with Heal Bell and Wish, and it also deals with Gyarados. Quagsire walls Electric- and Rock-types like Rotom-H and Lycanroc-D, and Amoonguss acts as a Knock Off absorber and secondary check to Keldeo and Primarina. They appreciate Moltres spreading Toxic and threatening Buzzwole and other physical attackers with Flame Body.

Moltres-Galar.overview: Galarian Moltres is one of the most dangerous sweepers in UU, defining hyper offense teams with its Double Dance set of Nasty Plot and Agility. Coupled with STAB attacks that provide near-perfect coverage, Galarian Moltres can be remarkably hard to stop after it sets up. This feat is not difficult thanks to Galarian Moltres's excellent bulk, allowing it to turn Pokemon like Hydreigon and Tapu Bulu into setup bait. Furthermore, Galarian Moltres can fill a defensive role by using a RestTalk set that is one of the few Pokemon capable of defeating all variations of Aegislash. These sets also can act as status absorbers to threats like Amoonguss and Chansey. However, having only base 100 Special Attack can prevent Galarian Moltres from breaking through specially bulky Pokemon such as Chansey and Nihilego, even when boosted. Galarian Moltres also requires two turns to set up if a Weakness Policy is not used or activated, which leaves it vulnerable to Taunt and status afflictions. Using RestTalk can make Galarian Moltres too passive when first entering a battle, so the set can be challenging to fit onto teams due to how often it invites wallbreakers such as Azumarill and Thundurus-T in. Lastly, despite an overall good defensive typing, Galarian Moltres is weak to common priority moves such as Lycanroc-D's Accelerock and Mamoswine's Ice Shard.
Moltres-Galar.comments:
Other Options

A set consisting of Rest + Chesto Berry alongside Nasty Plot, Agility, and Fiery Wrath is useable on hyper offense teams to provide the team with a win-condition that can break stall, but this set lets in plenty of threatening Pokemon like Mienshao, Primarina, and Azumarill for free. Forgoing a STAB or boosting move for Substitute is an option on the Double Dance set to give Galarian Moltres a better matchup against offensive teams, and it can even function decently alongside Salac Berry or Petaya Berry depending on which boosting move is being used, but overall is less reliable.

Checks and Counters

Rock-types: Rock-types such as Lycanroc-D and Rhyperior pose a huge threat to Galarian Moltres; Lycanroc-D can halt a sweep with priority Accelerock, and Rhyperior can tank a hit and KO Galarian Moltres with Stone Edge. Nihilego and Diancie also serve as great checks, as the former can take any boosted attack and retaliate with a Rock-type STAB attack, while the latter flat out counters Moltres.

Fairy-types: Azumarill and Primarina are capable of OHKOing either Galarian Moltres set. Bulkier variants of Primarina can take boosted Hurricane to boot. Diancie can hit Moltres hard with Diamond Storm and shrug off any attack Galarian Moltres tries to hit it with.

Revenge Killers: Faster threats like Thundurus-T and Life Orb Mienshao can heavily dent or KO Galarian Moltres, especially if it has taken Stealth Rock chip. Priority users like Lycanroc-D and Mamoswine are also helpful in halting a Galarian Moltres's sweep.

sets.name: Double Dance
sets.description:
After using both Nasty Plot and Agility, Galarian Moltres can OHKO most the metagame and outspeeds the entirety of it, even outspeeding weather abusers like Venusaur and Kingdra in their respective weathers. The only attacks needed here are STAB attacks Fiery Wrath and Hurricane, as the only UU-relevant Pokemon they miss out on is Diancie. Fiery Wrath's flinch chance also can give Galarian Moltres chances to break through bulkier Pokemon that can tank its attacks such as Chansey and Celesteela. Air Slash is an option over Hurricane if accuracy concerns arise. Weakness Policy is the optimal item for this set, as the most effective way to take down Galarian Moltres is a super effective attack, meaning it activates a decent amount of the time and gives Galarian Moltres exceptional power when coupled with Nasty Plot. Using Weakness Policy can also create opportunities for Galarian Moltres to set up in one turn by using Agility as a super effective attack hits it. Sitrus Berry can allow Galarian Moltres to regain its health and activate Berserk for a second time. Heavy-Duty Boots is also a viable item choice, as preventing Stealth Rock damage can make it much more challenging for an opponent to take down Galarian Moltres.

Double Dance Galarian Moltres fits primarily on hyper offense teams, though it also works on some balance teams as a late-game win condition. Stealth Rock setters like Excadrill can help rack up chip damage on Pokemon that check Galarian Moltres such as Diancie. It also provides an Electric-type immunity and Rapid Spin, keeping Galarian Moltres from getting chipped by Stealth Rock. Physical sweepers like Gyarados, Belly Drum Azumarill, and Swords Dance Aegislash fit well on hyper offense teams and can break through or soften up specially bulky Pokemon able to halt a Galarian Moltres sweep such as Chansey and Nihilego. Galarian Moltres can beat Grass-types like Amoonguss and Zarude that trouble these Pokemon in return. Grimmsnarl can provide dual screens support to give Galarian Moltres an easier time setting up as it becomes exceptionally difficult to take down behind screens. Pivots like Mienshao can bring Galarian Moltres in to safely set up against physical walls like Tangrowth and Skarmory. It can also beat Chansey for it.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description:
RestTalk Galarian Moltres can provide a lot of utility to a team by checking and breaking through foes like Aegislash, Slowking, and Galarian Slowbro. Fiery Wrath is the main attack on this set, as it has acceptable coverage and is reliable. Hurricane is preferable on Galarian Moltres, as it prevents it giving free switches to a range of potent offensive threats such as Keldeo, Primarina, and Conkeldurr. Nasty Plot is an option over Hurricane, as it provides the necessary power to overwhelm Pokemon like Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro. Rest and Sleep Talk allow Galarian Moltres to effectively check foes like Aegislash, absorb status, and lets it accumulate Berserk boosts. The Speed EVs let Galarian Moltres outspeed Aegislash, while the rest of the EVs with a Calm nature go towards special bulk to help Galarian Moltres against special attackers such as Aegislash and special Salamence. Heavy-Duty Boots prevents Galarian Moltres from taking Stealth Rock damage, easing the need for it to use Rest often.

This set can be challenging to fit onto teams because it has a very unique role and is vulnerable to powerful wallbreakers such as Primarina and Azumarill. It fares best on bulky offense and balance builds, however. Azumarill is a helpful partner to this set, as it is able to break through just about any special wall that can threaten Galarian Moltres, particularly Rhyperior and Diancie. Galarian Moltres can help Azumarill by providing an ideal matchup against Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Assault Vest Tangrowth can help check Electric-types like Thundurus-T that can take advantage of Galarian Moltres, especially after using Rest. Skarmory is a great partner that can help check foes like Lycanroc-D and Conkeldurr as well as act as a better Knock Off absorber against the likes of Krookodile. In return, Galarian Moltres can check Pokemon like Amoonguss and Aegislash that limit Skarmory. Diancie can provide Heal Bell support to wake Galarian Moltres up after it has used Rest. Steel-types like Jirachi and Aegislash are extremely important partners, checking one of Galarian Moltres's biggest checks in Nihilego. Jirachi can also provide Wish support so that Galarian Moltres doesn't have to use Rest as often, while Aegislash can threaten Chansey.

Azumarill.overview: Azumarill is an offensive powerhouse and effective wallbreaker when equipped with a Choice Band due to Huge Power, being able to nearly 2HKO the entire tier with the right move. It can also utilize a Belly Drum set to be a scary late-game cleaner. Water / Fairy is a great offensive typing, allowing Azumarill to beat key threats like Excadrill and Hydreigon. Access to great coverage moves such as Knock Off and Ice Punch lets Azumarill break past Pokemon like Volcanion and Amoonguss that would otherwise check it by resisting its STAB combination, while access to Aqua Jet allows it to also be a great revenge killer, especially against top threats like Lycanroc-D and Azelf that have taken chip damage. Azumarill also has decent natural bulk and a great defensive typing, which allows it to blanket check some of the more dangerous threats in the metagame such as Kommo-o and Salamence. Unfortunately, Azumarill is quite slow, so it is easily forced out by faster Pokemon such as Jirachi and Thundurus-T when it is not boosted with Belly Drum. Additionally, Rotom-W and faster Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Zarude can revenge kill Belly Drum Azumarill, as they can stomach a +6 Aqua Jet. Belly Drum Azumarill is restricted to only getting one setup opportunity, which usually forces it to be preserved until late-game. Azumarill faces competition from Primarina as it offers more defensive utility with its bulk.
Azumarill.comments:
Other Options

An Assault Vest set can help Azumarill more comfortably switch into Keldeo, Salamence, and Galarian Moltres and KO them back and also come in and pressure neutral special attackers like Primarina. Azumarill can run a trapping set with Sap Sipper and Whirlpool, Perish Song, and Protect. This can trap passive foes like Celesteela as well as Grass-types like Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth, but the effectiveness of this set is purely restricted to punishing walls and is deadweight against a majority of the offensive threats in UU.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Faster Grass-types like Zarude and Venusaur are the biggest threats to Azumarill because even a Belly Drum Azumarill cannot OHKO them with Aqua Jet and they OHKO back. Defensive Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth can usually switch into Choice Band Azumarill and threaten it with their own STAB moves as well as scout and switch out with Regenerator.

Electric-types: An unboosted Azumarill is easy prey for Thundurus-T and Toxtricity. Without being at +6, Azumarill cannot come close to KOing them with Aqua Jet, and both will in turn OHKO Azumarill. Rotom-W resists Aqua Jet and can also outspeed and cripple Azumarill with Will-O-Wisp or pressure it with an Electric-type attack.

Faster Water-resistant Pokemon: Anything faster that resists Aqua Jet is bound to pressure Azumarill. These Pokemon include Gyarados, Tentacruel, and Rotom-W. Salamence can also pressure Azumarill, but it is also pressured by Azumarill with Play Rough, so Azumarill would have to be significantly chipped for Salamence to KO it. Volcanion is immune to Aqua Jet and can threaten Azumarill with Sludge Wave.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Play Rough is Azumarill's main attack to remove foes like Zarude and Tangrowth. Aqua Jet becomes a very powerful STAB priority move when bolstered by Huge Power and a Choice Band, allowing it to OHKO Nihilego and revenge kill Thundurus-T and Rotom-H after they have taken sufficient chip damage. Ice Punch allows Azumarill to break through Amoonguss by hitting it hard enough to 2HKO on the switch. Knock Off can be used to burden anything that switches in, such as Tangrowth and Tentacruel, by removing their item. A Choice Band allows Azumarill to maximize the wallbreaking potential its STAB attacks have to offer. Adamant is the preferred nature to make it as strong as possible, notably 2HKOing Skarmory with Liquidation after Stealth Rock.

Choice Band Azumarill fits best on bulky offense teams. It wants to be brought in as often as possible early-game to wallbreak, so having good pivots such as Mienshao and Jirachi is extremely useful. Azumarill wants to fire off its STAB moves frequently, but it struggles to do so against bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss. Nidoking, Moltres, and Salamence can remove these Pokemon and make Azumarill's job easier. Hydreigon can offensively pressure Grass-types and can also check Volcanion. Keeping entry hazards up is important to ease Azumarill's ability to break through Tangrowth and Skarmory, so partners such as Excadrill and Nihilego are essential. Tapu Bulu and Zarude threaten to revenge kill Azumarill, as they are faster and resist Aqua Jet, so partners like Salamence and Amoonguss that can comfortably switch into them are ideal. Having a good Electric-immune teammate, such as Swampert or Thundurus-T, helps to deal with Electric-types like Rotom-W and Thundurus-T.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
A +6 Aqua Jet will KO almost anything that doesn't resist it, so it is very hard for anything to revenge kill Azumarill. Play Rough is used to pressure slower threats after a boost, as it can OHKO anything that does not resist it, including a fully defensive Tangrowth. A boosted Knock Off will OHKO Amoonguss and defensive Celesteela. Sitrus Berry allows Azumarill to set up more reliably and puts it at a comfortable amount of HP after a Belly Drum. Adamant is the preferred nature to guarantee an OHKO on Amoonguss with Knock Off.

Belly Drum Azumarill fits best on hyper offense teams due to its nature as a late-game cleaner and need for dedicated support. Boosted Aqua Jet can still KO Water-resistant foes like Tentacruel after substantial chip damage, so a hazard setter can help chip these Pokemon to allow Azumarill to KO them later on. Krookodile and Excadrill are good options for this, and they also provide an Electric immunity. A teammate that can pivot, such as Cobalion or Mienshao, can help Azumarill come in safely to set up a Belly Drum and also chip foes while doing so. Once Azumarill is boosted with Belly Drum, it typically will not get another chance to do so. As such, before it can come in and sweep, it needs teammates to help eliminate its main threats, which are mostly Pokemon that resist Water, are faster, and can KO it. Good offensive teammates include Salamence and Aegislash to help take out foes like Zarude and Keldeo. Thundurus-T can also hit most of Azumarill's checks with its coverage options, and it also provides a valuable Electric immunity.

Quagsire.overview: Quagsire possesses a unique niche in the UU metagame with its ability in Unaware, which lets it stop setup sweepers such as Kommo-o and Dragon Dance Salamence in their tracks. A Water / Ground typing allows Quagsire to act as a Volt Switch absorber while also checking Pokemon such as Rotom-H and Lycanroc-D. As such, these attributes make Quagsire a staple on stall teams. However, Quagsire's 4x weakness to Grass makes it unable to check Pokemon such as Nihilego and Gyarados, as they commonly carry Grass-type coverage. Quagsire's bulk only goes so far, as very strong wallbreakers such as Crawdaunt and Azumarill can break through it with minimal effort. Finally, Quagsire's poor special bulk leaves it unable to take on special attackers well, leaving it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Thundurus-T and Keldeo.
Quagsire.comments:
Other Options

A Curse set turns Quagsire into a bulky sweeper, but it will need many boosts before it can cause serious damage and is even more vulnerable to Grass-types. Additionally, it must drop Scald from its moveset, making Quagsire much more passive.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Moves: Grass-types like Zarude, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth resist any attack Quagsire throws at them and proceed to force it out, with the former two being able to bypass Toxic through Jungle Healing or its typing. Pokemon that can lure in Quagsire and KO it with a coverage move, such as Gyarados, Azelf, and Nihilego, are also threats to Quagsire.

Strong Wallbreakers: Quagsire's bulk is only decent; extremely strong attacks coming from the likes of Buzzwole, Keldeo, Diggersby, and Necrozma will easily overwhelm it.

Residual Damage: Status such as Toxic and burn hinder Quagsire, as it has to use Recover more often. Chip damage from Spikes can also wear down Quagsire for sweepers like Kommo-o to KO it more easily.

sets.name: Unaware Wall
sets.description:
Scald has a good chance to burn threats such as Aegislash and Tapu Bulu. Earthquake hits Pokemon such as Raikou, Jirachi, and Nihilego. Haze stops setup sweepers such as Galarian Slowbro and Kommo-o in their tracks. Toxic is an option that cripples switch-ins such as Tangrowth and Kommo-o, but it has to give up Scald or the utility of Haze to do so. Heavy-Duty Boots is an option to avoid damage from Spikes and Toxic Spikes; however, Quagsire is already resistant to Stealth Rock, and the passive recovery brought by Leftovers is generally much more appreciated. The given EV spread allows Quagsire to take on special attackers such as Rotom-W more comfortably while maximizing its physical bulk.

Quagsire fits best on stall teams, stopping setup sweepers with Unaware. Amoonguss and Tangrowth are excellent partners for Quagsire, as they check Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude. Additionally, these Pokemon are able to check wallbreakers that Quagsire struggles with, such as Conkeldurr and Keldeo. Chansey forms a solid defensive core with Quagsire, being able to check special attackers such as Nihilego and Thundurus-T, while Quagsire checks physical threats for it in return. Chansey's Heal Bell also allows it to cure status that easily wear down Quagsire. Other clerics such as Umbreon and Mew are also good options to pair with Quagsire. Salamence can help provide Defog support to remove Spikes for Quagsire. Ditto can provide offensive support and deter setup sweepers like Diggersby and Crawdaunt that Quagsire can't deal with properly.

Kingdra.overview: Kingdra is a threatening sweeper on rain teams thanks to its decent Speed and ability Swift Swim, which allow it to outrun the entire unboosted metagame in rain. This can help it against opposing rain teams, outrunning archetype staples like Keldeo and Salamence. In addition to a powerful rain-boosted Hydro Pump, Kingdra has Draco Meteor, allowing it to heavily damage Water-resistant Pokemon like Salamence and Rotom-W. It can additionally threaten Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth, which some Pokemon on rain builds struggle with, thanks to Hurricane. Kingdra's damage output can be rather middling at times, however, due to its merely decent Special Attack. Alongside its slightly lacking coverage, this can prevent it from reliably beating popular Pokemon like Chansey and Primarina. It faces intense competition from Barraskewda, another Pokemon with Swift Swim but better immediate power, higher Speed, and easier pivoting capabilities for generating momentum against checks. Kingdra additionally faces competition as a Water-type special attacker on rain teams, with Keldeo offering more immediate power and a way to beat special walls with Secret Sword, and as a Dragon-type, with Salamence also offering Hydro Pump and Hurricane but with far better defensive utility and longevity. Lastly, Kingdra's Speed and damage output can be rather middling outside of rain, causing it to be overreliant on Pelipper's Drizzle.
Kingdra.comments:
Other Options

Choice Specs further amplifies Kingdra's damage output. However, it can be taken advantage of quite easily if locked into one of its attacks. Flip Turn allows Kingdra to pivot away from switch-ins it can't reliably damage, like Chansey and bulky Primarina. However, Kingdra doesn't enjoy taking Life Orb damage from pivoting and often makes better use of Surf, a highly spammable move. Dragon Pulse hits foes like Salamence without decreasing Kingdra's Special Attack, preventing it from becoming setup bait, although the move's low power against Pokemon like Rotom-W rarely makes it a worthy option.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey's amazing special bulk and reliable recovery allow it to consistently switch into Kingdra. It can wear Kingdra down with either Seismic Toss or Toxic, take advantage of it to pivot with Teleport, or restore its health with Soft-Boiled.

Bulky Water-types: Kingdra struggles to power through many bulky Water-types due to its lack of a move that can KO them. Mantine's superb special bulk allows it to stomach Draco Meteor, while its Water-type immunity and Roost let it switch in on Kingdra. Jellicent and Gastrodon both take a fair amount of damage from Draco Meteor, but they can heal the damage with Recover and are also immune to Kingdra's Water-type moves. Bulky Primarina sets can utilize their resistance and immunity to Kingdra's STAB combination to switch in and threaten it with STAB Moonblast.

Various Revenge Killers: Timid Trace Gardevoir and Barraskewda can outspeed Kingdra in rain and threaten it. If Kingdra runs out of rain turns, it is also vulnerable to faster Pokemon that can smack it with powerful STAB moves, including Keldeo, Lycanroc-D, and Salamence.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Hydro Pump is a very powerful STAB move under rain, threatening to 2HKO Water-resistant Pokemon like Rotom-W and offensive Primarina after minimal chip damage. Draco Meteor hits various Water-resistant Pokemon quite hard, including Salamence, Kommo-o, Tentacruel, and Starmie. Hurricane has perfect accuracy in rain and can nab 2HKOs on Grass-types like Zarude, Amoonguss, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Surf is a perfectly accurate Water-type move that Kingdra can use against foes that it does not require the power of Hydro Pump to reliably power through, such as Moltres, Krookodile, and Rotom-H.
