While Rotom-W does have some useful resistances, it needs to be healthy or used with prediction to pivot against foes that can potentially dent it greatly, such as Ground-types that have a strong secondary STAB move like Nidoking and Diggersby.
Rotom-Wash.comments:
Other Options

Rocky Helmet has the benefit of punishing the likes of Jirachi for spamming U-turn or contact moves, though losing the passive recovery from Leftovers is not ideal. Maximum Defense investment with a Bold nature makes Rotom-W a more effective pivot against Keldeo and Mamoswine, but the loss in Speed hampers it against foes like Nidoking and Chandelure. Nasty Plot + Pain Split turns Rotom-W into a wallbreaker, but it still has immense problems with Grass-types. This set also sacrifices Volt Switch in favor of Thunderbolt or Discharge, which makes the matchup against Grass-types even worse. Rindo Berry can be used if the team is too weak to Dragon Dance Gyarados, as it can prevent an OHKO from +2 Adamant Power Whip and provide a safety net against Tapu Bulu if Will-O-Wisp misses.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types and Grass-type Coverage: Rotom-W cannot deal any significant damage to the likes of Tangrowth and Amoonguss aside from burning them. Though Tapu Bulu dislikes Will-O-Wisp, it can still threaten Rotom-W with Horn Leech to restore health. Zarude can use Jungle Healing to disregard status completely. However, all of them lose momentum to Volt Switch as they switch in. Rotom-W also must watch out for Grass-type coverage on Pokemon like Gyarados and Azelf.

Dragon-types: Kommo-o only dislikes status from Rotom-W and is able to freely set up with Clangorous Soul. Zygarde-10%'s Thousand Arrows ignores Levitate, meaning it heavily punishes teams that solely rely on Rotom-W to deal with Ground-types. Salamence outspeed and nails Rotom-W with a powerful Draco Meteor.

Seismitoad and Gastrodon: Seismitoad and Gastrodon shut down Rotom-W nearly completely if it is not carrying Toxic. Seismitoad can cripple Rotom-W with Toxic and is the only Stealth Rock setter that is immune to both Hydro Pump and Volt Switch, and Gastrodon does not care much about Will-O-Wisp.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
Volt Switch is required so Rotom-W can gain momentum against Grass- and Dragon-types such as Tangrowth and Kommo-o while bringing in teammates like Chandelure and Primarina to threaten them. Hydro Pump destroys common entry hazard setters such as Rhyperior and Krookodile. Pain Split is Rotom-W's only recovery move and gives Rotom-W more utility against bulkier teams, though it can be easy to play around. Will-O-Wisp cripples Amoonguss, Dragon Dance Salamence, and Tangrowth. Other status moves can be used over Will-O-Wisp; Toxic limits Seismitoad and Gastrodon's longevity better, whereas Thunder Wave cripples Noivern and Kommo-o. Defog is an alternative option because Rotom-W has several opportunities to remove hazards, such as when facing Celesteela and Jirachi, while having a good matchup against many of the entry hazard setters. Leftovers is Rotom-W's primary way of standing up to repeated U-turn and Stealth Rock damage. Maximum Speed EVs allow Rotom-W to outspeed and OHKO Nidoking as well as potentially cripple offensive Kommo-o with Will-O-Wisp.

Rotom-W fits on bulky offense and balance teams, which appreciate its ability to check Mamoswine and Moltres. U-turn users such as Zarude and Moltres form VoltTurn cores with Rotom-W that can be difficult to stop, as Rotom-W threatens their checks such as Rotom-H and Rhyperior. Rotom-W appreciates Moltres's ability to pressure Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Wallbreakers such as Buzzwole, Entei, and Nidoking appreciate Rotom-W's Volt Switch allowing them to pressure defensive cores relying on Pokemon such as Chansey and Tangrowth. Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Zarude can help remove Seismitoad and Gastrodon and patch any weaknesses against Zygarde-10%. Zarude also forms a VoltTurn core with Rotom-W and appreciates Rotom-W sponging Krookodile's Knock Off if its item is still required, this being particularly important for Choice Scarf variants.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Rotom is effective at revenge killing targets like Krookodile, Entei, and Lycanroc-D with Hydro Pump. Volt Switch helps Rotom-W offensively threaten foes such as +1 Gyarados, Keldeo, and Starmie. Thunderbolt can be used over Volt Switch to apply more reliable pressure against foes like Mantine and Galarian Moltres, although Volt Switch is more consistent. Defog allows Rotom-W to remove entry hazards before being KOed or as it forces out Pokemon like Mantine and Moltres. Pain Split over Defog gives Rotom-W more longevity. However, finding other options for entry hazard removal can be challenging and create more strain on teambuilding. Trick is vital because it cripples defensive pivots such as Chansey, Amoonguss, and Tangrowth. However, Rotom-W should only use Trick after the additional Speed is no longer necessary, as it will no longer be able to outspeed threats such as Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10%. Choice Scarf allows Rotom-W to revenge kill threats such as Lycanroc-D and Krookodile as well as maintain momentum against other Pokemon that would otherwise outspeed and deal massive damage such as Salamence. The additional speed also helps Rotom-W scout and maintain momentum against unfavorable matchups such as Zarude and Roserade more reliably.

Choice Scarf Rotom-W fits best on offense, balance, and bulky offense teams that appreciate its role compression as a Ground-immune offensive pivot and revenge killer that provides momentum and emergency entry hazard removal. Other pivots such as Mienshao form a potent VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, as they overwhelm each other's checks; Mienshao deals with Chansey and Zarude, while Rotom-W deals with Moltres and Nihilego. Entry hazard setters such as Jirachi, Nihilego, and Krookodile wear down targets for Rotom-W. The former is able to form a VoltTurn core with Rotom-W, while the latter two can cripple Pokemon such as Aegislash and Salamence with Knock Off. Wallbreakers such as Entei, Nidoking, and Mamoswine are fantastic partner that break through Pokemon Rotom-W grants them safe entry on, such as Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Galarian Slowbro. Hatterene deals with Pokemon that would otherwise take advantage of Rotom-W like Seismitoad and Kommo-o. Hatterene's Magic Bounce also assists Rotom-W in its role as entry hazard control and makes Rotom-W more comfortable with running Pain Split. Rotom-W's role compression means it can struggle against Entei and Jirachi in the long-term, so teammates such as RestTalk Primarina, Aegislash, and Moltres help relieve pressure.

Azelf.overview: Azelf is a versatile Pokemon that can take advantage of its incredibly high Speed tier and wide movepool to provide a powerful offensive presence and fast support. Nasty Plot and a variety of coverage moves such as Fire Blast, Energy Ball, and Dazzling Gleam allow Azelf to hit nearly the entire tier for super effective damage, OHKOing most of it at +2. Access to Knock Off and U-turn also makes it a great offensive pivot that can threaten tier staples like Aegislash and Tangrowth. Despite Azelf's elite Speed, common Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Zarude easily revenge kill it. Azelf does not have much bulk and lacks recovery, leaving it worn down quickly and making it difficult to set up with Nasty Plot. It also needs pivot support to get in safely, as it typically cannot directly switch into any attack. Azelf struggles to fit all the moves it needs on its Nasty Plot set, as without Energy Ball Azelf struggles to break Slowking and Swampert, whereas without Dazzling Gleam it is completely walled by Hydreigon and Mandibuzz. Thundurus-T gives Azelf large competition as a special wallbreaker and pivot, having more power, a better typing, and no 4MSS. However, Azelf's high Speed allows it to better threaten Pokemon like Keldeo and Nihilego.
Azelf.comments:
Other Options

Azelf can be used as a suicide lead due to its great Speed tier and access to Stealth Rock and Taunt. While this allows Azelf to always get Stealth Rock up with a Focus Sash, Pokemon like Excadrill and Krookodile, which possess better defensive utility and Rapid Spin or a stronger Knock Off respectively, can typically do this job better. Azelf can also be a Choice Band user with its great Speed tier and wide physical movepool, boasting options like Knock Off, U-turn, Zen Headbutt, Ice Punch, Explosion, and Trick. However, it is usually unable to OHKO its foes and outclassed by Pokemon like Azumarill, which provides priority and is much stronger. Azelf can run a Choice Scarf to be the fastest unboosted Pokemon in the tier, taking Choice Scarf users like Mienshao by surprise and hindering switch-ins like Hatterene with Trick.

Checks and Counters

Choice Scarf Users: Common Choice Scarf users like Krookodile, Zarude, Jirachi, and Mienshao outspeed and threaten Azelf with super effective STAB or coverage moves.

Priority Attackers: Azelf does not have great defenses and will be 2HKOed by most priority attacks, including Accelerock from Lycanroc-D and Aqua Jet from Azumarill. Additionally, more powerful priority attacks like a boosted Quick Attack from Diggersby will KO Azelf after minimal chip damage.

Dark-types: Galarian Moltres and Mandibuzz can OHKO Azelf, and Azelf cannot do much back it unless it is running Dazzling Gleam. Umbreon walls Azelf almost completely without Dazzling Gleam. Choice Scarf Hydreigon can easily revenge kill Azelf, though other sets must watch out for Dazzling Gleam.

sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
After a Nasty Plot, very few Pokemon other than Chansey and Umbreon can withstand a hit from Azelf. Psyshock is the preferred STAB option to OHKO Nihilego and Tentacruel without a boost, and it also hits Chansey considerably harder than Psychic. Fire Blast OHKOes defensive Celesteela and Assault Vest Tangrowth at +2. It also covers many key threats such as Jirachi, Skarmory, and Excadrill. The last move is dependent on Azelf's team; Energy Ball is able to nail Slowking, Swampert, Azumarill, and Rhyperior for super effective damage. Meanwhile, Dazzling Gleam is an option to OHKO Hydreigon, 2HKO Salamence, and hit Galarian Moltres and Mandibuzz super effectively while also maintaining coverage for Krookodile. It also prevents Umbreon from completely walling Azelf. Since Azelf will typically be hitting its foes for super effective damage, Expert Belt is enough to OHKO nearly everything. Life Orb can be used to increase Azelf's damage output more consistently on targets that it cannot hit super effectively, like Hatterene and Moltres, but the chip damage adds up quickly and leaves Azelf more vulnerable to revenge killers with priority like Lycanroc-D.

Nasty Plot Azelf is best used on hyper offense builds that can offer it support, although it can also fit on certain balance teams as a late-game wincon. An entry hazard setter like Nihilego, Excadrill, or Krookodile helps weaken foes like Chansey and Primarina into KO range of +2 Azelf. Ribombee can provide Sticky Web support to boost Azelf's ability to clean through teams, as Sticky Web invalidates common Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Zarude as revenge killers. It also ensures Azelf does not lose any Speed ties with Zygarde-10%. A pivot like Zarude can get Azelf in safely against Pokemon like Amoonguss. A wallbreaker like Azumarill or Mamoswine can help punch holes in the enemy team, significantly weakening them for Azelf to sweep later. Other sweepers like Gyarados and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T can be used on hyper offense teams to cover a wider range of threats, including Swampert, Slowking, and Galarian Moltres, which Azelf cannot easily beat.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
U-turn lets Azelf to pivot away from switch-ins and escape counters like Umbreon and Galarian Moltres. Knock Off offers important utility to cripple defensive switch-ins like Chansey, Mandibuzz, and Hatterene. Psychic is the preferred STAB option for its greater power, threatening Thundurus-T more while OHKOing Conkeldurr and Life Orb Mienshao. Psyshock is an option over Psychic to guarantee the OHKO on Nihilego and deal additional damage to specially defensive foes like Chansey and Primarina. Flamethrower allows Azelf to threaten Jirachi, Excadrill, and Aegislash. Energy Ball is an option over U-turn on Expert Belt sets to offer greater coverage and threaten Swampert and Azumarill. While Timid is the preferred nature, a Naive nature can be used to deal more chip damage with U-turn and Knock Off at the expense of some survivability.

Offensive pivot Azelf best fits on balance and offense teams that appreciate a fast pivot and revenge killer. Strong wallbreakers like Azumarill and Mamoswine appreciate Azelf's pivoting and deal with Umbreon. An entry hazard setter like Excadrill, Skarmory, or Roserade syncs well with the switches that Azelf's momentum forces, providing additional damage for it and its teammates to break through defensive cores like Tangrowth + Chansey. Offensive pivots like Zarude and Thundurus-T form a strong pivoting cores with Azelf. Zarude can bring Azelf in on Amoonguss and Tangrowth, while it can bring Zarude in on foes like Swampert and Krookodile. Thundurus-T can threaten Primarina and Mandibuzz for Azelf, while Azelf can wear down threats like Aegislash for Thundurus-T. Strong Fighting-types like Mienshao and Conkeldurr can remove Dark-types like Umbreon and Zarude. Primarina is a great partner for Azelf, as it threatens Pokemon like Krookodile and Galarian Moltres. In return, Azelf helps remove their common Grass-type checks like Amoonguss and Tangrowth after they are sufficiently chipped. Many Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Zarude can outspeed and threaten Azelf, so a defensive teammate like Amoonguss or Tangrowth can be used to take hits from these foes.

Conkeldurr.overview: Guts Conkeldurr is one of UU's most devastating wallbreakers. Once burned by Flame Orb, it can evade status from defensive staples like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Knock Off and Facade offer virtually perfect coverage alongside its powerful Drain Punch or Close Combat, allowing it to dismantle defensive cores like Chansey and Quagsire. STAB Mach Punch is also a great tool, functioning as a strong priority attack that can threaten faster Pokemon like Mienshao, Mamoswine and Hydreigon. Conkeldurr is a bit weighed down by its proneness to being worn down from Flame Orb, however. This is made a larger problem by its poor Speed, which allows the tier's many faster threats like Keldeo and Salamence to overwhelm it, as well as its iffy defensive typing, which doesn't give it many notable resistances and leaves it open to Pokemon like Moltres, Primarina, and Salamence. Conkeldurr also faces competition from Fighting-types like Mienshao, who offers comparable power in addition to a higher speed tier and Regenerator for longevity.
Conkeldurr.comments:
Other Options

A Bulk Up set with investment in Special Defense can function as a solid bulky sweeper, though it can struggle to make consistent progress with the tier's many strong Fairy- and Psychic-types. Conkeldurr could hold Assault Vest to more easily switch into Scald from Pokemon like Tentacruel and Quagsire while also checking special attackers such as Nihilego. However, this often prevents it from being able to maximize its offensive potential, and it is still quite prone to being worn down. Poison Jab is a coverage option that hits Fairy-types super effectively, but Conkeldurr can usually muscle through them with Facade.

Checks and Counters

Faster Pokemon: Conkeldurr's low Speed and Flame Orb use leave it quite vulnerable to being overwhelmed by faster Pokemon like Tapu Bulu, Nidoking, and Thundurus-T.

Psychic-types: Reuniclus and Galarian Slowbro can take Knock Off from full HP while severely damaging Conkeldurr with STAB Psychic-type attacks. Necrozma and Azelf outspeed and pressure Conkeldurr with their powerful attacks.

Fairy-types: Miscellaneous defensive Fairy-types can tank a hit and smack Conkeldurr with super effective STAB moves. Although it takes hefty damage from Facade, bulky Primarina can restore its health as it dents Conkeldurr with Draining Kiss, while its Choice Specs sets can outrun and OHKO it outright. Azumarill outspeeds Conkeldurr, resists Mach Punch, and can KO it with Play Rough.

Flying-types: Flying-types can often take Mach Punch fairly well and pressure Conkeldurr with super effective STAB attacks. Defensive Salamence is a particularly good check for its ability to always take a hit from full HP thanks to Intimidate, allowing it to switch into Conkeldurr and threaten it with Dual Wingbeat. Skarmory's massive physical bulk lets it switch into a weaker attack from Conkeldurr and nail it with Brave Bird. Togekiss can also be a solid check, 4x resisting Conkeldurr's STAB moves and revenge killing it with Air Slash. Moltres resists Mach Punch and can power through Conkeldurr with Hurricane. Galarian Moltres and Celesteela don't resist Mach Punch but can still tank it to revenge kill Conkeldurr.

sets.name: Guts Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Drain Punch can be used as Conkeldurr's primary STAB move, giving it more longevity and a safe attacking option. However, Close Combat is also an option for its massive damage output, crushing defensive staples like Celesteela and Skarmory. Facade heavily damages various Pokemon that resist its STAB attacks, including Nidoking, Amoonguss, and Primarina. Knock Off hits foes such as Galarian Slowbro, Chandelure, and Aegislash. Mach Punch is a strong priority move that can pressure faster foes like Hydreigon, Excadrill, and Zarude while picking off weakened threats in general. An Adamant nature is preferred in order to maximize Conkeldurr's wallbreaking potential.

Conkeldurr generally fits well on more offensively oriented builds. Some balance teams appreciate the offensive pressure it offers, too. Due to Conkeldurr's tendency to wearing itself down, it appreciates Grassy Terrain support from Tapu Bulu for passive recovery. Tapu Bulu also checks faster threats to Conkeldurr like Primarina and Azumarill. Wish from Jirachi or Sylveon can also support it well. Conkeldurr struggles to break through physical walls like Galarian Weezing and Tangrowth in the short term, so teammates who can threaten these like Moltres and Aegislash are appreciated. Entry hazard setters like Diancie and Krookodile can wear down checks like Skarmory with Stealth Rock for Conkeldurr to muscle through easier. Diancie can also check many revenge killers to Conkeldurr like Togekiss, Salamence, and Galarian Moltres. Slow pivots like Chansey, Slowking, and Mandibuzz can help bring Conkeldurr into play against threats like Excadrill, Zarude, and Lycanroc-D. Slowking can also provide Future Sight support to further amplify Conkeldurr's wallbreaking power. Late-game cleaners like Thundurus-T are able to clean up after Conkeldurr softens up the opposing team. In return, they can pressure Flying-types like Togekiss and Salamence.

Seismitoad.overview: Seismitoad separates itself from other Ground-type Stealth Rock setters thanks to its additional Water typing and access to Water Absorb, which allows it to easily pivot into Pokemon such as Rotom-H, Rotom-W, and Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro. These qualities also let Seismitoad threaten other entry hazard setters such as Krookodile, Rhyperior, and Jirachi. Seismitoad has a positive matchup against some of the entry hazard removers of the tier such as the aforementioned Rotom formes and Tentacruel. Seismitoad is a valuable asset on rain teams as a Stealth Rock setter and wallbreaker that does well against offensive threats such as Thundurus-T and Lycanroc-D due to its defensive typing. However, Seismitoad's lack of reliable recovery outside of Leftovers makes it vulnerable to status effects and Knock Off. Seismitoad's crippling weakness to Grass-types gives Pokemon like Amoonguss and Zarude free entry and bad matchups against threats that carry Grass-type coverage moves such as Nihilego and Gyarados. Seismitoad also faces competition from Gastrodon, as it has access to Recover, though Seismitoad has important access to Stealth Rock and is less passive. Defensive Seismitoad also has to compete with other Stealth Rock setters such as Rhyperior and Krookodile, which offer greater offensive presence.
Seismitoad.comments:
Other Options

A physical Seismitoad can open the door for teammates like Kingdra by blowing through Chansey, Salamence, and Gastrodon with Earthquake, Ice Punch, and Power Whip, respectively, though this gives Seismitoad a worse matchup against Buzzwole. Seismitoad can run more offensive EV spreads on its traditional Stealth Rock set with good coverage options such as Sludge Wave. However, this considerably cuts into Seismitoad's bulk, which is often less than ideal.

Checks and Counters

Grass-type Pokemon and Coverage Moves: Seismitoad's defensive set often invites in Pokemon like Tangrowth and Amoonguss, which are more difficult to outlast due to Regenerator. Zarude has Jungle Healing to remove status, and the Choice Scarf variant outspeeds Modest Seismitoad in rain. This weakness to Grass also means that Pokemon such as Gyarados and Nihilego can threaten Seismitoad with coverage moves like Power Whip and Grass Knot, respectively.

Powerful Wallbreakers: Pokemon like Nidoking, Mienshao, and Crawdaunt greatly hinder Seismitoad's ability to act as a pivot because of their powerful secondary STAB attacks, taking advantage of its passivity and lack of recovery. However, they do not appreciate switching into Seismitoad due to its STAB moves or fear of status.

Setup Sweepers: Pokemon such as Galarian Moltres and Kommo-o can force Seismitoad out or use it as setup fodder due to its relative passivity. However, they have to be weary of Toxic putting them on a timer or Scald crippling their offensive prowess.

sets.name: Defensive Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Seismitoad can use Stealth Rock after pivoting into Pokemon such as Lycanroc-D and Celesteela. Seismitoad walls Defog Rotom-W and Rotom-H lacking status moves, so it is able to consistently keep Stealth Rock in front of teams relying on them for entry hazard removal. Scald gives Seismitoad a chance to burn switch-ins such as Kommo-o and Tapu Bulu. It also provides long-term chip damage on Amoonguss so it does not get the most out of Regenerator. Earthquake gives Seismitoad a better matchup against Calm Mind users like Keldeo and Galarian Slowbro at the cost of reducing Scald's damage output. Earth Power is usable to hit targets like Kommo-o harder but is generally not worth it, as Seismitoad now becomes setup fodder for the aforementioned Keldeo and Galarian Slowbro, and Earth Power fails to OHKO Nihilego. Toxic makes Seismitoad less passive against the likes of Tangrowth and Gastrodon switching in. It also helps Seismitoad outlast other Defoggers such as Salamence and Rotom-W. Knock Off is another option for crippling other switch-ins such as Amoonguss and Chansey, but it makes Seismitoad more passive against other Water-types such as Primarina and Gastrodon. 64 Speed EVs enable Seismitoad to outspeed Adamant Azumarill.

Seismitoad fits best on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate its defensive qualities and Stealth Rock support. Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth are recommended because Seismitoad struggles to check Primarina, Keldeo, and Azumarill by itself, and they act as good Knock Off sponges for Seismitoad to maintain Leftovers. Wallbreakers that blow through Grass-types such as Salamence and Nasty Plot Rotom-H are appreciated. Defoggers such as Moltres and the aforementioned Salamence help keep entry hazards off the field to help maintain Seismitoad's longevity. Sylveon is also a good support teammate to keep Seismitoad healthy with Wish and Heal Bell while also checking Dragon-types like Kommo-o and Salamence that would otherwise give Seismitoad a more difficult time. The pair also provide a solid backbone against Keldeo. Togekiss can similarly play the role of a cleric and assist in pressuring Grass-types like Zarude and Tapu Bulu. In exchange, Seismitoad helps in wearing down Rotom-W, Rhyperior, and non-Grass Knot Nihilego.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Seismitoad has to be more cautious about finding opportunities to set up Stealth Rock, as it is no longer immune to Rotom-W's Hydro Pump, but it does help Seismitoad chip some other answers to rain teams like Amoonguss and Gastrodon. Under rain, Weather Ball comfortably OHKOes many neutral targets such as Conkeldurr and Thundurus-T and 2HKOes targets that resist it such as defensive Salamence after some chip damage. Hydro Pump is an alternative option to deal more damage against specially defensive Pokemon like Sylveon and Celesteela, but its accuracy makes it more unreliable overall. Earth Power 2HKOes threats such as Amoonguss and Gastrodon after some chip damage. Sludge Wave destroys Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu and Zarude while also finishing off a weakened Salamence or Noivern. Power Whip is usable over Stealth Rock to muscle through other Water-types like Rotom-W and Primarina more easily. A Modest nature maximizes Seismitoad's damage output. Timid can be used to outspeed Choice Scarf Zarude, though the drop in power is less than ideal.

This Seismitoad set fits only on rain teams, and its teammates should be able to help break through Pokemon it cannot such as Milotic and Chansey. Pelipper is the best partner to set Drizzle for Seismitoad and can bring it in safely with U-turn against foes like Thundurus-T. Other Swift Swim users like Kingdra can help Seismitoad overwhelm walls such as Amoonguss and Celesteela. Crawdaunt is an excellent partner that lures in and destroys bulky Grass-types like Tangrowth with a Swords Dance-boosted Knock Off, and it has priority in Aqua Jet to hit faster foes. Thundurus-T provides a good backup check to a weakened Raikou that also rips through Celesteela while potentially breaking through Chansey with a Nasty Plot-boosted Focus Blast. Offensive Salamence can pressure the Grass-types of the tier, namely Amoonguss and Choice Scarf Zarude.

Scolipede.overview: Scolipede is a niche late-game cleaner thanks to its ability to boost both its Attack and Speed with Swords Dance and Speed Boost in one turn, giving it a good matchup against both offensive and defensive teams. Its decent STAB combination alongside Earthquake pressures a majority of the tier. Scolipede's typing also provides it with opportunities to set up against foes such as Tangrowth and prevents it from being crippled by Toxic. Unfortunately, Scolipede is very frail, which means it can struggle to set up a Swords Dance safely without being severely worn down. This can severely hinder its ability to clean late-game, especially when it continues to wear itself down from Life Orb recoil. The UU tier also has an abundance of priority users like Lycanroc-D, Azumarill, and Zygarde-10% that can easily pick off Scolipede. Albeit having a respectable Attack stat, Scolipede struggles to break through physically defensive walls such as Celesteela, Skarmory, and Mandibuzz even after a Swords Dance boost. Scolipede also has a crippling weakness to Stealth Rock, which limits how often it can switch in to find opportunities to set up and sweep. All of these factors cause Scolipede to face severe competition from other late-game sweepers like Nihilego and Gyarados.
Scolipede.comments:
Other Options

A suicide lead set consisting of Megahorn / Spikes / Earthquake / Endeavor can be used on hyper offense teams to support wallbreakers and late-game cleaners; however, it has a tough time keeping its entry hazards up due to its inability to pressure common Defoggers. Rock Slide is an option to help break through Rotom-H, Moltres, and Salamence more easily; however, Poison Jab hits these targets hard enough and Earthquake is generally preferred for its ability to pressure Jirachi while still maintaining coverage for other Fire-types like Chandelure. Protect is an option over Earthquake to guarantee a Speed boost, but losing a coverage option greatly hinders its ability to break through a good amount of the tier.

Checks and Counters

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Mandibuzz can stomach a boosted hit from Scolipede and OHKO it in return. Swampert walls Scolipede after a Swords Dance boost and can easily beat it one-on-one. Celesteela and Skarmory indefinitely wall Scolipede, so unless they are removed, it will have a very hard time making any progress.

Priority: Lycanroc-D threatens to OHKO Scolipede with Accelerock, while other common priority users like Azumarill, Mamoswine, and Zygarde-10% can also pick off Scolipede if brought into range.

Stealth Rock: Stealth Rock hinders the number of times Scolipede can set up a Swords Dance and will bring it into range of priority users like Azumarill and Mamoswine.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Megahorn is a powerful STAB move that is necessary for Scolipede to muscle past foes like Amoonguss and Krookodile. Poison Jab provides Scolipede with strong neutral coverage to break through Pokemon like Salamence, Rotom-H, and Kommo-o. It also helps Scolipede beat Fairy-types like Primarina and Azumarill. Earthquake gives Scolipede super effective coverage to break through Pokemon like Excadrill, Tentacruel, and Aegislash. Aqua Tail can be considered to help break through foes like Rhyperior and Rotom-H better; however, it will have a harder time with foes like Tentacruel and Aegislash. Heavy-Duty Boots are an option over Life Orb to offset its weakness to Stealth Rock; however, you miss out on OHKOing Amoonguss after Stealth Rock with a Swords Dance-boosted Megahorn. Amoonguss could then retaliate with a powerful Foul Play as a result. A Jolly nature allows Scolipede to outspeed threats like Keldeo before a Speed Boost, as well as Choice Scarf users like Zarude after a Speed boost.

Scolipede should primarily be used on offense teams that can support it well enough to clean late-game. Entry hazards are key to bring foes like defensive Swampert and Rhyperior into range of a boosted attack, so entry hazard setters like Nihilego, Roserade, and Krookodile are appreciated. Krookodile can also help Scolipede set up a Swords Dance more easily thanks to Intimidate and help blanket check Lycanroc-D if holding a Chople Berry. Entry hazard removal from the likes of Excadrill, Rotom-W, and Salamence can help alleviate Scolipede's weakness to Stealth Rock. Rotom-W can also bring Scolipede in against Grass-types like Tangrowth to set up, while Salamence does a phenomenal job of wearing down Rhyperior into range of a Swords Dance-boosted Earthquake. Wallbreakers like Azumarill and Aegislash can help break through defensive foes like Mandibuzz and Celesteela for Scolipede to sweep more easily. Indeedee-F can provide Psychic Terrain support to prevent Scolipede from being revenge killed by common priority users such as Lycanroc-D and Azumarill. It can also provide Healing Wish support to give Scolipede another opportunity to sweep. Magneton can trap and remove Celesteela and Skarmory for Scolipede, allowing it to sweep more easily.

Krookodile.overview: Krookodile's high Attack, respectable Speed, and amazing offensive typing make it one of the best offensive checks to Pokemon like Aegislash and Galarian Slowbro. Few Pokemon resist the combination of Earthquake and Knock Off, which dents even neutral targets such as Primarina, Keldeo, and Amoonguss. Intimidate lets Krookodile switch into resisted and neutral hits such as Lycanroc-D's Stone Edge without getting too worn down. It also helps prevent late-game sweeps from Pokemon like Salamence. Moves like Stealth Rock and Taunt let Krookodile compress utility roles, and its ability to run a plethora of items, like Life Orb, Leftovers, Choice Scarf, Choice Band, and resist berries, makes for a key factor in its unpredictability and versatility. It's one of the best Choice Scarf users in UU, capable of revenge killing threats like Thundurus-T and Lycanroc-D. With Choice Band, it can remove common answers to it like Amoonguss more easily. However, Krookodile is threatened by physical attackers like Lycanroc-D and Zygarde-10% even after Intimidate, and its special bulk leaves it vulnerable to special attackers like Nidoking and Aegislash. Weaknesses to common types like Grass, Water, and Fighting hinder its defensive utility and leave it helpless against common Pokemon like Tangrowth, Azumarill, and Conkeldurr. Coverage from Electric-types like Thundurus-T's Focus Blast prevents Krookodile from checking them despite its Electric immunity. Excadrill gives Krookodile immense competition as a utility Ground-type on teams, sporting a better defensive typing, having access to Rapid Spin, and being able to hit hard without investment in Attack. However, Krookodile's access to Knock Off, Intimidate, and a greater speed tier letting it threaten Moltres and opposing Excadrill gives it a niche on certain teams.
Krookodile.comments:
Other Options

Rindo Berry is an option to survive +1 Nihilego's Grass Knot and OHKO back with Earthquake. Meanwhile, Passho Berry gives Krookodile a chance to eliminate threats like Crawdaunt and Rotom-W. Life Orb lets Krookodile pressure Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Rotom-W more easily. Smack Down is an option on the Stealth Rock set to ground Skarmory and prevent it from taking advantage of Krookodile. Krookodile can opt for a more offensive Choice Scarf set with Moxie, letting it accumulate Attack boosts as it KOes enemies. However, the utility that Intimidate offers is more worth it to weaken Pokemon like Lycanroc-D, and Krookodile can't break past Grass-types and Buzzwole without enough boosts. Choice Band Assurance can nail Pokemon like Amoonguss as they switch in, but it requires specific conditions and good prediction

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Tangrowth check Krookodile very well and are only bothered by Knock Off. Both cause big damage with Giga Drain and incapacitate a team member with Spore or Sleep Powder. However, Amoonguss has to wary of Choice Band Earthquake, as it is 2HKOed after Stealth Rock damage. Zarude and Tapu Bulu can also switch into Krookodile's STAB moves and can recover with Jungle Healing or Horn Leech.

Water-types: Rotom-W and Gyarados are immune to Ground and can take advantage of Krookodile being Choice-locked into Earthquake. The former can remove Stealth Rock with Defog, while the latter can get a free turn of setup. Krookodile also can't take any Water-type hits from Azumarill, Primarina, and Keldeo, but they don't like to switch in directly into its moves. Swampert and Slowking can take hits from Krookodile and threaten it back, though the latter doesn't like a Choice Band-boosted Knock Off.

Fighting-types: Mienshao, Keldeo, Cobalion, and Conkeldurr also threaten Krookodile greatly. The former three outspeed non-Choice Scarf sets, with Choice Scarf Mienshao outspeeding even those. Meanwhile, Conkeldurr has the bulk to take an Earthquake and recover its health with Drain Punch or just pick off Krookodile with Mach Punch. However, Mienshao and Cobalion should scout for Chople Berry and Choice Scarf sets.

Strong Wallbreakers: Despite its ability and good defensive typing, Krookodile has subpar bulk and lacks reliable recovery, meaning it gets worn down quite quickly switching into Pokemon such as Excadrill and Zygarde-10%. Pokemon like Aegislash and Nidoking hurt it very badly with even resisted special STAB moves due to its bad special bulk.

sets.name: Stealth Rock
sets.description:
Krookodile's role compression and item versatility let it perform on both hyper offense teams and on more defensive ones, like balance and bulky offense. With Life Orb, this set fits on hyper offense teams as a great lead. If running Leftovers or a Berry, this set fits on bulky offense and balance teams, which appreciate Krookodile's utility and resistances. Knock Off is useful for checks like Amoonguss, Swampert, and Celesteela, crippling them for Krookodile's teammates. High Horsepower should be used in place of Earthquake if Tapu Bulu is on Krookodile's team, as Grassy Terrain weakens Earthquake. Stealth Rock wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Tangrowth for teammates like Aegislash and Choice Specs Primarina. Toxic allows Krookodile to cripple checks such as Tangrowth and Tapu Bulu. Taunt prevents Stealth Rock and Defog from Pokemon like Excadrill, Swampert, Rotom-W, and Moltres. Leftovers offsets entry hazard damage and gives Krookodile longevity to keep threats like Nihilego, Excadrill, and Aegislash in check more easily. Chople Berry lets Krookodile take Lycanroc-D's Close Combat and KO back with Earthquake. It also helps Krookodile take Thundurus-T's Focus Blast to then weaken or KO it. Maximum investement in HP lets Krookodile better check Excadrill and Aegislash.

Setup sweepers such as Thundurus-T and Salamence work well with Krookodile, as it can set Stealth Rock up and weaken their checks such as Diancie and Primarina. Special attackers like Azelf and Nihilego appreciate Krookodile denting and crippling their checks in Chansey and Celesteela with Knock Off, paving their way to sweep. In return, they compensate for Krookodile's lower Speed tier and remove Pokemon like Conkeldurr, Zarude, and Tapu Bulu. Amoonguss can check Pokemonn like Primarina, Mienshao, and Zarude for Krookodile, and together they can keep Lycanroc-D in check. Salamence forms a double Intimidate core with Krookodile, weakening Pokemon like Zarude and stopping setup sweepers like Gyarados from getting out of control. Krookodile is vulnerable against Fairy-types such as Azumarill and Togekiss so partners like Aegislash, Rotom-W, and Tentacruel are valuable. Tapu Bulu threatens Azumarill and Primarina for Krookodile. It can also provide Grassy Terrain to give Krookodile more recovery.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Knock Off pressures walls that rely on their items, like Mandibuzz, Celesteela, and Chansey, and discourages Pokemon like Rotom-H and Salamence from switching in. Stone Edge threatens Pokemon immune to Ground like Gyarados, Moltres, and Rotom-H. Close Combat lets Krookodile hit targets such as Zarude, Hydreigon, Chansey, and opposing Krookodile harder. Toxic cripples switch-ins such as Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth, but since others like Amoonguss and Zarude are immune or resilient to it, it's quite matchup reliant. Darkest Lariat is useful to hit Pokemon like Rotom-W harder after they've had their items removed. Stealth Rock can be used to take advantage of Krookodile's ability to force switches against Pokemon such as Azelf and Nihilego, but it should only be used when the role compression is necessary, and it requires very good prediction. Choice Scarf turns Krookodile into a solid revenge killer, outspeeding key Pokemon and sweepers such as Lycanroc-D, Azelf, and +1 Gyarados.

This set fits well on offense, bulky offense, and balance teams that need a fast revenge killer. These kinds of teams appreciate Krookodile's defensive utility in its two immunities and Intimidate. Even though Intimidate allows Krookodile to take on physical attacks a bit better, it shouldn't be relied on, so teammates like Aegislash and Tangrowth help it against wallbreakers like Lycanroc-D. Assault Vest Tangrowth takes on threatening Water-types such as Primarina, Rotom-W, and Keldeo well. Strong wallbreakers such as Thundurus-T and Nidoking can get past Krookodile's checks such as Slowking, Skarmory, and Tapu Bulu, allowing it to spam its STAB moves more freely. Krookodile is helpless against Grass-types, so partners that can pressure them like Nihilego and Mamoswine are great. Rotom-H is another good teammate that can scare away Grass-types and brings Krookodile in on checks like Nihilego. Entry hazard support from teammates such as Nihilego and Jirachi is key to weaken checks like Rotom-W and Primarina. Salamence and Moltres ensure Tapu Bulu is not given free turns to wallbreak, as it can freely come into Krookodile.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Earthquake and Knock Off threaten a large portion of the metagame and together have almost unresisted coverage, hitting even Amoonguss hard thanks to Choice Band. Stone Edge hits Pokemon immune to Ground like Salamence, Moltres, and Mandibuzz. Close Combat hits Zarude and Chansey harder. Toxic cripples common switch-ins, such as Swampert and Tapu Bulu. Darkest Lariat hits Rotom-W and Tangrowth harder after Knock Off. Choice Band gives Krookodile extra power to break through would-be checks like Amoonguss and defensive Primarina, notably 2HKOing the former with Earthquake.

Krookodile fits on bulky offense and balance teams, where it acts as a potent wallbreaker and clears the way for late-game sweepers like Substitute + Calm Mind Primarina and Azelf by removing threats like Amoonguss and Chansey. Due to its frailty, Krookodile loves VoltTurn support from teammates like Jirachi and Mienshao, which can bring it in safely against Pokemon such as Aegislash and Tentacruel to start wreaking havoc. Rotom-H is an especially great teammate, since it can bring in Krookodile with Volt Switch and scares out switch-ins like Tangrowth, Zarude, and Skarmory. Entry hazard support from allies like Nihilego and Skarmory is greatly appreciated to weaken checks like Tangrowth. Future Sight Support from Slowking and Galarian Slowbro amplifies Krookodile's wallbreaking power by dealing great combined damage to threats like Tangrowth and Conkeldurr. Late-game cleaners like Lycanroc-D and Dragon Dance Gyarados appreciate Krookodile weakening checks like Amoonguss and Celesteela. Grass-types like Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth make great teammates, as they sponge Water- and Grass-type hits from Pokemon like Azumarill and Zarude, while Krookodile can scare out Salamence and Moltres for them.

Reuniclus.overview: With amazing HP and Special Defense stats, an excellent ability in Regenerator, and solid coverage moves, Reuniclus is one of the best special tanks in the tier, capable of checking foes such as Nidoking and Keldeo. Additionally, Reuniclus's powerful Future Sight allows it to support many top-tier threats such as Mienshao and Mamoswine. However, Reuniclus faces heavy competition from other Psychic-types and defensive Pokemon in the tier. Despite access to Knock Off and superior special bulk, Galarian Slowbro's Toxic immunity and Fire-type coverage to beat Steel-types often make it the superior choice, while Chansey is better at preserving momentum thanks to Teleport. Reuniclus is also very vulnerable to Knock Off from Pokemon it switches into, such as Nihilego and Azelf.
Reuniclus.comments:
Other Options

Reuniclus can run a physically defensive Calm Mind set with Magic Guard to turn it into a deadly setup sweeper, but it has trouble picking between Focus Blast to hit Dark-types and Shadow Ball to hit Aegislash, making other Calm Mind users like Hatterene and Galarian Slowbro, which don't struggle with their coverage as much, better options. A Trick Room set with Life Orb can be used to threaten offensive teams while negating Reuniclus's poor Speed, but this set is mediocre can't fit Recover or Regenerator, which causes it to lack defensive utility.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types and Dark-type Coverage: Zarude, Krookodile, and Galarian Moltres can all easily outspeed Reuniclus and threaten it with their STAB attacks, though the former two do not like switching into a Focus Blast. Other Pokemon like Nihilego and Azelf can use Knock Off against Reuniclus, which both damages it greatly and removes its Assault Vest.

Ghost-types: Aegislash and Chandelure can easily take out Reuniclus with their STAB attacks, though both of them fear Shadow Ball.

Steel-types: Celesteela and Jirachi resist Reuniclus's STAB attacks and can easily force it out, but the latter does not like taking a Shadow Ball, and neither enjoys getting its item removed by Knock Off.

Physical Wallbreakers: Pokemon such as Lycanroc-D, Azumarill, and Entei can hit Reuniclus hard on its weaker defensive side and overwhelm it more easily.

sets.name: Assault Vest
sets.description:
Psyshock is used over Psychic to hit Chansey harder, OHKO Nihilego, and threaten Calm Mind users such as Primarina. Future Sight pressures the opposing team and forces switches that Reuniclus and its teammates can easily exploit. Focus Blast allows Reuniclus to hit Dark- and Steel-types coming in on a Future Sight such as Krookodile, Zarude, and Cobalion super effectively. Shadow Ball lets Reuniclus hit Ghost- and Psychic-types such as Aegislash, Galarian Slowbro, and Hatterene. Knock Off can be used to remove items, letting Reuniclus pressure walls such as Tangrowth and Celesteela. It also gives Reuniclus another way to deal with Chansey by removing its Eviolite and still hits Ghost- and Psychic-types. Assault Vest greatly improves on Reuniclus's special bulk, allowing it to switch in on powerful hits such as Primarina's Moonblast and Salamence's Hurricane. 20 Special Attack EVs allow Reuniclus's Focus Blast to OHKO Krookodile after Stealth Rock damage.

Reuniclus is best used on balance and bulky offense teams as a defensive pivot that checks Pokemon such as Salamence and Keldeo. Wallbreakers such as Mienshao and Mamoswine greatly appreciate Reuniclus's presence, as its Future Sight discourages their checks, such as Buzzwole, from switching in against them. In return, these wallbreakers can remove Dark-types such as Umbreon and Galarian Moltres. Reuniclus is very susceptible to Knock Off, so Knock Off absorbers such as Cobalion and Buzzwole are valued as partners. These Pokemon can also check Dark-types such as Zarude and Krookodile. Dark-types such as Krookodile and Obstagoon make great partners, as they can deal with Aegislash, a Pokemon that Reuniclus greatly struggles against. Entry hazard removers such as Salamence and Tentacruel prevent Regenerator's recovery from being cancelled out, letting Reuniclus switch in and out more reliably. Other Regenerator users such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth, can form a Regenerator core with Reuniclus, tank physical hits, and switch into Knock Off.

Amoonguss.overview: Amoonguss is a potent defensive pivot due to its good defensive typing, which enables it to check dangerous foes such as Mienshao, Primarina, and Zarude, combined with its access to Regenerator. Access to Spore allows Amoonguss to shut down an opposing foe completely, making it harder to play around and offensively check due to pressuring opponents to choose sleep fodder. Its Poison typing additionally gives it an edge over other common Grass-types, as it is able to threaten Tangrowth and Zarude with Sludge Bomb, which also prevents them from switching in to absorb Spore. However, despite Amoonguss's good defensive typing, it struggles against metagame staples like Salamence and Hydreigon. It can also be overwhelmed by Pokemon it is supposed to check due to their access to coverage, such as Ice Punch from Azumarill, Psychic from Primarina, and Zen Headbutt from Tapu Bulu. After using Spore, Amoonguss is easy to take advantage of by setup sweepers that take little from its other moves such as Galarian Slowbro and Galarian Moltres. Amoonguss faces competition from Tangrowth as a defensive Grass-type pivot, which can opt to run Assault Vest sets to check specially offensive foes such as Aegislash and Thundurus-T better.
Amoonguss.comments:
Other Options

Assault Vest allows Amoonguss to act as a better check to special attackers like Keldeo and Thundurus-T. It can even still run utility moves like Spore due to Amoonguss's tendency to get hit with Knock Off. Synthesis allows Amoonguss to recover HP without needing to switch out, so it is forced out less. However, it means Amoonguss cannot damage Steel-types at all aside from putting them to sleep with Spore. Heavy-Duty Boots can also be run to help it pivot in against Spikes stacking teams, but the chip damage or passive recovery is too valuable. It is also prone to being hit by Knock Off from Pokemon it attempts to check such as Krookodile and Azumarill, limiting the effectiveness of this set. Seed Bomb does more damage to Calm Mind Primarina, particularly Substitute sets that can boost enough to stop Sludge Bomb breaking the Substitute. However, it does less damage to most other Water-types and loses out on the recovery of Giga Drain.

Checks and Counters

Psychic-types and Psychic-type coverage: Offensive Psychic-types like Necrozma and Azelf can force out Amoonguss with their powerful attacks. If it has Safety Goggles, Galarian Slowbro can easily setup on Amoonguss. Psychic-type coverage like Psychic Fangs on Lycanroc-D and Psychic on Primarina and Thundurus-T also dent Amoonguss.

Fire-types: Rotom-H threatens Amoonguss with Overheat and can gain momentum with Volt Switch or set up with Nasty Plot. Entei and Chandelure can threaten to OHKO Amoonguss with their powerful STAB.

Flying-types: Salamence, Togekiss, and Moltres all deal heavy damage to Amoonguss with their STAB attacks. Galarian Moltres can easily pivot into Amoonguss, not fearing status thanks to Rest, and either nail it with Hurricane or set up on it.

Strong Wallbreakers: While Amoonguss is bulky, it can be overwhelmed by wallbreakers such as Nidoking, Mamoswine, and Diggersby. These Pokemon all fear Spore, however, so they can only effectively threaten Amoonguss if a teammate has been put to sleep or they are brought in safely. Conkeldurr is able to overwhelm Amoonguss with Facade and is immune to Spore once its Flame Orb activates.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Giga Drain heavily damages Lycanroc-D and Keldeo, which Amoonguss naturally checks by virtue of its typing and bulk. It also enables Amoonguss to regain some HP, reducing the need for it to continually pivot for Regenerator recovery. Sludge Bomb threatens Primarina, Zarude, and Azumarill. It is also useful for the chance to poison switch-ins such as Salamence. Foul Play dents physical attackers such as Gyarados and prevents them from setting up on Amoonguss, and it is also Amoonguss's best way to damage other Steel-types such as Aegislash and Jirachi. Spore shuts down Pokemon such as Moltres and Hydreigon, deterring them from wanting to pivot into it. This often requires an opposing team to use a Pokemon as sleep fodder, making it easier for Amoonguss's teammates to capitalize on. Rocky Helmet punishes physical attackers Amoonguss switches into such as Azumarill and Zarude. Eject Button can be run so Amoonguss can pivot into a foe, take a hit, and bring in a teammate safely. Black Sludge is an alternative option that reduces Amoonguss's reliance on switching out to regain HP with Regenerator. 36 Special Defense EVs guarantee that Amoonguss can take a Choice Specs-boosted Psychic from Primarina as well as better check Keldeo. A more specially defensive spread can be used to better check Keldeo and Aegislash, though this gives Amoonguss a worse matchup against Mienshao, Excadrill, and Lycanroc-D.

Amoonguss fits best on bulky offense, balance, and stall teams that appreciate its ability to blanket check dangerous metagame staples such as Azumarill and Excadrill. Chansey can take on special attackers like Nidoking, Moltres, and Hydreigon that can overwhelm Amoonguss. Checks to Moltres and Salamence, such as Diancie and Primarina, are useful partners that can switch into them and force it out. Dark-types such as Krookodile and Mandibuzz can check Psychic-types like Galarian Slowbro and Azelf. Amoonguss is heavily threatened by Fire-types such as Entei and Moltres, so checks to these such as Slowking and Rhyperior make good partners. Amoonguss is vulnerable to Stealth Rock and Spikes chip damage, so entry hazard removal support from partners such as Salamence and Excadrill enables it to switch in more often and prevents entry hazards from cancelling out its Regenerator recovery.

Chandelure.overview: Chandelure's amazing Special Attack stat, threatening STAB combination, and wide utility movepool make it a strong offensive presence capable of working around most of its checks. Choice Specs is an excellent option for its immediate wallbreaking prowess and ability to utilize utility moves like Sleep Talk and Trick. Alternatively, Hex Chandelure can take advantage of the switches it forces to burden switch-ins like Primarina and Kommo-o with status, wearing them down with chip damage and STAB Hex throughout the match. Chandelure's typing also offers a few defensive benefits, letting it soft check popular Pokemon like Celesteela and Amoonguss. Unfortunately, Chandelure's rather average Speed and common weaknesses allow UU's many faster threats, including Keldeo, Krookodile, and Nihilego, to overwhelm it. Moreover, it is weak to Stealth Rock, which can significantly damage its longevity on sets that aren't running Heavy-Duty Boots. The other Fire- and Ghost-types available in UU also give Chandelure great competition, with Moltres offering greater utility through its typing, recovery, and pivoting capabilities, and Aegislash both lacking a Stealth Rock weakness and being more versatile overall.
Chandelure.comments:
Other Options

Substitute + Calm Mind is an okay option for a set, taking advantage of defensive foes like Chansey to find setup opportunities. However, Chandelure's other sets are more immediately powerful, which is often more valuable for it. Will-O-Wisp is an option over Toxic on the Hex set, inflicting status on foes immune to poison like Tentacruel and Nihilego. However, Toxic is usually more valuable due to its greater long-term chip damage on Pokemon like Primarina and Gastrodon, as well as its ability to hit Fire-types like Rotom-H and Moltres. Energy Ball is a situational option for powering through various Pokemon, like Rhyperior, Gastrodon, and Seismitoad, in one hit. It also deals super effective damage to foes like Primarina and Suicune. Chandelure can still hit all the aforementioned targets hard with its Ghost-type moves, however. Choice Scarf Chandelure is an adequate revenge killer with its potent offensive typing, even still having the option of crippling defensive checks with Trick, though it notably lacks power and is usually only standout on sun teams. Memento allows Chandelure to grab momentum for its team after it's been weakened while potentially positioning a teammate to sweep. This is rather situational and gives up better utility, though, usually only working well on Choice item sets.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Several Water-types can often find ways to give Chandelure trouble. Azumarill and Crawdaunt can apply serious pressure with their powerful STAB Aqua Jet. Primarina can take any hit from full health and power through Chandelure with its Water-type STAB moves. Tentacruel can be particularly annoying, tanking attacks with its good special bulk and checking the Hex set well thanks to its Toxic immunity. Although they fear Toxic, Milotic and Mantine make for solid answers thanks to their reliable recovery. Both can also often take two Choice Specs-boosted Shadow Balls from full, but they should be wary of being too worn down to reliably pivot in.

Dark-types: Krookodile and Zarude often struggle to reliably switch in, but they can outspeed Chandelure and pick it off with super effective STAB moves. Incineroar, albeit uncommon, resists both of Chandelure's STAB moves and can take advantage of it to annoy a switch-in with either Knock Off or status. Galarian Moltres's high Special Defense allows it to tank hits from Chandelure to then set up. Umbreon is another good check thanks to its superb special bulk and Heal Bell, which allow it to handle Hex sets on its own.

Faster threats: Chandelure's rather average Speed leaves it vulnerable to most faster Pokemon, such as Keldeo, Lycanroc-D, and Mienshao, which can smack it with super effective attacks.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Various specially bulky Pokemon can tank hits from Chandelure and cripple it in return. Chansey doesn't risk major damage from any attack, but it needs to look out for Trick or Taunt on the switch; Taunt leaves it completely unable to touch Chandelure. Nihilego can always take at least one Shadow Ball from full and pressure Chandelure with a super effective STAB moves. It's a particularly strong check to the Hex set, bearing an immunity to Toxic and taking minimal damage from Fire-type moves.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Fire Blast is an immensely powerful STAB move that can significantly damage even resisted foes, threatening to 2HKO Salamence and Keldeo. Overheat is also an option, offering even more power and notably damaging foes like Bulletproof Kommo-o and Incineroar more reliably. However, its Special Attack drop makes Fire Blast more spammable. Flamethrower is strong and accurate, preventing foes like Aegislash, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss from utilizing a lucky Fire Blast miss to cripple Chandelure. Psychic is an option that provides coverage against Kommo-o and Nihilego, though both these targets are adequately worn down by Chandelure's other attacks. Sleep Talk lets Chandelure act as a sleep absorber for its team, pivoting in on Amoonguss's Spore without being entirely crippled. Trick is another option in the fourth moveslot, however, to cripple defensive switch-ins like Chansey, Incineroar, and Tentacruel. Flash Fire allows Chandelure to pivot in on Fire-type attacks from foes like Moltres and Choice-locked Entei, boosting its damage output. Flame Body is also an option, however, to potentially punish physical attackers such as Buzzwole.

This set is a solid fit on offense and balance teams for the massive wallbreaking prowess it offers. Chandelure appreciates entry hazard support for furthering damage on foes alongside its attacks; Rhyperior and Seismitoad are solid choices, additionally pivoting in on foes that can revenge kill it like Lycanroc-D and Thundurus-T. Entry hazard removal is also important due to this set's vulnerability to Stealth Rock. Tentacruel can pivot in on foes like Keldeo and Primarina while utilizing Rapid Spin. Rotom-W is a particularly strong teammate, as it can lure in Grass-types like Amoonguss and pivot Chandelure into them with Volt Switch while also making use of Defog. Pivots that can bring Chandelure in safely for opportunities to wallbreak make good teammates. Zarude is another strong partner, pressuring foes like Primarina and Nihilego for Chandelure and bringing it in against Pokemon like Buzzwole and Amoonguss. Sweepers like Swords Dance Kommo-o and Calm Mind Keldeo appreciate this set's wallbreaking prowess weakening teams for them to more easily clean up late-game. This set can struggle breaking past a few specially defensive Pokemon, such as Chansey and Tentacruel, making physically offensive Pokemon like Mienshao and Mamoswine decent partners to complement Chandelure's pressure.

sets.name: Hex
sets.description:
Hex severely damages foes that Chandelure hits with Toxic. However, it should be noted that it isn't too powerful on non-statused foes, which can require careful play. Toxic burdens potential switch-ins like Bulletproof Kommo-o, Gastrodon, and Salamence, putting them on a timer and allowing Chandelure to potentially whittle them down with Hex. Protect allows Chandelure to rack up poison damage and can also scout Choice item users, such as Zarude and Primarina. Fire Blast is an option over Flamethrower, providing more power for breaking past foes like Galarian Moltres and Nidoqueen more reliably. Its lower accuracy can be a burden, however, against foes like Amoonguss and Tangrowth that can punish a miss. Taunt is an option over Protect, allowing Chandelure to pressure Chansey more effectively by blocking Chansey's recovery and Toxic, which boosts its stall matchup. However, Protect is often too valuable thanks to its stronger applications against offensive Pokemon. Heavy-Duty Boots significantly boosts this set's longevity and self-sufficiency. Flash Fire allows Chandelure to take advantage of foes like opposing Choice-locked Chandelure. Flame Body is also an option, however, allowing it to pivot into and threaten a burn against foes like Jirachi and Celesteela. It can also let Chandelure cripple Pokemon that revenge kill it, like Knock Off Azelf, as it faints.

This set is a strong fit on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate Chandelure's ability to wear down defensive threats early- to mid-game. Chandelure notably struggles breaking past the likes of Nihilego and Tentacruel with this set's listed options, making Pokemon more equipped to handle them, like Nidoqueen and Seismitoad, good teammates. Both can also set Stealth Rock for Chandelure, whittling down its checks. Other entry hazard setters can work well too; Rhyperior can also ease the matchup against foes like Moltres and Nihilego without Grass Knot, and Kommo-o can pivot in on opposing Chandelure. Sweepers like Kommo-o and Keldeo appreciate Chandelure's ability to weaken bulky foes like Rhyperior and Primarina throughout a match with Toxic, allowing them to clean up more easily late-game. Chandelure appreciates them compensating for its slightly paltry Speed. Chandelure also enjoys pivots as teammates, as it doesn't often enjoy directly switching into play. In addition to providing pivoting support, Choice Scarf Jirachi can pressure faster Pokemon like Lycanroc-D and Nihilego, while Rotom-W can lure in Pokemon like Tangrowth for Chandelure to take advantage of. Rotom-W can also pivot in on various Ground-types, like Rhyperior and Krookodile. Other status spreaders can work well as teammates, alleviating Chandelure's need for prediction regarding Hex. Galarian Slowbro is particularly good at spreading status due to its tendency to run both Scald and Sludge Bomb. Tentacruel does this as well and can also utilize Knock Off to further cripple foes.

Mienshao.overview: A solid Speed tier, Regenerator, and moves like Knock Off and U-turn make Mienshao a solid choice for an offensive pivot or wallbreaker. Regenerator means that Mienshao isn't worn down by entry hazards, Rocky Helmet damage, and Life Orb recoil, giving it much more longevity than the average wallbreaker. Its good coverage moves in Poison Jab and Stone Edge can take out many of its would-be checks, such as Hatterene and Salamence. Mienshao is also one of the best Choice Scarf users in the metagame, being able to revenge kill threats like Lycanroc-D and Starmie while also outrunning other Choice Scarf users like Krookodile and Jirachi. However, Mienshao suffers from flaws that depend on the item and coverage moves that it is running. If running Life Orb, Mienshao has a mediorce Speed tier, leaving it easily revenge killed by threats like Keldeo and Thundurus, while running Choice Scarf makes it much harder to score KOs. It struggles with Pokemon like Moltres if not running Stone Edge and Hatterene if not running Poison Jab. Mienshao also has incredibly low HP and defenses, so priority attacks like Lycanroc-D's Accelerock and Azumarill's Aqua Jet easily threaten it. It also does not have good coverage to deal with Amoonguss and Buzzwole, both of which are very prominent in the tier.
Mienshao.comments:
Other Options

Assault Vest boosts Mienshao's bulk, synergizes with Regenerator, and lets it pivot decently into Nihilego and Aegislash, but it doesn't boost Speed or damage output. Choice Band can be used to increase Mienshao's firepower, but Life Orb's flexibility is preferred despite the slight power loss. Blaze Kick can be used to deal with Amoonguss and Buzzwole, but it lacks other relevant targets and doesn't do much to Buzzwole anyway. Reckless + High Jump Kick makes Mienshao hit even harder, but the risk of missing is too great, and Mienshao also really needs the recovery from Regenerator.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Primarina, Azumarill, Hatterene, and Tapu Bulu resist all of Mienshao's main attacking moves. However, they do have to scout Mienshao to see if it is running Poison Jab.

Flying-types: Pokemon like Salamence and Moltres can easily wall Close Combat, forcing Mienshao to use the unreliable Stone Edge to take them out. Salamence can also cripple Mienshao with Intimidate, making it easier to pivot into. However, these Pokemon are usually very reliant on Heavy-Duty Boots, meaning that Mienshao can easily cripple them with Knock Off.

Physical Walls: Pokemon like Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Buzzwole can all comfortably shrug off Mienshao's attacks, even if it is holding a Life Orb.

Faster Pokemon and Priority: Pokemon like Lycanroc-D, Keldeo, and Azelf can outspeed and revenge kill Mienshao; however, they must scout for Choice Scarf first. Pokemon like Lycanroc-D and Azumarill can do the same thing with their priority attacks, but the latter needs a fair amount of chip damage to be able to OHKO Mienshao, and the former can't switch in safely against it.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Knock Off is especially useful for removing items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Rocky Helmet from checks like Salamence and Amoonguss. U-turn lets Mienshao pivot, allowing it to escape checks like Amoonguss and Buzzwole and safely bring in a teammate. Stone Edge KOes Flying-types like Salamence, Moltres, and Noivern. Poison Jab hits Fairy-types such as Primarina, Azumarill, and Tapu Bulu. Life Orb increases Mienshao's damage output, which allows it to perform better against physical walls such as Tangrowth.

Mienshao works best on balance and offense teams as a powerful wallbreaker that can easily cripple its foes with Knock Off, as well as form VoltTurn cores. Late-game sweepers such as Gyarados and Nihilego appreciate Mienshao wearing down their checks such as Salamence and Nidoqueen, allowing them to clean up more easily. Nihilego is an especially good partner because it can set entry hazards, which allow Mienshao to beat checks like Hatterene, Tangrowth, and Galarian Slowbro more easily. Other entry hazard setters like Jirachi and Rhyperior also work well as teammates. Mienshao's is outsped and revenge killed by common threats like Keldeo and Thundurus-T, so faster teammates are appreciated. Choice Scarf Krookodile makes an especially good partner for Mienshao, as their combined power allows them to overwhelm shared checks such as Amoonguss and Togekiss. Lycanroc-D is also a good option because it can check Keldeo and Thundurus-T for Mienshao. Mienshao greatly appreciates Future Sight support from teammates like Reuniclus and Galarian Slowbro, which helps it take out its two biggest checks, Amoonguss and Buzzwole. Electric-types like Regieleki and Rotom-H form a fast VoltTurn core with Mienshao. Rotom-H is a particularly good partner, as it can remove some of Mienshao's biggest checks in Amoonguss, Buzzwole, and Tangrowth. Strong special attackers like Primarina and Azelf greatly appreciate Mienshao taking out Chansey and forming a strong wallbreaking core with them. RestTalk Primarina in particular is amazing as it can check Pokemon like Salamence and Keldeo for Mienshao and be a generally fantastic defensive partner for it to fall back on.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
With Choice Scarf, Mienshao becomes an excellent revenge killer, outspeeding and taking out foes like Thundurus, Keldeo, +1 Gyarados, and non-Choice Scarf Zarude. Knock Off prevents Aegislash from walling Mienshao and also removes items from checks like Salamence and Togekiss. Stone Edge takes out Flying-types like Salamence and Moltres, while Poison Jab handles Hatterene and Primarina. Regenerator prevents Mienshao being worn down by entry hazards, making it an even more effective pivot.

Choice Scarf Mienshao works best with hard-hitting attackers, as well as other fast pivots that can form a VoltTurn core with it, so it fits best on playstyles like bulky offense. Azelf and Noivern are both especially good partners for Mienshao, as their extremely high Speed tiers ensure a very fast pivoting core that lets them bring each other and their teammates in with ease. Dark-types like Zarude and Galarian Moltres can help deal with Psychic-types such as Reuniclus and Azelf. In return, Mienshao can revenge kill threats like Gyarados and boosted Kommo-o for them. Frail wallbreakers like Lycanroc-D, Mamoswine, and Chandelure appreciate Mienshao bring them in safely. In turn, it appreciates these Pokemon's raw power, which allows them to take on threats Mienshao struggles to break through such as Tangrowth and Nidoqueen. Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi are greatly appreciated as partners, as they can deal with Psychic- and Fairy-types like Galarian Slowbro and Primarina.

Cobalion.overview: Cobalion's typing makes it one of the best defensive answers to common threats such as Nihilego, Jirachi, and Zarude, with its ability Justified also punishing the former for using Knock Off. Its Speed tier allows it to revenge kill Pokemon such as Nihilego and non-Choice Scarf Mienshao as well as set itself apart from other Stealth Rock setters like Jirachi and Nihilego, allowing it to pivot out of its checks and counters such as Salamence and Aegislash with Volt Switch more easily. Cobalion's Swords Dance set also stands out among other physical setup sweepers such as Aegislash and Ice Fang Gyarados by not fearing any of Amoonguss's attacks, becoming a fierce wallbreaker after Sleep Clause has been activated. Cobalion's typing has its drawbacks, though, as it is not Fairy or Flying resistant like other Steel-types, making Cobalion unreliable at switching into threats such as Hatterene and Galarian Moltres. Without Swords Dance, its offensive prowess also is underwhelming compared to its Fighting-type competition such as Mienshao and Kommo-o. Lastly, Cobalion's lack of recovery means it is susceptible to being worn down by repeated attacks and Rocky Helmet chip from Pokemon like Amoonguss and Buzzwole, while its mediocre Special Defense means even uninvested attacks from Pokemon like Rotom-W and Primarina will deal considerable damage.
Cobalion.comments:
Other Options

Megahorn can be used over Iron Head to heavily damage Reuniclus, which otherwise takes advantage of Cobalion, although Reuniclus is uncommon and giving up on Iron Head means sacrificing consistent damage on threats such as Primarina, Nidoking, and Amoonguss. Shuca Berry makes Cobalion less vulnerable to being revenge killed by Krookodile and Zygarde-10%, but its use is otherwise limited. A Calm Mind set is able to bait Pokemon such as Buzzwole and give Cobalion a boost to its lackluster Special Defense. However, Focus Blast is a less reliable STAB move than Close Combat and gives Cobalion a worse matchup against Chansey. Life Orb makes Cobalion more immediately threatening, as it enables Close Combat to OHKO Mienshao without a boost and guarantees other OHKOs against Pokemon such as offensive Kommo-o with +2 Close Combat and Salamence with +1 Stone Edge. However, this leaves Cobalion much more susceptible to being worn down.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-resistant Foes: Pokemon that resist Close Combat such as Buzzwole and Galarian Slowbro are able to take advantage of Cobalion's usual lack of power by either firing back with their own attacks or using Cobalion as setup fodder. Aegislash completely walls Cobalion and can use the opportunity to attack with Shadow Ball or set up with Substitute or Swords Dance as Cobalion is forced out.

Bulky Water-types: Pokemon such as Gastrodon, Quagsire, and Seismitoad can burn Cobalion with Scald and block Volt Switch. Other threats such as Rotom-W, Starmie, and Tentacruel don't mind Cobalion's attacks very much and can remove Cobalion's entry hazards.

Fire-types: Moltres and Rotom-H target Cobalion's Fire weakness, and the former has Flame Body to potentially cripple Cobalion with a burn. Chandelure is able to switch into either of Cobalion's STAB moves and launch a powerful attack. However, Fire-types risk being KOed by Stone Edge. Pokemon that carry Fire-type coverage such as Celesteela can also threaten Cobalion.

Ground-types: Nidoking can switch in on either Volt Switch or Close Combat and threaten Cobalion with Earth Power, while Zygarde-10% outspeeds Cobalion and slams it with Thousand Arrows. Krookodile commonly carries Chople Berry or Choice Scarf, letting it get the upper hand on Cobalion.

Faster Threats: Pokemon such as Choice Scarf Mienshao and Lycanroc-D outspeed and consistently revenge kill Cobalion with Close Combat.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Cobalion has plenty of opportunities to set up Stealth Rock against Pokemon like Zarude and Jirachi thanks to its typing and bulk. Iron Head provides consistent damage against foes like Nidoqueen and Hatterene, while Stone Edge threatens Moltres, preventing it from removing entry hazards freely, and makes Cobalion a better revenge killer to Thundurus-T. Volt Switch is useful for helping Cobalion gain momentum against switch-ins like Moltres and giving safe entry to teammates such as Primarina. Rocky Helmet is primarily used to punish contact moves from Jirachi and Zarude, while Leftovers allows Cobalion to remain healthy while checking Chansey and non-Knock Off Nihilego.

Cobalion fits on bulky offense and balance teams that appreciate its role compression and ability to check to threats such as Zarude. Because Cobalion fills the role of a Stealth Rock setter, it allows teammates like Krookodile to run Choice Scarf and Nihilego to run Toxic Spikes; Krookodile deals with revenge killers like Azelf, while Nihilego handles Moltres and Salamence. Rotom-H and Moltres burn through checks like Amoonguss and Tangrowth for Cobalion and act as Defoggers so Cobalion can continue to act as a pivot. Both enjoy Cobalion deterring Knock Off and forming a VoltTurn core with them so they can provide a pivoting core for an offensive teammate like Lycanroc-D, which is also a solid revenge killer to threats such as Keldeo and Nidoking. Sylveon provides cleric support with Wish and Heal Bell while checking Keldeo and Salamence for it; in return, thanks to Sylveon's support, Cobalion is able to check Sylveon's answers like Jirachi and Nihilego more reliably throughout the match. Other Steel-types like Aegislash can pair up with Cobalion to circumvent its neutrality to Fairy and Flying, though this stacks weaknesses to Fire and Ground. Teammates such as Zarude and Azumarill deal with problematic Ground-types such as Zygarde-10% and Nidoking. Zarude is also great for its ability to check Aegislash, while Azumarill is able to revenge kill Rotom-H and Entei.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Swords Dance allows Cobalion to become a more significant threat, as +2 Close Combat 2HKOes Celesteela and OHKOes Rotom-W after Stealth Rock, while +2 Iron Head obliterates Hatterene and Sylveon and hits Amoonguss, Primarina, and Nidoking hard. Stone Edge is useful for KOing Moltres, preventing free setup from Gyarados, and OHKOing other threats such as Rotom-H and Chandelure after Swords Dance. Leftovers prevents Amoonguss from wearing down Cobalion as it sets up and also makes Cobalion a more reliable check to foes such as Chansey and Zarude. Safety Goggles is an option for teams that cannot afford having something put to sleep by Amoonguss's Spore, making it easier in general for Cobalion to set up on Amoonguss.

This set is more suited towards offense and bulky offense teams as a fast wallbreaker with defensive utility. Knock Off support from teammates such as Mamoswine and Seismitoad is appreciated to leave threats like Rotom-H and Salamence vulnerable to entry hazards, wearing them down into range of Cobalion's attacks; Mamoswine also breaks through Aegislash, while Seismitoad checks both Rotom-H and Rotom-W and provides Stealth Rock support to further weaken foes such as Celesteela. Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth provide utility with Spore and Knock Off and are also able to check special attackers such as Keldeo and Primarina. In return, Cobalion is able to break through opposing Amoonguss for them so they won't have to stall each other out. Cobalion cannot break through Aegislash and Buzzwole, so teammates such as Salamence and Chandelure are options. Salamence additionally provides Defog support and checks Choice Scarf Mienshao and Kommo-o, while Chandelure has a better matchup against Hatterene; both teammates appreciate Cobalion removing Nihilego and Rhyperior. Zarude helps break through bulky Water-types like Rotom-W and takes care of threats such as Krookodile and Zygarde-10%. In return, Zarude appreciates Cobalion removing Amoonguss. Rotom-W is also a good pivot for Safety Goggles Cobalion because it lures in Amoonguss to give Cobalion easy entry and setup.

Tornadus.overview: Tornadus's blistering Speed, high Special Attack, and powerful and diverse coverage make it a good setup sweeper in UU. Nasty Plot lets Tornadus boost its power even further and muscle through walls like Chansey and Celesteela. It shines mainly on rain teams, severely threatening the opposing team by spamming perfectly accurate Hurricanes. Rain also gives it reliable coverage for Rhyperior, Nihilego, and Rotom-H in Water-type Weather Ball. However, Tornadus's Hurricane is too unreliable to spam outside of rain. Tornadus also struggles to boost safely because of its terrible defenses, cannot consistently pressure foes like Primarina, fails to remove certain Flying-resistant Pokemon like Celesteela, and falls prey to threats like Nihilego, Raikou, and Lycanroc-D.
Tornadus.comments:
Other Options

Grass Knot can be run over Weather Ball to grant a more reliable hit on Krookodile, Rhyperior, and Gastrodon, but it fails to OHKO the former and makes Tornadus unable to hit Aegislash. A physical Defiant set with Acrobatics, Knock Off, U-turn, and Superpower without an item can be used to punish Intimidate users like Krookodile and Defoggers like Salamence. Acrobatics destroys Grass-types like Amoonguss and hits a lot of the tier extremely hard at +2. However, this set can't run Heavy-Duty Boots and gets worn down quite quickly by Stealth Rock. Tornadus can use utility moves like Defog and Taunt with Prankster to help its teammates, but it has very little bulk and longevity to consistently pull off these moves.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey easily takes multiple +2 Hurricanes and only fears +2 Focus Blast. Even then, the move fails to 2HKO it reliably, and Chansey can wear down Tornadus with Toxic + Seismic Toss or bring in a teammate with Teleport.

Rock-types: Lycanroc-D and Nihilego OHKO Tornadus with their Rock-type STAB attacks, and the latter can switch into it relatively comfortably if unboosted, but they have to be wary of Weather Ball in rain. Rhyperior can take an unboosted Focus Blast and OHKO Tornadus back, but it folds to Water-type Weather Ball and boosted Focus Blast.

Steel-types: Aegislash, Jirachi, and Celesteela can comfortably switch into Hurricane, really only fearing Tornadus's coverage moves. Aegislash hits Tornadus very hard with Shadow Ball, Jirachi can generate momentum with U-turn and bring in an answer to it, and Celesteela can take Hurricane very easily and heal back with Leech Seed.
