However, Lycanroc-D struggles to break through teams that run physically bulky threats such as Tangrowth, Swampert, and Skarmory. Its poor bulk also means it cannot come in on almost anything, so it requires pivot support to come in safely as well as occasional aggressive prediction on expected switches. Lycanroc-D is also very prone to wearing itself down with Life Orb recoil, limiting its staying presence on the field.
Lycanroc-Dusk.comments:
Other Options

Swords Dance is an option that allows Lycanroc-D to OHKO foes like Amoonguss and Tangrowth at +2; however, it can struggle to find many opportunities to set up safely. Drill Run is nice to give Lycanroc-D excellent Rock- and Ground-type neutral coverage, but the only notable Pokemon it hits super effectively is Colbur Berry Galarian Slowbro. A Focus Sash lead Lycanroc-D is able to use Endeavor while setting up Stealth Rock, but this is generally not worth it in comparison to its other, much more dynamic sets.

Checks and Counters

Grass-types: Amoonguss and Tapu Bulu do not switch into Stone Edge well, but they resist Close Combat and threaten Lycanroc-D after switching in; the former also runs Rocky Helmet often, which punishes Lycanroc-D. Tangrowth is the biggest offender, since unboosted Close Combat damage is restored nearly completely by Regenerator, it commonly uses Rocky Helmet, and it can freely threaten Lycanroc-D's team in multiple ways after it comes in. Choice Scarf Zarude takes Accelrock well and can OHKO it with Power Whip.

Steel-types: Skarmory's excellent physical bulk and reliable recovery lets it effortlessly wall Lycanroc-D unless significantly chipped. It also can wear Lycanroc-D down with Rocky Helmet. Choice Scarf Jirachi resists Lycanroc-D's Accelrock and can revenge kill it with Iron Head, only having to fear the rare Sucker Punch. Unless carrying the necessary coverage, Aegislash can safely pivot into Lycanroc-D multiple times and threaten to OHKO with either of its STAB moves. Aegislash can also remove Lycanroc-D if weakened into Shadow Sneak Range.

Water-types: Foes like Slowking, Primarina, and Swampert that don't fall to one hit and are capable of firing back with super effective attacks pose problems for Lycanroc-D, which has to be kept in reserve while its teammates wear them down. Starmie naturally outspeeds and can threaten Lycanroc-D, though it must be wary of its health to avoid being taken out by Accelrock. Azumarill and Crawdaunt can take an Accelrock from Lycanroc-D unless they are severely weakened and revenge kill it with Aqua Jet in return.

Revenge Killers: Choice Scarf users that are not in range of its priority are able to revenge kill Lycanroc-D due to its frailty; Mienshao, Diggersby, and Krookodile are all notable for their resistance to Accelerock and ability to OHKO Lycanroc-D with their STAB moves. Pokemon like Azumarill and Conkeldurr can revenge kill Lycanroc-D with their priority attacks.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
Stone Edge is a very spammable STAB move that can OHKO Rotom-H and Salamence while dealing heavy damage to neutral targets like Primarina. Alternatively, Psychic Fangs is an option that inflicts heavy damage on the likes of Amoonguss, Tentacruel, and Keldeo. However, most of the targets Psychic Fangs hits can be muscled through with Stone Edge after they have taken decent chip damage. Close Combat is a powerful coverage option that nails many Rock resistant Pokemon such as Keldeo, Krookodile, and Excadrill. Crunch hits Aegislash, Jirachi, and Galarian Slowbro harder. Accelerock is useful against offense teams, specifically keeping threats such Agility-boosted Galarian Moltres and Dragon Dance Salamence in check. It also makes Lycanroc-D more difficult to revenge kill with faster threats such as Venusaur in sun and Starmie. Sucker Punch can be used to deal more damage than Accelerock against neutral targets; however, it is only really useful for a better matchup against Choice Scarf Jirachi. A Life Orb is used to guarantee feats such as 2HKOing defensive Celesteela with Close Combat and Amoonguss with Stone Edge on the switch with Stealth Rock up. Maximum Speed investment with a Jolly nature is needed to make Lycanroc-D outspeed and threaten as many foes as it can, particularly Keldeo.

Lycanroc-D fits best on offensive teams that appreciate its ability to revenge kill common offensive threats such as Salamence without sacrificing its teammates' wallbreaking capabilities. As Lycanroc-D is unable to switch in on mostly anything, pivots are appreciated to give it opportunities to punch holes as often as possible and gain momentum; Moltres and Rotom-H are efficient at this and help pressure Skarmory and bulky Grass-types, which usually give Lycanroc-D grief. Swampert also acts as a pivot while providing entry hazard support to wear down Slowking, Tapu Bulu, and Tangrowth. Krookodile is another Stealth Rock setter that draws out Skarmory and Amoonguss to remove their Rocky Helmets with Knock Off. Special attackers such as Moltres and Primarina appreciate Lycanroc-D's ability to break through Chansey, and in return they can help wear down common physically defensive threats such as Skarmory for it. The Grass-types of the tier like Tangrowth and Zarude are excellent partners to handle threats such as Azumarill. Additionally, they also check faster Pokemon Lycanroc-D cannot threaten as much with its priority, such as Zygarde-10%. Early-game wallbreakers like Thundurus-T and Aegislash can pave the way for a Lycanroc-D sweep by weakening foes like Skarmory and Amoonguss for it.

Tapu Bulu.overview: Tapu Bulu is a decent wallbreaker that provides defensive utility to its team with passive recovery through its Grassy Surge. Tapu Bulu has a great movepool with coverage options like Close Combat, Zen Headbutt, and Stone Edge, which break through potential checks such as Celesteela, Amoonguss, and Moltres. Furthermore, its decent defensive typing, speed, and ability in Grassy Terrain allows it to distinguish itself from other bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth by being a more reliable check to Keldeo and Azumarill as well as enable threats like SubToxic Aegislash, though it does have to be wary of the former crippling it with a Scald burn and hitting it with Choice Specs-boosted Air Slash or Icy Wind. While Tapu Bulu's typing has many useful resistances, it comes at the cost of having a lot of weaknesses to common attacking types like Fire, Ice, and Poison, meaning it struggles against staples like Entei, Mamoswine, Nidoking, and even Kommo-o due to its tendency to run Poison Jab. The tier has an abundance of defensive checks to Tapu Bulu, such as Salamence, Amoonguss, and Aegislash, which makes it difficult for Tapu Bulu to make much progress as a wallbreaker, especially when multiple of these checks are naturally found on the same team. Despite its positive traits compared to Amoonguss and Tangrowth, they still outclass it as a defensive Grass-type due to their access to Regenerator and less vulnerable typing. Furthermore, Tapu Bulu's Grassy Terrain also heals up the opponent's Pokemon as well, sometimes making it a hindrance to teams it is on.
Tapu Bulu.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band is an option that gives Tapu Bulu even more power; however, it requires a lot more prediction to break through its checks like Amoonguss, and Wood Hammer recoil can wear it down quickly. A Choice Scarf set can be used to revenge kill foes like Thundurus and Noivern; however, it primarily relies on surprise factor to do so. A specially defensive Tapu Bulu set with Horn Leech / Darkest Lariat / Synthesis and either Bulk Up or Swords Dance can be used as a better switch-in to foes like Keldeo and Thundurus-T. However, this set is a huge momentum drain against foes like Amoonguss, Kommo-o, and Celesteela. An Assault Vest set improves its matchup against the aforementioned foes while retaining an offensive presence; however, it can be easily overwhelmed by special attackers such as Primarina.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Chandelure is a relatively safe switch-in to Tapu Bulu's most spammable moves and threatens to OHKO it. Rotom-H has to be wary of taking Close Combat; however, it can threaten to OHKO with Overheat and use Tapu Bulu as a free Volt Switch or Defog opportunity. Moltres has to be wary of Stone Edge but otherwise freely switches into Tapu Bulu and threatens to burn it with Flame Body or KO it with a STAB move.

Steel-types: Many of UU's more common Steel-types like Celesteela and Jirachi only take neutral damage from Close Combat and threaten to KO Tapu Bulu. Aegislash can comfortably stomach any hit in Shield forme and OHKO it in return.

Poison-types: Nihilego and Nidoking outspeed and OHKO Tapu Bulu with their Poison-type STAB. Without Darkest Lariat, Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro sets up on it with ease. Amoonguss threatens to OHKO Tapu Bulu with Sludge Bomb, though it has to be wary of +2 Zen Headbutt.

Physical Walls: Physically defensive Tangrowth stomachs any attack barring a +2 Megahorm and OHKOes Tapu Bulu with Sludge Bomb. Salamence is a huge issue for Tapu Bulu, as it resists the coverage it commonly carries and pressures it with Flying-type attacks, though it has to be wary of Stone Edge. Intimidate makes it much easier for Salamence to stomach any hit from Tapu Bulu. Defensive Buzzwole can stomach any attack and KO Tapu Bulu with Poison Jab.

sets.name: Swords Dance
sets.description:
Horn Leech is the preferred STAB option thanks to its recovery and respectable damage. Stone Edge is crucial coverage to break past Pokemon like Chandelure, Moltres, and Salamence. Close Combat lets Tapu Bulu break through Cobalion and hit other Steel-types like Jirachi and Celesteela harder; however, dropping Stone Edge leaves it unable to punish the common Flying-types, particularly Moltres, which can fish for a burn with Flame Body. Zen Headbutt breaks through Amoonguss, Kommo-o, and Buzzwole. Megahorn can help against Tangrowth; however, its coverage isn't very useful otherwise. Darkest Lariat can be used to hit Pokemon like Jirachi, Aegislash, and Chandelure harder. Life Orb with an Adamant nature gives +2 Tapu Bulu the extra power needed to KO foes like Tangrowth and Celesteela. A Jolly nature can be used to outspeed Buzzwole and Timid Volcanion, though Adamant's power is generally valued more.

Tapu Bulu fits best on offense and balance teams that appreciate its combination of utility and wallbreaking potential. Rotom-W can lure in foes like Seismitoad, giving Tapu Bulu free opportunities to use Swords Dance. Rotom-W can also remove foes like Moltres and wear down Kommo-o and Amoonguss into KO range of Tapu Bulu's attacks. Other wallbreakers like Conkeldurr and Nidoking can help break through defensive cores that Tapu Bulu struggles with. Keldeo appreciates Tapu Bulu being able to lure in and remove bulky Grass-types like Amoonguss and Tangrowth. Tentacruel is appreciated as another Water-resistant Pokemon, as Tapu Bulu doesn't want to risk a burn from Keldeo's Scald, for example. Although Tapu Bulu is a Fairy-type, it struggles to consistently check a majority of Dragon-types, such as Salamence and Kommo-o, due to its lack of a good Fairy-type attack and its weakness to their common coverage. For this reason, partners like Celesteela and Aegislash are imperative.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Horn Leech allows Tapu Bulu to gain recovery while still having a strong move to hit Primarina, Crawdaunt, and Lycanroc-D. Dazzling Gleam is able to sometimes OHKO Kommo-o and deals good damage to Zarude and Buzzwole. Toxic punishes switch-ins such as Rotom-H and Salamence. Synthesis is reliable recovery, but it should only be used sparingly due to its low PP. Heavy-Duty Boots is the preferred item, but Rocky Helmet can be used to punish contact moves from Zarude, Krookodile, and Gyarados. The EV spread is to outspeed Choice Specs Primarina while maximizing physical bulk to better check Buzzwole and Lycanroc-D.

Defensive Tapu Bulu is mainly found on stall and balance teams, as they appreciate it bringing Grassy Terrain for extra recovery. Calm Mind Galarian Slowbro and SubToxic Aegislash are great partners, as they can deal with Amoonguss and Togekiss, respectively. In return, Tapu Bulu is able to handle Krookodile, Rhyperior, Zarude, and Crawdaunt for these Pokemon. Chansey is able to check non-Dragon Dance Salamence and other special attackers such as Nidoking and Nihilego; Tapu Bulu beats Keldeo, one of the few special attackers that can break through Chansey. Umbreon provides Wish support so that Tapu Bulu does not have to use Synthesis often while also checking Salamence and Aegislash. Fire-types such as Entei and Moltres help deal with Jirachi, Amoonguss, and Aegislash, which wall it.

Nihilego.overview: Nihilego stands out as a great utility Pokmon that also boasts high offensive stats. Its good STAB combination hits key Pokemon such as Thundurus-T, Salamence, Tangrowth, and Primarina super effectively. It has important resistances like Flying, Fairy, and Fire; its Flying resistance and high Special Defense in particular are appreciated by teams that struggle with Flying-types like Thundurus-T and Galarian Moltres. Nihilego is an amazing Stealth Rock setter, as its resistances give very good matchups against Defoggers such as Salamence, Moltres, and Rotom-H. Its Knock Off is useful for common switch-ins like Chansey, Aegislash, and Celesteela. It can use Meteor Beam as well to boost its Special Attack and become a fierce sweeper. Its unique Speed tier puts it ahead of Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Moltres, and after a Speed boost from Beast Boost, it only falls behind Choice Scarf Zarude and Choice Scarf Mienshao. However, its weaknesses and horrid Defense stat leave it vulnerable to Pokemon such as Nidoking, Jirachi, and Keldeo, and priority from the likes of Conkeldurr, Azumarill, and Crawdaunt easily shuts down its sweeps. It lacks room for coverage for Pokemon like Nidoking, and it just cannot get past checks like Jirachi and Aegislash.
Nihilego.comments:
Other Options

Toxic Spikes is a secondary entry hazard option that weakens defensive staples like Assault Vest Tangrowth and cripples Substitute users such as Primarina and Raikou. However, Poison-types remove it and a large portion of the metagame is immune to it, like Rotom-H, Salamence, Celesteela, and Aegislash. A Choice Scarf set with Power Gem / Sludge Wave / Thunderbolt / Grass Knot lets Nihilego clean through teams and revenge kill Pokemon like Keldeo and other Choice Scarf users like Krookodile, but Choice-locked Nihilego is vulnerable to Pokemon like Aegislash and Azumarill. Pain Split can be considered as a form of recovery on the utility set, but it is very unreliable due to Nihilego's high HP and can only be used against special attackers that can't hurt it much. Dazzling Gleam OHKOes Kommo-o and maintains coverage for Krookodile but has no use outside of that. Psychic hits Kommo-o, opposing Nihilego, and Nidoking, but just like Dazzling Gleam, it is not worth running most times.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Chansey is Nihilego's best answer, capable of wearing it down with Seismic Toss and healing itself with Soft-Boiled. As long as Chansey doesn't let it accumulate several boosts, it can always beat Nihilego. Chansey hates having its Eviolite removed, though.

Ground-types: Krookodile, Nidoking, Seismitoad, and Rhyperior don't care about Nihilego's STAB moves and can force it out of the field with their STAB Ground-type moves, but they have to be wary of Grass Knot and get crippled by Knock Off. Zygarde-10% outspeeds Nihilego and can OHKO it with Thousand Arrows.

Steel-types: Jirachi walls Nihilego easily and can scare it out with Iron Head and Thunder Wave. Cobalion can pivot into Nihilego's attacks and exploit its weak physical defense. Celesteela is capable of taking +1 Thunderbolt and OHKOing Nihilego back with Heavy Slam. Aegislash easily switches into even boosted Nihilego and can KO it with its Steel-type STAB move or revenge kill it with Shadow Sneak.

Faster Pokemon and Priority Users: Faster threats like Keldeo, Lycanroc-D, and Azelf all outspeed and threaten to OHKO Nihilego. However, these Pokemon must be wary of Nihilego getting a speed boost after getting a KO on its Meteor Beam set. Priority users like Azumarill and Crawdaunt can OHKO Nihilego with their priority moves.

sets.name: Stealth Rock Utility
sets.description:
Nihilego's typing allows it to switch into a majority of the tier's Defoggers, including Salamence and Moltres, and set Stealth Rock. Power Gem threatens many Defoggers and hits neutral targets Sludge Wave can't, like Galarian Slowbro and Celesteela. Sludge Wave threatens Pokemon such as Tangrowth and Primarina. Knock Off cripples checks to Nihilego like Aegislash, Chansey, and Celesteela. It's also great for removing Heavy-Duty Boots from Defoggers. Grass Knot eliminates Pokemon that don't mind Power Gem + Sludge Wave, like Seismitoad and Rhyperior. However, the utility Knock Off provides is amazing, and it's only worth replacing if Nihilego's team has enough other Knock Off users. Protect scouts Choice-locked foes like Krookodile, Zarude, and Keldeo, letting Nihilego switch to the appropriate teammate. It also lets Nihilego accumulate recovery from Black Sludge and stall weather and Toxic turns. Black Sludge mitigates entry hazards and chip damage.

This set fits on every playstyle, except hyper offense. Nihilego's team appreciates its good defensive typing and Knock Off, and its offensive capabilities are valuable for removing threats like Primarina and Salamence. Stall in particular appreciates Nihilego's good matchup against Nasty Plot Togekiss. Setup sweepers such as Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Keldeo love Nihilego setting up Stealth Rock and weakening their checks like Assault Vest Tangrowth, Amoonguss, and Celesteela. Teammates like Azelf, Krookodile, and Tangrowth provide Knock Off support, giving Nihilego the option of running Grass Knot. Amoonguss and Buzzwole can check physical threats to Nihilego like Krookodile and Mienshao, while Nihilego checks Fire-types like Moltres. Aegislash has notable defensive synergy with Nihilego, as it checks Pokemon like Galarian Slowbro, Lycanroc-D, and Kommo-o. Moltres and Rotom-H deal with Steel-types that wall Nihilego, like Aegislash and Jirachi. Chansey completely walls this set even after having its Eviolite removed, so wallbreakers like Lycanroc-D and Buzzwole should take care of it. Nihilego in return can take out physically defensive Tangrowth and Salamence.

sets.name: Meteor Beam Sweeper
sets.description:
Meteor Beam is Nihilego's most important move, boosting Special Attack and muscling past checks like Celesteela once they're chipped. Sludge Wave hits tier staples like Primarina, Tangrowth, and Kommo-o. Thunderbolt allows Nihilego to hit Steel-types like Jirachi and Aegislash neutrally and other checks like Celesteela and Milotic super effectively. Power Gem can be used in place of Thunderbolt for a more reliable hit on Pokemon like Salamence, Thundurus-T, and Galarian Moltres. Grass Knot deals with Ground-types like Krookodile and Rhyperior. Power Herb is required for Meteor Beam. The given EV spread and a Timid nature make Speed Nihilego's highest stat for Beast Boost, letting it outspeed revenge killers like Keldeo and Choice Scarf Krookodile.

This set fits on hyper offense teams, where Nihilego can KO weakened checks like Celesteela with Meteor Beam to boost both its Speed and Special Attack. Entry hazard setters like Krookodile and Klefki help Nihilego by weakening some of its checks, like Nidoking and Celesteela, with the former setting Stealth Rock and the latter setting Spikes. Belly Drum Azumarill and Keldeo are extremely strong wallbreakers that can punch holes for Nihilego to sweep late-game. They destroy Chansey, Celesteela, and Ground-types like Rhyperior, Nidoking, and Krookodile. Fighting-type Pokemon and coverage like Buzzwole and Lycanroc-D's Close Combat remove Chansey; in return, Nihilego removes Salamence and Moltres for Buzzwole, and it wears down Aegislash and threatens Buzzwole for Lycanroc-D. Galarian Moltres can break past or dent Nidoking and Steel-types like Jirachi, Aegislash, and Celesteela. In return, Nihilego can remove Thundurus and Thundurus-T. Indeedee-F can provide Psychic Terrain to prevent Nihilego from being revenge killed by Aqua Jet from Azumarill and Crawdaunt. It can also patch up Nihilego with Healing Wish.

Celesteela.overview: Celesteela's typing and defensive stats are both fantastic, allowing it to check a considerable portion of UU's top threats, including Salamence, Jirachi, Nihilego, and Excadrill. Thanks to its decent offensive stats, powerful STAB Heavy Slam, and access to Flamethrower to smack foes like Aegislash and Zarude, Celesteela can prevent itself from being too passive. Leech Seed is also an excellent tool, sustaining Celesteela's longevity and allowing it to significantly wear down its switch-ins, such as Rotom-H and Thundurus-T, potentially forcing them out. Autotomize sets are also a strong option, tapping into Celesteela's strong special coverage and the sweeping potential Beast Boost lends it. Despite its defensive potency, however, Celesteela suffers a bit from its lack of access to reliable recovery, which can prevent it from tanking strong neutral hits as consistently as it would like to and cause it to be overreliant on Leftovers. This can allow a few common Pokemon, such as Mienshao and Mamoswine, to muscle past Celesteela after relatively minimal chip damage. Celesteela also struggles to bypass popular Fire- and Electric-types such as Moltres and Rotom-W on its own, as well as various defensive picks like Tentacruel and Slowking; Tentacruel can utilize Liquid Ooze to take advantage of Leech Seed, while Slowking doesn't take meaningful damage from any of Celesteela's attacks, can absorb Leech Seed and Teleport out, and can threaten to chip Celesteela down with burns from Scald.
Celesteela.comments:
Other Options

Celesteela's physical movepool contains solid options like Earthquake and Stone Edge, which allow it to run a physically based Autotomize set, effectively luring checks like Tentacruel and Rotom-H. However, this generally isn't as effective due to Celesteela's middling immediate power and hardships breaking various Pokemon, such as Tangrowth and Intimidate Krookodile. Earthquake is an option in the fourth slot of the defensive set to still hit Steel-types super effectively while also hitting Tentacruel hard. However, Flamethrower is usually way more valuable for its ability to pressure Zarude while still hitting Steel-types. Toxic cripples some of Celesteela's switch-ins on the defensive set, but it generally isn't as useful as its other options, and, due to foregoing either Protect, it notably makes Celesteela more susceptible to being worn down.

Checks and Counters

Fire-types: Fire-types like Moltres, Volcanion, Rotom-H, and Chandelure can pivot in on both Heavy Slam and Flamethrower and hit Celesteela hard with super effective STAB moves. They can also blanket check Celesteela's Autotomize set if it opts for Flash Cannon, though Meteor Beam can power through them. Moltres is particularly annoying, often being able to restore any chip damage it sustains from Leech Seed with Roost.

Electric-types: Electric-types like Thundurus-T, Rotom-W, and Toxtricity can tank hits from either of Celesteela's sets and proceed to break past it with super effective STAB attacks, though they all take fair damage from Meteor Beam.

Specially Defensive Pokemon: Chansey doesn't take major damage from Celesteela's attacks and can whittle it down with Seismic Toss or bring in a teammate with Teleport. Tentacruel's Liquid Ooze punishes Leech Seed attempts and it doesn't take major damage from any attack Celesteela commonly runs. If it is running Haze, it can also stint the Autotomize set's progress.

Knock Off: Celesteela's defensive set becomes far easier to wear down if Leftovers, its most reliable means of passive recovery, has been removed. Knock Off users like Mamoswine, Krookodile, and Nihilego can wear it down immensely as it tries potentially pivoting in on them. The Autotomize set is also often reliant on whichever item it is running to pose a significant offensive threat, which can prevent Celesteela from setting up on foes like Nihilego and Tangrowth as safely as it would like to at times.

Strong Wallbreakers: Celesteela's lack of reliable recovery allows particularly powerful wallbreakers, including Primarina, Mamoswine, and Aegislash, to quickly overwhelm it.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Flamethrower hits Steel-types like Aegislash and Excadrill, preventing them from reliably setting up on Celesteela, while also hitting Grass-types such as Tangrowth and Zarude, which are immune to Leech Seed. Leech Seed is important to wear down common switch-ins, including Moltres, Rotom-W, and Thundurus-T. It also prevents Pokemon like Gyarados and Dragon Dance Salamence from reliably setting up on Celesteela, chipping them down. Protect works well alongside Leech Seed, offering Celesteela a guaranteed opportunity to restore health with both Leftovers and Leech Seed. It can also help to scout moves from Choice-locked Pokemon, like Chandelure and Primarina.

Celesteela is a solid fit on balance teams thanks to its ability to check several prominent threats, allowing offensive teammates to fall back on it upon losing momentum to foes like Salamence and Noivern. Bulky Water-types often share strong synergy with Celesteela, checking the Fire-types that power through it, while Celesteela can handle Pokemon like Zarude and Tapu Bulu in return. Swampert and Gastrodon check both Rotom-H and Rotom-W, two of Celesteela's more effective answers, while applying pressure to Moltres with STAB Scald. Slowking is another great partner that can bring Celesteela in safely with Teleport against foes such as Tapu Bulu and Hydreigon. Nihilego is another good teammate, pivoting in on Pokemon like Moltres and Thundurus-T for Celesteela while appreciating its ability to deal with Ground-types such as Excadrill and Nidoking. Defensive Grass-types like Tangrowth and Amoonguss can also make solid teammates, as they can pivot into threats to Celesteela like Keldeo, Azumarill, and Krookodile. They both can absorb Knock Off for Celesteela, and the former can use Knock Off itself to cripple switch-ins to Celesteela like Moltres. Zarude is another phenomonal partner capable of offensively pressuring Slowking better and revenge killing Thundurus-T.

sets.name: Autotomize
sets.description:
Autotomize allows Celesteela to outspeed the entire unboosted metagame and more easily snowball. It can find setup opportunities against a solid amount of common Pokemon that its defensive set forces out, including Zarude, Hatterene, and Nihilego. Fire Blast provides important coverage against Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi. Flamethrower is an option over Fire Blast for its greater accuracy. However, Celesteela wants all the power it can get due to this set's nature as a sweeper. Meteor Beam grants Celesteela an opportunity to bypass Fire-types like Rotom-H, Moltres, and Chandelure. It also deals massive damage to foes like Rotom-W, Thundurus-T, and Salamence, and the Special Attack boost it supplies is often extremely useful in boosting Celesteela's sweeping capabilities. Due to taking two turns, however, it must be used with Power Herb, and Celesteela must watch out for the opponent predicting the attack and bringing in a foe that resists it due to often being restricted to a one-time use. Flash Cannon is also an option in the fourth slot, offering more overall consistency and giving Celesteela a strong secondary STAB attack that deals decent neutral damage and hits Pokemon like Hatterene, Nihilego, and Rhyperior super effectively. Giga Drain is an option to bypass Quagsire, Rhyperior, and Rotom-W, which can otherwise tank various hits, though it generally doesn't provide too valuable of coverage otherwise. Beast Boost lets Celesteela boost its Special Attack upon netting KOs, giving it great sweeping potential. If Meteor Beam is not being run, Celesteela has no need for Power Herb and can then run Weakness Policy. This allows it to use its solid bulk to tank super effective hits, such as Fire-type moves from Salamence or opposing Celesteela, to gain a +2 boost in power, which heavily increases its threat level. This is particularly potent when Celesteela is behind dual screens, as often the only way to break past it at that rate is with super effective moves.

This set fits on offensive builds, acting as a late-game sweeper that cleans weakened teams. Hyper offense teams do particularly well supporting Celesteela, sometimes employing dual screens setters like Grimmsnarl to increase its odds of reliably setting up. Entry hazards let Celesteela muscle past foes like Rotom-W more easily, making setters like Excadrill good options for teammates. On hyper offense teams, leads like Froslass work well for its ability to quickly set Spikes and keep up momentum with Destiny Bond, respectively. Powerful wallbreakers like Mienshao and Conkeldurr make strong teammates capable of removing foes such as Slowking and Chansey for Celesteela to sweep through late-game. Depending on the coverage it opts for, Celesteela will struggle to reliably break past various Pokemon. If it isn't running Meteor Beam, checks to Fire-types like Azumarill and Gyarados are great teammates, easily being able to pressure Rotom-H and Moltres. Without Flash Cannon, Celesteela can't hit Rock-types like Rhyperior and Nihilego super effectively, making Pokemon like Zygarde-10% and the aforementioned Azumarill solid partners. Lastly, sweepers like Thundurus-T and Aegislash often fit well with offensive Celesteela, helping pressure the likes of Slowking and Chansey.

Necrozma.overview: Necrozma is a solid sweeper in UU thanks to its offensive versatility, allowing it to bypass traditional answers like Chansey and Celesteela with its unpredictability. Its Dragon Dance set is a strong sweeper, powering through metagame staples like Slowking and Amoonguss. On the other hand, its Meteor Beam set is equally as potent, allowing it to lure in and slam answers to the Dragon Dance set like Celesteela and Mandibuzz. Necrozma's high natural bulk and Prism Armor allow it to set up on many Pokemon like Nihilego and take super effective hits from threats like Lycanroc-D and even Aegislash. Necrozma also has a solid matchup against common entry hazard removers like Salamence and Tentacruel, letting it act as an offensive Stealth Rock setter capable of supporting its team. However, Necrozma heavily dislikes status from threats like Chansey and Aegislash, which limits its chance to sweep. Necrozma is also limited by the number of Dark-types in the tier like Zarude, Mandibuzz, Hydreigon, and Galarian Moltres, which can all hinder at least one of its sets. Overreliance on Power Herb on Necrozma's Meteor Beam set makes it hard to pull off a sweep at times with Pokemon like Hydreigon and Slowking being common, while the Dragon Dance set can be worn down it accumulates multiple boosts.
Necrozma.comments:
Other Options

Necrozma can run a Calm Mind + Moonlight set thanks to its great bulk, allowing it to be a strong late-game sweeper. However, Necrozma is walled by Hydreigon, Mandibuzz, and Slowking who can all wear it down or pivot out into a strong revenge killer like Zarude. Necrozma can run Expanding force over Photon Geyser on its Meteor Beam set on Psychic Terrain teams for more devastating damage, but the limited viability of the playstyle and reliance on Terrain being active make Photon Geyser the preferred option. A final option is a Stored Power set with Cosmic Power or Calm Mind to boost Necrozma's stats, but it lacks the dangerous immediate sweeping potential of Necrozma's other sets and can be inconsistent at times.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Choice Scarf Hydreigon and Zarude can easily revenge kill Necrozma, even at +1 Speed from Dragon Dance. However, if Necrozma uses Autotomize, it can threaten them before they attack. Still, Hydreigon forces Necrozma to conserve its Power Herb as it can take advantage of Meteor Beam requring two turns. Umbreon can tank hits from all sets and cripple it with Toxic. Although they must watch out for Meteor Beam, both Mandibuzz and Galarian Moltres can take on Necrozma.

Special Walls: Special walls like Chansey, Slowking, and Assault Vest Reuniclus can take on the Meteor Beam set with ease. However, they must watch out for the Dragon Dance set. Celesteela walls the Dragon Dance set and can take a boosted Heat Wave while wearing down Necrozma with Leech Seed, but it can get overwhelmed easily. Hatterene can take boosted attacks from Necrozma and lower its Special Attack with Mystical Fire.

Status: Status is detrimental to Necrozma's attempts to sweep, so moves like Thunder Wave from Togekiss, Scald from Slowking, and Toxic from Aegislash, Excadrill, and Chansey greatly hinder it.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance boosts Necrozma's Attack to incredible levels, letting it power through Pokemon like Swampert, Primarina, and Moltres. X-Scissor OHKOes Zarude and deals great damage to Krookodile, Slowking, and Tangrowth. Heat Wave prevents Celesteela and Skarmory from walling Necrozma and also hits Steel-types like Excadrill. Alternatively, Earthquake can be used to reliably beat other Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi. Since Prism Armor lets Necrozma take weak super effective hits like Knock Off from Nihilego with ease, Necrozma can employ a Weakness Policy to get a huge boost to its Attack. Alternatively, with a Lum Berry, Necrozma can set up on Pokemon like Amoonguss, Rotom-W, and Slowking, which would normally stay in to cripple it with status. Naughty is the preferred nature, since Necrozma outspeeds the entire unboosted metagame barring Choice Scarf users like Mienshao after a Dragon Dance and prefers to not lower its Special Attack to boost the power of Heat Wave.

Necrozma best fits on offense teams as a late-game cleaner once its answers have been removed. Celesteela is problematic for this particular set, so powerful wallbreakers like Thundurus-T can remove it. Thundurus-T also beats Mandibuzz and helps wear down walls like Aegislash, Chansey, and Primarina for Necrozma to bypass them more easily. Sticky Web support from Ribombee help offset Necrozma's average Speed tier, allowing it to outspeed Choice Scarf users like Mienshao and Zarude after a Dragon Dance. Other entry hazard support from Pokemon like Excadrill and Roserade wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Hatterene. Zarude and the aforementioned Excadrill can also check Aegislash, a Pokemon Necrozma struggles with if it is healthy. Dark-type checks like Primarina and Azumarill make great partners for Necrozma, beating threats like Umbreon, Krookodile, and Galarian Moltres. Psychic Terrain support from Indeedee-F allows Necrozma to boost its damage output without fearing priority from Azumarill or Lycanroc-D if weakened. It also can provide Healing Wish support to patch up Necrozma, allowing it to sweep later in the game.

sets.name: Meteor Beam
sets.description:
In conjunction with Power Herb, Meteor Beam is a powerful attack capable of wiping out Pokemon like Salamence, Galarian Moltres, and Thundurus-T while simultaneously giving Necrozma a boost to its Special Attack in one turn. Since Power Herb is single use, it should be saved until special walls like Chansey and Slowking are gone. Photon Geyser is Necrozma's primary move to power through many Pokemon like Keldeo and Amoonguss. It is also able to ignore abilities like Quagsire's Unaware. Heat Wave melts Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi as well as Grass-types like Zarude and Tangrowth. It is also Necrozma's most reliable option for damaging Krookodile and Hatterene. Autotomize lets Necrozma boost its Speed to outpace the fastest Choice Scarf users in Zarude and Mienshao. Alternatively, Necrozma can utilize Stealth Rock to act as an entry hazard setter for its team thanks to its good matchup against common entry hazard removers like Salamence and Rotom-H. Modest is the preferred nature to maximize damage output, since after an Autotomize, Necrozma outspeeds the fastest Choice Scarf users. Even if Stealth Rock is chosen, Modest is still preferred, since Necrozma doesn't miss out on many important Speed tiers.

This set also fits on offense teams as a powerful late-game sweeper. Entry hazard support from Pokemon like Excadrill wears down Pokemon like Celesteela and Hatterene for Necrozma to break through them more easily and allows Necrozma to drop Stealth Rock for Autotomize. Excadrill can also beat special walls like Assault Vest Galarian Slowbro and cripple Slowking and Mandibuzz with Toxic. Early-game wallbreakers like Belly Drum Azumarill, Swords Dance Aegislash, and Nasty Plot Thundurus-T can muscle through special walls like Chansey and Slowking for Necrozma. Mienshao can bring in Necrozma on Pokemon it can set up on like Amoonguss and Galarian Weezing while also threatening Umbreon, Hydreigon, and Chansey for Necrozma. Sticky Web support from Ribombee help offset Necrozma's average Speed tier, allowing it to forego Autotomize for Stealth Rock if the team needs to as well as outspeed and remove threats like Keldeo and Lycanroc-D.

Toxtricity.overview: Toxtricity carries a unique niche in UU as a fearsome Electric-type wallbreaker that isn't shut down by the tier's Grass- and Ground-types. Thanks to Punk Rock and Boomburst, Toxtricity is able to deal heavy damage to walls like Amoonguss, Tangrowth, and Rhyperior and maintain pressure on Pokemon that resist its STAB combination, such as Nidoking and Swampert. In addition, Toxtricity has a relatively decent defensive typing, allowing it to come in on Iron Head from Jirachi and Close Combat from Cobalion and threaten to 2HKO them. It can also pivot into various passive Pokemon such as Togekiss and Amoonguss. Despite Toxtricity's middling Speed, Shift Gear can allow it to outpace foes like Keldeo, Salamence, and even Choice Scarf Krookodile, making it a great late-game cleaner on offensive teams. However, Toxtricity's STAB attacks and Boomburst have immunities, making it a prediction-reliant wallbreaker that struggles to break through cores like Aegislash + Excadrill. Although Toxtricity's base 75 Speed is enough to outspeed the bulkier threats it is able to deal with, its bulk leaves it prey to revenge killers such as Thundurus-T, Excadrill, and Krookodile. Additionally, priority users such as Azumarill, Lycanroc-D, and Mamoswine can all halt a sweep by KOing a chipped Toxtricity. Toxtricity faces stiff competition as an offensive Poison- or Electric-type with Nihilego and Thundurus-T, which offer better coverage and Speed.
Toxtricity.comments:
Other Options

Choice Scarf turns Toxtricity into a revenge killer that is able to outpace threats such as Keldeo and Azelf while still having a Special Attack-boosting nature. Throat Spray is an option on Shift Gear sets, as long as Sludge Bomb or Sludge Wave is used over Drain Punch.

Checks and Counters

Chansey: Although it must be wary of Shift Gear sets with Drain Punch, Chansey can stand in the way of Toxtricitys strongest offensive moves with ease. It can heal itself with Soft-Boiled as Toxtricty switches out, keep momentum with Teleport, and spread status with Toxic or Thunder Wave.

Psychic-types: Assault Vest Reuniclus and Galarian Slowbro can directly counter Toxtricity, as they can comfortably switch into Boomburst and force Toxtricity to switch out. Furthermore, their ability Regenerator allows them to heal off most of Boombursts damage and lets them consistently switch into Toxtricity. Azelf is faster than Toxtricity and threatens to OHKO it with Psyshock.

Ground-types: Rhyperior, Excadrill, and Krookodile are immune to Overdrive and threaten to KO Toxtricity with their STAB attacks. The former two, though resistant to Boomburst, are easily worn down by it due to its lack of recovery, and the latter risks an OHKO from it.

Faster Pokemon: Although they must be careful around Shift Gear sets, Toxtricity's low Speed and poor natural bulk leave it prey to Pokemon that outspeed it naturally, such as Hydreigon, Keldeo, Salamence, and Lycanroc-D. The latter can even use Accelerock to stop a weakened Toxtricity from sweeping with Shift Gear.

sets.name: Offensive
sets.description:
Boomburst is the most powerful move on this set, heavily damaging Ground-types such as Quagsire, Swampert, and Krookodile for heavy damage and wearing down switch-ins without recovery like Excadrill. Despite not receiving the Punk Rock boost, Sludge Wave can still power through Fairy- and Grass-types such as Tapu Bulu, Primarina, and Tangrowth. Sludge Bomb is a viable alternative over Sludge Wave to poison and wear down switch-ins like Rhyperior and Swampert. Volt Switch is Toxtricitys way of generating momentum against threats that Toxtricity cannot break through, like Chansey. Heavy-Duty Boots prevent Toxtricity from being worn down by entry hazards. A Life Orb can be used to increase its firepower but the recoil hinders its longevity. A Modest nature is preferred to guarantee the 2HKO on Amoonguss and pressure Aegislash better, but a Timid nature can be used to outpace Adamant Gyarados and Mamoswine.

Toxtricity fits on bulky offense teams as a potent wallbreaker and is most useful in the early- to mid-game, where it can force out bulky threats such as Mandibuzz, Celesteela, and Tangrowth and punch huge holes in the opposing team. Toxtricity appreciates entry hazard support from setters such as Jirachi and Roserade to punish and accumulate chip damage on vulnerable checks such as Excadrill. Toxtricity can compliment these entry hazard setters by threatening to 2HKO entry hazard removers like Tentacruel and Salamence. Additionally, Toxtricity appreciates Pokemon that can threaten to KO and force out specially defensive walls. Keldeo is a prime example of a wallbreaker that excels at dealing with Ground-types and forcing out Chansey thanks to Secret Sword. Pokemon that resist Ground-type attacks, such as Tangrowth and Zarude, make great partners. Zarudes U-turn, combined with Toxtricity's ability to break its checks, yields another VoltTurn core that Toxtricity benefits from.

sets.name: Shift Gear
sets.description:
Shift Gear grants Toxtricity the ability to contend with would-be threats that are faster than it, such as Keldeo and Choice Scarf Krookodile, after a boost. Boomburst 2HKOes Ground-types like Gastrodon and Nidoking and OHKOes Krookodile. Drain Punch allows Toxtricity to defeat its greatest counter in Chansey by healing enough to offset Seismic Toss damage. Drain Punch is also useful to pick off weakened foes and keep Toxtricity healthy. Life Orb gives Toxtricity the immediate damage it needs to secure 2HKOs on specially defensive Amoonguss and Assault Vest Tangrowth after entry hazard damage. A Rash nature is preferred to secure 2HKOs on the aforementioned Grass-types, but a Naive nature can be used to outspeed fast Choice Scarf users such as Jirachi and Mienshao.

Shift Gear turns Toxtricity into a terrifying late-game sweeper that fits best on hyper offense archetypes. Toxtricity appreciates help from wallbreakers such as Keldeo and Aegislash taking care of threats such as Rhyperior and Chansey to help it sweep late-game. Additionally, entry hazard setters such as Krookodile and Excadrill help to accumulate chip damage on its checks, allowing Toxtricity to secure KOs on Swampert, Hydreigon, and Necrozma. Dragon Dance Salamence appreciates Toxtricity's ability to break through Celesteela and Tangrowth and can sweep late-game once its checks are dealt with. In return it can switch into Ground-type attacks. Priority moves like Azumarill's Aqua Jet can heavily damage Toxtricity or halt a sweep, making Gyarados and Rotom-W useful to have alongside Toxtricity. Jirachi resists Psychic and has U-turn to get Toxtricity safely into battle on a forced switch and preserve its HP, which is valuable due to Life Orb recoil. Jirachi can also provide Healing Wish support to give Toxtricity another chance to clean.

Polteageist.overview: Polteageist's primary role in the UU metagame is as a late-game sweeper; with support to eliminate its weaknesses to priority moves and Dark-types, it becomes a premier offensive threat. Shell Smash and powerful coverage options like Giga Drain and Stored Power make it a threatening setup sweeper that can easily OHKO much of the tier. However, Polteageist's frail defensive stats means it needs significant team support to truly be a consistent threat; while it's a powerful sweeper, it's still a predictable one due to having only one viable set, unlike other setup sweepers such as Necrozma and Kommo-o. Additionally, Polteageist struggles to break through Dark-types like Zarude and Galarian Moltres. The potential upside of using Polteageist is huge, but its weakness to entry hazards and priority alongside its inability to break through several common metagame threats can easily hamper its success. Polteageist works best with Psychic Terrain support to neutralize its weakness to priority, and while it can succeed with dual screens support, there are several other setup sweepers that require less support and are easier to justify.
Polteageist.comments:
Other Options

White Herb can be used in place of Focus Sash to restore the reduced defenses from Shell Smash, making Polteageist less immediately weak to priority moves like Lycanroc-D's Accelerock. Hyper Beam can be run as a nuke to nearly always OHKO Zarude while retaining the ability to OHKO Krookodile, but it's situational and leaves Polteageist open to being set up on or revenge killed.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Dark-types like Zarude, Galarian Moltres, and Incineroar, can all stomach a boosted Shadow Ball with ease, and immunity to Stored Power means they need to be weakened significantly before Polteageist can break through them. Additionally, Galarian Moltres can use Polteageist as setup fodder.

Priority Moves: Without Psychic Terrain support, Polteageist is extremely vulnerable to priority. Defense drops from Weak Armor and Shell Smash combined with its poor defensive stats means that common priority users like Aegislash, Lycanroc-D, and Crawdaunt can easily OHKO it.

Entry Hazards: Entry hazards break Polteageist's Focus Sash on entry, making it harder to set up, while Sticky Web prevents it from outspeeding common speed control Pokemon it otherwise would, like Choice Scarf Zarude, Barraskewda, and Choice Scarf Krookodile.

Specially Defensive Walls: Polteageist can boost past Chansey and overwhelm it, but other special walls like Umbreon, Celesteela, and Assault Vest Tangrowth can easily check it. However, Psychic Terrain lets Polteageist muscle past Celesteela after two Shell Smash boosts.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
Stored Power takes advantage of Shell Smash and Weak Armor boosts to boost its Base Power, and it provides powerful coverage. Giga Drain offers important coverage against threats like Krookodile and allows Polteageist to recover HP, eliminating entry hazard and chip damage and restoring the usefulness of a nullified Focus Sash. Weak Armor further boosts Polteageist's Speed past threats like Timid Venusaur in sun and Adamant Barraskewda in rain, and it boosts Stored Power even further.

Psychic Terrain blocks common priority moves like Lycanroc-D's Accelerock and Mamoswine's Ice Shard and prevents them from revenge killing Polteageist. It also boosts Stored Power, allowing Polteageist to OHKO Pokemon like bulky Salamence that would otherwise tank a hit and OHKO in return. As such, Indeedee-F is a perfect partner: it sets up Psychic Terrain on the switch, it can help lure in and weaken threats like Zarude, and it can offer last-ditch support with Healing Wish. On Psychic Terrain builds, Necrozma can help weaken opposing Dark-types for Polteageist and Nihilego can work along with Polteageist as an effective sweeper. Entry hazard setters like Kommo-o and Krookodile can help weaken enemy Pokemon to make sweeping easier. Stacking other offensive threats like Gyarados and Kommo-o to weaken checks like Zarude and Galarian Moltres can help overwhelm the opponent and clear a way for Polteageist to clean up late-game.

Hatterene.overview: Hatterene is an imposing Calm Mind user for defensive teams to deal with because its ability Magic Bounce deflects status moves such as Toxic and Thunder Wave, as well as phazing attempts. Hatterene's STAB moves complement each other brilliantly and, alongside Mystical Fire, give it good matchups against entry hazard setters such as Swampert and Skarmory to block their hazards with Magic Bounce and keep pressure off of its teammates. Hatterene's typing, while offensively potent, makes it a Fairy-type that's hit neutrally by Dark-type moves and a Psychic-type weak to Poison. This greatly impedes Hatterene's ability to consistently handle Pokemon such as Galarian Moltres and Hydreigon and makes it unreliable at pressuring Tentacruel and Nihilego. It also struggles to beat Steel-types such as Jirachi and Celesteela if it does not catch them with Mystical Fire on the switch. Without a Calm Mind boost, Hatterene noticeably lacks offensive presence, which can be taken advantage of by wallbreakers such as Diggersby and Choice Specs Primarina. While it does have some good matchups against some hazard setters, it also has poor ones, such as against Jirachi and Nidoqueen, so it can require prediction to make the most out of Magic Bounce. Excadrill is a hazard setter that not only forces out Hatterene but can completely ignore Magic Bounce thanks to Mold Breaker. Hatterene's dismal Speed tier greatly limits what it can accomplish against offensive teams.
Hatterene.comments:
Other Options

On Trick Room teams, Hatterene is an effective suicide lead with Focus Sash and Misty Explosion. Magic Bounce denies entry hazards from everything bar Excadrill, and using Misty Explosion right after Trick Room gives a safe entry point for teammates such as Crawdaunt with three turns of Trick Room still remaining. Hatterene can also be an offensive threat in Trick Room with Life Orb, but this sacrifices a lot of consistency in defensive utility because of its need for Special Attack investment and Life Orb recoil. Assault Vest alongside Nuzzle is an option to make Hatterene more bulky without a boost while still crippling the likes of Aegislash and Jirachi, but it faces stiff competition from Reuniclus, which has more consistent healing with Regenerator and better bulk to handle threats such as Keldeo.

Checks and Counters

Powerful Wallbreakers: Hatterene's poor Speed, lack of consistent recovery, and reliance on a Calm Mind boost to be a consistent threat makes it easy for Pokemon such as Mamoswine, Diggersby, and Crawdaunt to revenge kill it.

Steel-types: Jirachi takes little damage from Hatterene's STAB moves and threatens it back with Iron Head, though it dislikes Mystical Fire. Aegislash is an especially detrimental offensive threat, because even if it takes Mystical Fire on the switch a weakened Shadow Ball still threatens substantial damage; the Swords Dance set can take a Mystical Fire and obliterate Hatterene with a STAB move. Celesteela does not take too much damage from Mystical Fire due to its massive special bulk, and it 2HKOes with Heavy Slam.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description:
Hatterene has plenty of opportunities to gain a Calm Mind boost against various Pokemon such as Mandibuzz and Hydreigon, though it does have to be wary of Flash Cannon from the latter. Calm Mind notably helps Hatterene stomach hits from strong attackers such as Choice Specs Keldeo better and retaliate with Draining Kiss. Draining Kiss is mandatory as a powerful recovery tool and is instrumental against Chansey; after three boosts, Draining Kiss + Leftovers will outheal Seismic Toss's damage. Psyshock is useful against opposing Calm Mind users, most notably Primarina, as well as a more immediate weapon against Chansey. Psychic is an alternative option because it OHKOes Amoonguss after one Calm Mind boost instead of two. It also helps Hatterene pressure Quagsire better with Special Defense drops. Mystical Fire is vital to deter Steel-types looking to come in on a Calm Mind or STAB move like Celesteela, Jirachi, and Aegislash. Leftovers augments the recovery from Draining Kiss and makes Hatterene harder for Pokemon such as Suicune to wear down. Hatterene needs 12 EVs in Speed to outrun Amoonguss and 56 EVs to outspeed Quagsire and help against stall, though Psychic is required for the latter Pokemon.

Hatterene fits well on balance and bulky offense teams that appreciate its Magic Bounce relieving entry hazard pressure from Skarmory. Pokemon that handle hazard setters Hatterene cannot switch into well like Nidoqueen, Jirachi, and Nihilego are appreciated. Chansey and Celesteela are able to check them. Celesteela can also pivot into Excadrill. Hazard support from teammates such as Krookodile and Chansey wears down Hatterene checks such as Aegislash and Celesteela. Fire-types can blow through Steel-types that Hatterene has issues with; Rotom-H and Moltres are notably able to check Aegislash and take advantage of Celesteela. Amoonguss and Skarmory can act as secondary pivots into Mienshao and Conkeldurr as repeatedly taking hits from them and losing its Leftovers greatly diminishes its ability to clean with Calm Mind.

Obstagoon.overview: Obstagoon is the only Guts user with STAB Facade, allowing it to pressure physical walls such as Amoonguss with ease. Its solid bulk, decent Speed, and access to STAB Knock Off make it a unique offensive threat, being able to take out metagame staples like Rotom-W, Galarian Moltres, and most notably SubToxic Aegislash, who cannot touch Obstagoon due to its typing and status immunity. It also has an excellent matchup against slower bulkier teams because of its status immunity, ability to heal off chip damage with Rest, and high damage output with STAB Knock Off. Due to its poor defensive typing, Obstagoon is easily revenge killed by common threats like Thundurus-T and Lycanroc-D. The abundance of Fighting-types like Buzzwole, Keldeo, and Kommo-o is especially problematic for Obstagoon due to its 4x weakness to fighting moves. Also, it tends to have poorer matchups against hyper offense, as teams pack more faster threats that give Obstagoon few opportunities to wallbreak, although it still can potentially pick up a KO or two. Obstagoon hates Knock Off as it cannot activate Guts without its Flame Orb, severly limiting its threat level. Its overreliance on Sleep Talk isn't ideal, as it relies on RNG to click the correct move. Obstagoon is generally outclassed by other offensive Dark-types like Krookodile and Zarude due to their better defensive utility and less reliance on their item.
Obstagoon.comments:
Other Options

Bulk Up makes Obstagoon more difficult to revenge kill due to the increase in power and bulk, but its 4x weakness to Fighting still makes getting anywhere with setup difficult in the long term. Obstruct can stall a turn to activate Obstagoon's Flame Orb while also potentially halving the Defense of normal checks such as Buzzwole. Parting Shot allows it to pivot on switch-ins such as Buzzwole.

Checks and Counters

Fighting-types Moves: Fighting-types such as Keldeo and Mienshao can outspeed Obstagoon and KO it with ease with their STAB moves. Conkeldurr can also KO it with Mach Punch. Faster Pokemon with Fighting-type coverage like Lycanroc-D and Thundurus-T can also threaten it out. All of these Pokemon struggle to pivot into Obstagoon.

Physically Defensive Pokemon: Rhyperior, Buzzwole, and Diancie almost completely stonewall Obstagoon, though the former doesn't like Knock Off. Tangrowth can wear down Obstagoon with Rocky Helmet chip, forcing it to use Rest.

Residual Damage: Obstagoon puts itself on a timer as soon as it activates Flame Orb, so it can prematurely faint after a strong neutral hit. Entry hazards can chip it down a lot in conjunction with the burn damage. This residual damage also pressures Obstagoon to use Rest often, limiting its effectiveness as a wallbreaker.

sets.name: Guts
sets.description:
Facade combined with Knock Off gives Obstagoon excellent neutral coverage against the majority of the tier. Rest can patch up residual damage from Rocky Helmet users such as Tangrowth and Amoonguss. It can also let Obstagoon completely wall SubToxic Aegislash and give Obstagoon longevity against bulkier teams. Sleep Talk lets Obstagoon be a potent wallbreaker while asleep thanks to Guts remaining active. Close Combat OHKOs the only Pokemon in the tier that resist Obstagoon's STAB combination, Cobalion, while also letting it hit foes like Krookodile harder. Switcheroo can be used alongside Close Combat to cripple some slower physical attackers like Azumarill, Crawdaunt, and Tapu Bulu. It can also mess with defensive Salamence and Buzzwole by adding chip damage and getting rid of the former's Heavy-Duty Boots.

Obstagoon fits well onto bulky offense and balance teams that can generate turns for it to break consistently with the right offensive and defensive pivots. Rotom-H can bring Obstagoon in safely and pressure Amoonguss, physically defensive Tangrowth, and Celesteela. Noivern can revenge kill threats to Obstagoon like Keldeo and Cobalion. Obstagoon can also fit well on Sticky Web teams with Ribombee and Shuckle to patch up its Speed a bit. It also appreciates entry hazard support from Roserade, Nidoqueen, and Nihilego to get KOs on threats like Azumarill, Mamoswine, and Tangrowth. Amoonguss and Primarina are great defensive pivots, using their Fighting resistance to check foes that would try to revenge kill Obstagoon like Keldeo.

Indeedee-F.overview: Indeedee-F has a niche as a Psychic Terrain setter that is capable of enabling powerful threats like Necrozma, Polteageist, and Meteor Beam Nihilego. Its Healing Wish lets it replenish the health of weakened teammates to give them a second shot at sweeping, making Indeedee-F superior to Indeedee-M. Furthermore, Expanding Force gives Indeedee-F a decent offensive presence by threatening common Pokemon like Amoonguss and Buzzwole, and its defensive typing even allows it to switch into Ghost-type attacks from Aegislash. However, Indeedee-F is frail and slow, causing it to be outsped and KOed by common offensive threats like Krookodile, Zarude, and Salamence. Indeedee-F's Special Attack is also underwhelming at times, and it struggles to break through defensive staples like Celesteela, Rhyperior, and Assault Vest Tangrowth. Psychic Terrain is a niche playstyle in UU, limiting Indeedee-F's viability compared to other offensive Psychic-types like Starmie and Azelf.
Indeedee-F.comments:
Other Options

Indeedee-F can run Future Sight to support its team, but it is hard to fit over other moves. Indeedee-F can also utilize a Choice Specs or Choice Scarf set to act as a decent wallbreaker or priority-immune revenge killer, but Indeedee-M outclasses it due to having better Special Attack and speed. However, Indeedee-M itself is outclassed by more dangerous Psychic-types like Necrozma and Azelf.

Checks and Counters

Dark-types: Krookodile and Zarude outspeed and OHKO Indeedee-F, although they dont like to switch into Dazzling Gleam. Umbreon walls Indeedee-F and takes advantage of it by passing Wish to a teammate. Galarian Moltres can either KO Indeedee-F or use it as setup fodder with Nasty Plot.

Specially Defensive Walls: Chansey, Assault Vest Tangrowth, and Assault Vest Reuniclus can take Indeedee-F's attacks and hinder it with status or item removal. Celesteela is also able to come in and force it out, although it dislikes switching into Mystical Fire repeatedly.

Faster Threats: Pokemon like Lycanroc-D, Keldeo, and Salamence outspeed and OHKO Indeedee-F. Salamence can also remove Indeedee-F's Psychic Terrain with Defog, allowing it to take advantage of Indeedee-F switching out to come in and set up Psychic Terrain again.

sets.name: Terrain Setter
sets.description:
Expanding Force KOes threats like Kommo-o, Amoonguss, and Buzzwole in Psychic Terrain. Dazzling Gleam handles Dark-types like Krookodile and Zarude, which attempt to switch into Expanding Force. Mystical Fire is Indeedee-F's best option for hurting Steel-types like Aegislash and Jirachi as well as Assault Vest Tangrowth. It also helps lower the Special Attack of switch-ins like Galarian Moltres and Assault Vest Reuniclus, allowing its teammates to more easily set up on them. Indeedee-F can utilize Healing Wish late-game to fully heal a teammate, giving them a second chance to sweep. It also allows Indeedee-F to preserve momentum by letting a sweeper in with a free switch. Terrain Extender maximizes Psychic Terrain turns, giving teammates like Polteageist and Necrozma an easier time sweeping.

Indeedee-F fits best on offense teams centered around the support it offers with Psychic Terrain. Sweepers like Polteageist, Scolipede, Dragon Dance Necrozma, and Meteor Beam Nihilego appreciate Psychic Terrain boosting their attacks or nullifying priority moves, allowing them to sweep through teams more easily. For example, Polteageist can OHKO Assault Vest Tangrowth with Stored Power in Psychic Terrain after Weak Armor has been activated, while Meteor Beam Nihilego no longer has to fear priority from Azumarill when Psychic Terrain is up. All of these Pokemon also like Healing Wish support. Krookodile provides entry hazard support to wear down Pokemon like Celesteela and cripples Chansey and Assault Vest Tangrowth with Knock Off. Choice Scarf Krookodile is a massive threat to Psychic Terrain teams, so Pokemon like Zarude and Kommo-o are great teammates to handle it. The aforementioned Zarude and Registeel can utilize a Psychic Seed sweeper set with Indeedee-F's support to sweep teams. Zarude especially likes Amoonguss and Buzzwole being threatened by Indeedee-F. Hatterene discourages entry hazards from being set against the team and wears down Umbreon.

Zarude.overview: Zarude's great Speed alongside U-turn allows it to be an excellent pivot and revenge killer. Its Speed enables it to outspeed common Pokemon such as Nihilego and Thundurus-T, and its good bulk and defensive typing let it check many dangerous threats such as Aegislash, Slowking, and Krookodile. The ability to heal status conditions and HP with Jungle Healing can allow Zarude to consistently pivot around defensive Pokemon such as Swampert and Aegislash. However, it often struggles to break defensive Pokemon, such as Celesteela, Tangrowth, and Salamence, due to them resisting Power Whip and taking minimal damage from Darkest Lariat. Many teams naturally fit multiple Grass-type resistant Pokemon such as Mandibuzz, Tangrowth, and Moltres, leaving Zarude with limited opportunities to click its strongest STAB attack. If it is running Choice Scarf, Zarude can risk being locked into an undesirable move, losing momentum. Flame Body from Moltres and Rocky Helmet from Amoonguss and Tangrowth can punish U-turn, forcing momentum to be sacrificed to use Jungle Healing.
Zarude.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band allows Zarude to function as a powerful wallbreaker. However, the lack of Speed from Choice Scarf and increased prediction-reliance are problematic, and it still struggles to break through Skarmory, Mandibuzz, and Salamence. A Bulk Up set with Jungle Healing, Acrobatics, and Darkest Lariat allows Zarude to deal heavy damage and potentially tank super effective hits. Psychic Seed alongside Bulk Up + Synthesis on Psychic Terrain teams allows it to be a fantastic Krookodile counter, greatly benefiting its teammates by allowing them to spam their Psychic-type moves more easily. Zarude can also become a better setup sweeper by taking hits from Salamence and Tangrowth more easily. Taunt is an option that can completely shut down Chansey's recovery and prevent Roost from Salamence, but Zarude would have to give up Jungle Healing or valuable coverage. Encore on Choice Scarf sets can be used to punish setup sweepers such as Galarian Moltres and Dragon Dance Salamence so that a teammate such as Mamoswine can safely switch in and threaten them. However, it is very situational, and Zarude is forced to switch afterwards.

Checks and Counters

Fast U-turn Users: Faster Pokemon such as Noivern, Azelf, and Choice Scarf Mienshao are able to put Zarude in a tough spot. It either has to take heavy damage from U-turn, or switch out, meaning that these threats can pivot freely. However, the former two must watch out to see if Zarude is running a Choice Scarf set.

Grass-types: Grass-types such as Amoonguss and Tangrowth take little damage from Zarude's STAB attacks, while Tapu Bulu resists both. Amoonguss and Tangrowth can threaten Zarude out with Sludge Bomb, with Tapu Bulu threatening it out with Close Combat, or set up on it with Swords Dance.

Flying-types: Salamence, Moltres, and Galarian Moltres can switch into Zarude's attacks easily. Salamence can weaken Zarude's hits with Intimidate, Moltres can threaten a burn with Flame Body, and Galarian Moltres resists both STAB attacks. They all must watch out for Rock Slide, though.

Physical Walls: Mandibuzz, Cobalion, Skarmory, and Celesteela all take minimal damage from Zarude's STAB attacks, with the former two resisting both. They can all retaliate with super effective attacks to deal heavy damage to Zarude.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Zarude's STAB combination allows it to threaten many tier staples like Azumarill, Excadrill, and Aegislash. U-turn grabs momentum on usual switch-ins such as Celesteela and Salamence. Jungle Healing allows Zarude to remove status conditions from moves such as Toxic from Aegislash and Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W, while restoring 25% of its health. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Zarude to not worry about entry hazards, letting it constantly pivot throughout the game. Jolly is the required nature on the set so that Zarude can outspeed Nihilego and Thundurus-T.

Heavy-Duty Boots Zarude is seen on balance and bulky offense due to the easy pivoting provided by Heavy-Duty Boots and its ability to act as a status sponge against Toxic from Aegislash and Will-O-Wisp from Rotom-W. Secondary pivots like Mienshao, Thundurus-T, and Swampert all form potent pivoting cores with Zarude. Mienshao can revenge kill faster threats like Azelf and Lycanroc-D if holding a Choice Scarf, while Thundurus-T heavily pressures Celesteela and Moltres. Swampert can pivot into attacks from Celesteela and set entry hazards for Zarude to soften up Pokemon like Tangrowth with Stealth Rock. Other entry hazard setters like Diancie, Skarmory, and Excadrill also can do this and appreciate Zarude dealing with Water-types such as Rotom-W, while Zarude appreciates them dealing with Salamence, Mamoswine, and Rotom-H. Primarina, Nidoking, and Chandelure are wallbreakers that appreciate Zarude bringing them in on Salamence, Tangrowth, and Amoonguss, as they often have trouble switching in safely due to their low Speed and frailty.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Zarude's high Speed allows it to be a great user of Choice Scarf that can revenge kill Pokemon such as Keldeo and Azelf in addition to boosted sweepers such as Gyarados and Dragon Dance Necrozma. Power Whip OHKOes Lycanroc-D and Keldeo. Darkest Lariat is Zarude's strongest Dark-type STAB move and can hit Jirachi and Aegislash for good damage. Jungle Healing can get rid of status conditions such as a burn from Moltres's Flame Body and Slowking's Scald while regaining HP so that Zarude can be used in the long run in a battle but it is not ideal to lock into. Rock Slide allows Zarude to OHKO Moltres while also dealing good damage to Salamence. U-turn allows Zarude to pivot out on potential switch-ins such as Tangrowth, Celesteela, and Kommo-o, allowing it to gain momentum.

Choice Scarf Zarude is an excellent pivot and revenge killer on bulky offense. It appreciates additional pivots such as Mienshao and Rotom-W that can form VoltTurn cores and pivot out of unfavorable matchups. For example, Mienshao can bring Zarude in on Psychic-types such as Reuniclus and Galarian Slowbro. Entry hazard control allows Zarude to consistently pivot without worrying about hazard damage. Rapid Spin support from Excadrill and Tentacruel is appreciated, and they can also check threats like Tapu Bulu and Celesteela. Thundurus-T, Chandelure, and Nidoking are wallbreakers that appreciate Zarude's pivot support and its ability to check Pokemon such as Rhyperior, with the wallbreakers KOing Pokemon such as Amoonguss and Celesteela in return. Nidoqueen is an entry hazard setter that appreciates Zarude dealing with revenge killers like Keldeo, Starmie, and Azelf for it while Nidoqueen can set Stealth Rock in return and also help deal with Pokemon like Tapu Bulu and Tangrowth. Primarina and Azumarill can help deal with some of Zarude's checks such as Salamence.
